story:
About Us.

Ambiance Theatre Company is a new collective of passionate voices dedicated to nurturing unchained imaginations. Here we dive into folklore, science fiction, memoir, history, and community narratives in order to support a haven of creative minds often left on the margins of the theatre world.

 

Play Synopsis.

Waiting in Vain is a story about four young and Black teens who rob a gas station and hide out in an abandoned store blocks away.  As they devise a plan to escape home unscathed, they are stricken with agonizing panic, detachment, and nightmares, as the media finds evidence pointing closer to their location - preventing them from returning back into their esteemed lives.

 

Giving back to our Audience and Supporters.

With this donation, not only will you be a key contributor and incubator  for us as an organization, but also make a great impact on funding our first production.  In return, we hope to provide you with:

  • If you donate up to $20 or more, you will be given a free ticket to Waiting in Vain and will be also added to our emailing list.
  • With any donation, donors will also receive acknowledgement in our program through the entire performance run of Waiting in Vain.
  • Frequent (but not taxing) updates via email of our season and events that are taking place with Ambiance.

 

With your help.

This donation will also help us fill in the essential steps that will help Ambiance Theatre grow not only as an organization creating the necessary art of the future, but also help us further give back to our community artistically.  Ambiance Theatre Company is an organization that thrives from nuanced stories that are untold, brave, and seek to help us understand our history.  With your help, we will be able to obtain:

  • Financial stability as a theatre company.
  • More resources for future productions and build a season.
  • Compensation for all the artists we work with.
  • And a soon to be dream toward paying for staff.

 

Where we seek to Grow.

As we sprout our seeds as a theatre organization, patience is a true virtue.  We don't want to over feed, nor feed enough to help the fruits of our labor grow.  We see where we can become more effective, efficient, and supportive.  However, we always seek change and will listen to our community.  Moving forward, our goals for this next year are the following:

  • Collaborate with other theatre organizations, artists, and other community organizers.
  • Build a social media presence.
  • Put on at least 2-3 productions within our 2019-20 season.
  • Organize community events, curation, and gatherings.
  • Build a team for Ambiance Theatre and grow an administration. 

 

We are a resource.

If you have any further questions, comments, or curiosity of who we are, please contact us at ambiancetc@gmail.com and place in the subject line, "ATC - Indiegogo"

story:
(**To give any amount, press the "back it" button at the top of this page**)

 

WHO Are We?

We are Heather and Dave.  We are Lovers of the Arts and St. Pete, Florida.  We have been in the Entertainment and Theater industry for over 40 years combined with college degrees as firm foundations.   We have had the roles of a Performer, Educator, Manager, Coordinator, Producer, just to name a few.

We own a Production Company called Keltherave Productions, LLC. The purpose of Keltherave is to promote positive human connection through the power of Creativity and Education.

And finally, we have a dream of opening our own Theater.  We want our Production Company to operate our new Theater called: The Mar Theater.


WHAT is The Mar Theater?

Essentially, The Mar Theater will be a Creative Development Center; or as some of our colleagues have coined it, a Performing Arts Incubator.  

In this Theater:

  • Performing artists of all kinds are welcome.
  • Local working artists can take real-world applicable workshops.
  • Performance Companies and Organizations will have a new “home.”
  • Artists will be able to collaborate with like-minded individuals from around St. Petersburg and find powerful new connections.  
  • Events such as concerts, theatre, dance recitals, weddings, and so much more 

 

WHERE will The Mar Be?

In a warehouse building, 5000 square feet, located in Downtown Saint Petersburg, Florida.  

 

WHEN will The Mar Open?

Within 6 months we envision that we will secure the building and begin the build out.  We will launch the Theater in 2020.

 

WHY are we Doing This?

Because:

We believe in you, your potential, and what you have to offer, those around you. 

We believe in St. Petersburg, Florida. 

We believe in the power of Creative Collaboration, and how when given a safe environment and inspiration, an individual’s potential soars. 

The result: Radical Transformation.

Radical transformation in confidence,

Radical transformation in relationships, 

Radical transformation in community

 

With all That Said…

Here is What We’ve Done   

  1. We have been approved for a Small Business Administration Loan that is guaranteed by the Government - NOT our personal assets
  2. We have a strong Business Plan that has been reviewed by several business minds
  3. We have a fantastic list of revenue sources 
  4. We have a Theater Feasibility Consultant to set our business up for success
  5. We are working with amazing people and organizations around the Arts and Business Industries local and beyond:
  • Lance Olsen & Associates – Business Feasibility 
  • Fischbach Commercial – Commercial Real Estate
  • Lovewell Institute for the Creative Arts - Creative Workshop Programming 
  • City of St. Petersburg - The Mayor’s Office  
  • Suncoast Credit Union - Banking Services
  • Skyway Media - Website Design
  • Big3 Entertainment - Audio / Visual Consulting
  • The Edwards Group - Business Guidance
  • Different Church - Partner
  • Stanley Black & Decker - Business Guidance
  • Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings - Collaborations
  • Academy of Ballet Arts - Collaborations
  • St. Pete City Theatre - Collaborations
  • TBBCA - Business Guidance / Networking
  • Your Real Stories - Collaborations
  • Warehouse Arts District Association - Collaborations
  • Conscious Accounting - Accounting Services
  • USF School of Theatre and Dance - Collaborations
  • Short Stage North Columbus, Ohio - Business Guidance
  • Bay Hope Church - Business Guidance
  • One Step Media - Marketing
  • St. Pete Arts Alliance - Collaborations
  • Huffman General Contractors Inc. - General Contractor
  • Architechtonics Studio - Architecture Firm

 

Here is What We Still Need to do

  1. Secure the total down payment to close on the SBA loan
  2. Finalize the design of the space and get true numbers of costs
  3. Finalize the timeline

 

FAQ’s:

What if We Get Our Entire Loan? (a.k.a. The Perfect Scenario)

  • We will sign our lease for our dream space and begin Phase One
  • Phase One - Build out begins
  • $150,000 will be our build out budget
  • Phase Two - Transform the space into a Theater with staging, lighting, audio
  • $41,000 will go to the Theater fixtures
  • Phase Three - Open Those Doors!!
  • $34,000 will go towards working capital to get us started

What if We Don’t Get Our Entire Loan? 

  • We will use the funds we can gather to get the loan amount that the funding allows
  • We will work with our Architect and General Contractor to see what getting everything up to code will cost
  • We will sign our lease for our dream space and begin Phase One
  • Phase One - Minimal build out - getting everything up to code
  • Phase Two - Host a fundraising event in the building for the next 2 phases 
  • Phase Three - Transform the space into a Theater with staging, lighting, audio
  • Phase Four - Open Those Doors!! Use fundraising funds for working capital

story:
What is the Alumni Company?

Each summer, the Shakespeare Academy @ Stratford invites former students to return to Stratford to create and perform a mobile production of a play by Shakespeare.

The Alumni Company is tasked with creating, directing, performing and producing a play of Shakespeare. Putting the skills they gained during their time as students at SA@S into practice and gaining real-world experience in all aspects of theater making, including:

  • devising and staging a play by Shakespeare
  • collaborating as an ensemble
  • fundraising
  • producing
  • publicity
  • adapting Shakespeare's text 
  • planning and managing a tour
  • designing set, costume, and sound
  • and training as teaching artists, with a new focus on community outreach this year.

Last year's Alumni Company has passed the baton onto a trio of intrepid theater-makers: Annie Saenger, Ellis, Sargeant, and Robert Solomon.  To support their residency in Stratford and the tour this summer, we hope to raise $2500. (That breaks down roughly to $600 for travel expenses, $600 for production costs, $800 for actor pay, and $500 to cover living expenses while in Stratford.)

 

The Impact

Last summer, four actors (Zoe Chen, Meaghan Johnson, Shana Laski, and Oliver Shoulson) took to the road with a clothesline, a ukulele, and their production of THE TAMING OF THE SHREW. For two weeks, they travelled along the east coast and beyond, making stops in Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York City, as well as far abroad as Chicago. The Alumni Company began and ended their tour at the home of SA@S,  on the grounds of the former American Shakespeare Festival Theater.  The Alumni Company has performed at summer camps, art galleries, private homes, wineries, parks, schools, and universities.

Last year's Alumni Company not only grew as artists and collaborators, but also used the performance and process to engage with communities and local businesses to bring Shakespeare to people of all walks of life. By providing communities all along the eastern seaboard with FREE SHAKESPEARE, the Alumni Company accomplishes its goal of making Shakespeare accessible - and worth accessing - to everyone.

 

"One of the most rewarding parts of the experience (and also one of the biggest challenges) is creating a truly self-contained show. You have minimal sets and costume resources, just whatever you can pack into a trunk, the rest of the story really comes from yourselves as actors. You have to build the rest of that world with your bodies and voices, and the best part is when you can see the audience is in that world with you." -Mia DeLasho (Alumni Co. 2016)

 

"For company members, this is a unique opportunity to take ownership of our own theatre-making experience, experiment and explore collaboratively.  Confidence in choice making and cross-over in responsibility for production roles is the main benefit of this freedom--working on multiple aspects of one production expands the appreciation for the way those different threads interweave, and experiences as a director can feed one’s approach to acting and vice versa.  Theatre is a field where being able to generate, publicize, and produce one’s own work is an incredible asset. " -Olivia Gregorich (Alumni Co. 2016)

 

"The most rewarding part of the experience was when audience members stumbled upon the performance, like when we were at Short Beach in Stratford, CT... When kids would just sit completely rapt in the play and what we were doing. They got it. That's a pretty amazing feeling as an actor."- Kelly Letourneau (Alumni Co. 2015)

 

Risks & Challenges

Every summer, the Alumni Company is faced with the challenges of cutting down a Shakespeare play, creating a show (without a director), collaborating and managing egos in the rehearsal room, working within a limited budget, balancing time management and creativity, and the risk of sharing their own work with the world. 

Macbeth is one of Shakespeare’s most famous plays - its cultural purchase as a story of temptation, sin, and immense cruelty is almost unparalleled. In this production, we hope to breathe new life into the play by pushing against assumptions and questioning everything we think we know about Shakespeare’s most famous murderers. We hope to focus our investigation on three main facets of the play:

1. Gender roles, and what happens when they’re questioned, challenged, and even inverted.

2. The intersection of human choice and fate, and the point at which actions become irreversible and the future becomes inevitable.

3. Fear, and how the unknown cripples us in both action and identity.

As a three-person company, we have a unique opportunity to interrogate the play in an intense and novel way. Each challenge we face when working with such a reduced cast is another chance to use a creative solution to ask new questions and tell a new story with the text of the play. With your help, we hope to simultaneously do homage to and reimagine Macbeth.”

 

"Projects like these necessitate myriad risks and challenges….But one amazing thing about theater is that often it is the risks and the challenges that lead to growth, to intrigue and to change. “Risk” is not a dirty word in theater. The truth is, we don’t watch movies and shows to be entertained. We see them to be challenged—our beliefs, our intellect, our convictions, our disbelief—and to overcome those challenges. Audiences see theater to challenge and learn about themselves. And if the actors are not challenged, how could the audience ever be?"- Nate Currier of the 2015 Alumni Company

 

The Mighty Quinn Foundation, Inc. 

SA@S and its Alumni Company are a project of the Mighty Quinn Foundation, a 501(c)(3) charity dedicated to providing educational and theatrical experiences for young artists. A lifelong Stratford resident, Quinn Rooney grew up next door to the theater grounds and always hoped to see them revitalized. He passed away in June 2012 from a rare form of brain cancer at age 19, having led life to the fullest. SA@S holds the example of Quinn's great joy, utmost generosity, indefatigable spirit, and love for the fellowship of sharing theater with friends at the heart of its founding values.

 

Other Ways You Can Help!

Please help us continue to spread the word, both about the Shakespeare Academy @ Stratford and the Alumni Company fundraising effort, by sharing with your friends, family, and the Stratford community. Read more about the Alumni Company on Facebook, Instagram, and our website. Stay tuned for information on this summer's tour!


If you’re interested in bringing MACBETH to your town, city, school, home, or any other location, please contact Robert.

story:
How to support:

By clicking the pink BACK IT button, you may enter any amount you wish to contribute.  Or you can select one of the PERKS levels and and receive the corresponding benefits.  

 

Overview

November 21, 2019 marks the 20th anniversary of the passing of Quentin Crisp, English-born writer, actor, eccentric and raconteur. He became famous from the publication of his 1968 autobiography THE NAKED CIVIL SERVANT, which chronicled the oppression he faced as a homosexual in England before, during and after World War II, when being gay was illegal. THE NAKED CIVIL SERVANT later became an award-winning film starring John Hurt, first broadcast in the United States by PBS in 1975. Crisp performed a one-man show, AN EVENING WITH QUENTIN CRISP, which he toured nationally and internationally and which won an L.A. Drama Critic’s Circle and Drama Desk award. Crisp moved to New York at the age of 72, where he wrote books on style, culture and manners, appeared in numerous films and late night talk show interviews, and published a second autobiography, HOW TO BECOME A VIRGIN. He has been immortalized in artworks by Al Hirschfeld and was the inspiration for Sting’s hit song "An Englishman In New York." The third and final installment of his autobiography, THE LAST WORD: AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY, was published posthumously in 2017, while AND ONE MORE THING, his last book, was published in 2018 and includes his collected poetry and the script of his one-man show. Both books display Crisp's insightful, amusing, and at times controversial philosophies which remain surprisingly relevant today, including the revelation at age 90 that he was not in fact homosexual, but rather transgender.

Pittsburgh writer, producer, performer, arts advocate, and Crisp scholar Brian Edward has been selected by Phillip Ward and the Quentin Crisp Estate to collaborate on the composition of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD, a new stage script and performance extracted from the writings contained within THE LAST WORD: AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY and AND ONE MORE THING, which will have its wold premiere in Pittsburgh in February 2020 before touring nationally and internationally.  The project is seeking funding from individual donors, corporations, and grants to cover production expenses, marketing, and the professional filming of the show to submit for local and national broadcast, and to offer support that will continue the legacy of Quentin Crisp and the continuation of the Quentin Crisp Archives far into the future.

 

What We Need & What It Will Do

For this campaign, we have set a fundraising goal of $65,000 with the optimism that it will reach and engage admirers of Quentin Crisp worldwide.  Your contribution will help fund:

  • The stage production of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD, February 6 - 16, 2020.  (Rentals, designer fees, production team, set, costume, lighting, makeup, ticketing fees.)
  • Marketing and outreach for QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD.
  • Future touring productions of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD
  • A professional filming of the stage production to submit for broadcast on public television.
  • To support, carry on, and expand the mission of the Quentin Crisp Archives and the Crisp legacy far into the future.

 

What You'll Get

In addition to the satisfaction of being a part of Quentin Crisp's continuing legacy, this campaign offers many rewards at different donation levels:  

  • Acknowledgment of your contribution in the show program, social media, and website.
  • Items from the official Quentin Crisp Style Shop, authorized by Phillip Ward and the Quentin Crisp Estate.
  • Copies of the recently published books by Quentin, signed by editor and estate executor Phillip Ward.
  • At the top donation levels, a trademark scarf owned and worn by Quentin, accompanied by a certificate of authenticity from Phillip Ward and the Quentin Crisp Estate.
  • Your donation is tax deductible.  The fiscal sponsor for this project is 'Burgh Vivant, a 501c(3) nonprofit organization.

 

​The Impact

Quentin Crisp was an important voice in the history of LGBTQIA liberation, though his works and influence are at risk of slipping into obscurity. Perhaps it was advantageous that Phillip Ward recorded Crisp's final autobiography shortly before his passing in 1999 and did not publish it until 2017. In a sense, it's an exciting comeback from someone who never actually went away, as Quentin Crisp's observations and philosophies seem even more relevant today than they did in his own time. The stage work QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD celebrates the gift of Crisp's farewell to us all, delivered 20 years after his death. It celebrates the fact that he is still with us, and reminds us that now, especially within the current climate of cultural strife laden with attacks on civil liberties, his powerful words can lend great inspiration. As has been stated, this project intends to initiate the official founding of a nonprofit organization that will foster and continue that inspiration indefinitely.

Many people today struggle with identity, especially LGBTQIA individuals, despite the advances in equality and acceptance. The works and words of Quentin Crisp offer refuge and inspiration for those who struggle with who they really are, and how to interact with the vast and often cruel world at large. Although his wisdom comes from an LGBTQIA perspective, Crisp's anecdotes and examples are universally relatable, while at the same time, wildly entertaining. The very particular voice of Quentin Crisp can be a beacon of hope to many today, just as it was in his lifetime. This particular stage presentation gives a more intimate look at Crisp than any piece prior, and in the author's own words upon entering the final days of his life.

 

Risks & Challenges

Although $65k is a lofty goal, we know that Quentin Crisp has touched many minds and many generations all around the globe.  It is important to note that the premiere production of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD will take place regardless of the final amount of funds raised.  The degree to which the goal is reached will determine how well we are able to achieve the goals of production quality, marketing and outreach, filming for television, and to provide funds that will maintain Quentin Crisp's legacy after the production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Purchase tickets in advance to attend QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD at www.quentincrisp.org

  • Shop the official Quentin Crisp Style Shop at www.quentincrisp.org.  Proceeds benefit the world premiere of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD and the Quentin Crisp Archives.  Great for holiday gift-giving!

  • Share this campaign, the performance, and the Quentin Crisp Style Shop with friends.
  • Hold a small fundraising event of your own with fellow Crisp fans in honor of the 20th anniversary of his passing with readings from his books and poetry.  Contact us to cooperate and coordinate.
story_txt:
How to support:
By clicking the pink BACK IT button, you may enter any amount you wish to contribute.  Or you can select one of the PERKS levels and and receive the corresponding benefits.  
 
Overview
November 21, 2019 marks the 20th anniversary of the passing of Quentin Crisp, English-born writer, actor, eccentric and raconteur. He became famous from the publication of his 1968 autobiography THE NAKED CIVIL SERVANT, which chronicled the oppression he faced as a homosexual in England before, during and after World War II, when being gay was illegal. THE NAKED CIVIL SERVANT later became an award-winning film starring John Hurt, first broadcast in the United States by PBS in 1975. Crisp performed a one-man show, AN EVENING WITH QUENTIN CRISP, which he toured nationally and internationally and which won an L.A. Drama Critic’s Circle and Drama Desk award. Crisp moved to New York at the age of 72, where he wrote books on style, culture and manners, appeared in numerous films and late night talk show interviews, and published a second autobiography, HOW TO BECOME A VIRGIN. He has been immortalized in artworks by Al Hirschfeld and was the inspiration for Sting’s hit song "An Englishman In New York." The third and final installment of his autobiography, THE LAST WORD: AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY, was published posthumously in 2017, while AND ONE MORE THING, his last book, was published in 2018 and includes his collected poetry and the script of his one-man show. Both books display Crisp's insightful, amusing, and at times controversial philosophies which remain surprisingly relevant today, including the revelation at age 90 that he was not in fact homosexual, but rather transgender.
Pittsburgh writer, producer, performer, arts advocate, and Crisp scholar Brian Edward has been selected by Phillip Ward and the Quentin Crisp Estate to collaborate on the composition of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD, a new stage script and performance extracted from the writings contained within THE LAST WORD: AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY and AND ONE MORE THING, which will have its wold premiere in Pittsburgh in February 2020 before touring nationally and internationally.  The project is seeking funding from individual donors, corporations, and grants to cover production expenses, marketing, and the professional filming of the show to submit for local and national broadcast, and to offer support that will continue the legacy of Quentin Crisp and the continuation of the Quentin Crisp Archives far into the future.

 
What We Need & What It Will Do
For this campaign, we have set a fundraising goal of $65,000 with the optimism that it will reach and engage admirers of Quentin Crisp worldwide.  Your contribution will help fund:

The stage production of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD, February 6 - 16, 2020.  (Rentals, designer fees, production team, set, costume, lighting, makeup, ticketing fees.)
Marketing and outreach for QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD.
Future touring productions of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD
A professional filming of the stage production to submit for broadcast on public television.
To support, carry on, and expand the mission of the Quentin Crisp Archives and the Crisp legacy far into the future.


 
What You'll Get
In addition to the satisfaction of being a part of Quentin Crisp's continuing legacy, this campaign offers many rewards at different donation levels:  

Acknowledgment of your contribution in the show program, social media, and website.
Items from the official Quentin Crisp Style Shop, authorized by Phillip Ward and the Quentin Crisp Estate.
Copies of the recently published books by Quentin, signed by editor and estate executor Phillip Ward.
At the top donation levels, a trademark scarf owned and worn by Quentin, accompanied by a certificate of authenticity from Phillip Ward and the Quentin Crisp Estate.
Your donation is tax deductible.  The fiscal sponsor for this project is 'Burgh Vivant, a 501c(3) nonprofit organization.

 
​The Impact
Quentin Crisp was an important voice in the history of LGBTQIA liberation, though his works and influence are at risk of slipping into obscurity. Perhaps it was advantageous that Phillip Ward recorded Crisp's final autobiography shortly before his passing in 1999 and did not publish it until 2017. In a sense, it's an exciting comeback from someone who never actually went away, as Quentin Crisp's observations and philosophies seem even more relevant today than they did in his own time. The stage work QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD celebrates the gift of Crisp's farewell to us all, delivered 20 years after his death. It celebrates the fact that he is still with us, and reminds us that now, especially within the current climate of cultural strife laden with attacks on civil liberties, his powerful words can lend great inspiration. As has been stated, this project intends to initiate the official founding of a nonprofit organization that will foster and continue that inspiration indefinitely.
Many people today struggle with identity, especially LGBTQIA individuals, despite the advances in equality and acceptance. The works and words of Quentin Crisp offer refuge and inspiration for those who struggle with who they really are, and how to interact with the vast and often cruel world at large. Although his wisdom comes from an LGBTQIA perspective, Crisp's anecdotes and examples are universally relatable, while at the same time, wildly entertaining. The very particular voice of Quentin Crisp can be a beacon of hope to many today, just as it was in his lifetime. This particular stage presentation gives a more intimate look at Crisp than any piece prior, and in the author's own words upon entering the final days of his life.

 
Risks & Challenges
Although $65k is a lofty goal, we know that Quentin Crisp has touched many minds and many generations all around the globe.  It is important to note that the premiere production of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD will take place regardless of the final amount of funds raised.  The degree to which the goal is reached will determine how well we are able to achieve the goals of production quality, marketing and outreach, filming for television, and to provide funds that will maintain Quentin Crisp's legacy after the production.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Purchase tickets in advance to attend QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD at www.quentincrisp.org


Shop the official Quentin Crisp Style Shop at www.quentincrisp.org.  Proceeds benefit the world premiere of QUENTIN CRISP: THE LAST WORD and the Quentin Crisp Archives.  Great for holiday gift-giving!
Share this campaign, the performance, and the Quentin Crisp Style Shop with friends.
Hold a small fundraising event of your own with fellow Crisp fans in honor of the 20th anniversary of his passing with readings from his books and poetry.  Contact us to cooperate and coordinate.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is April Aguilera. I am a singer songwriter/performer, and graduate student at the Savannah College of Art and design. I am  pursuing a graduate degree in dramatic writing. 

I wrote A Sea Full of Stars, as a way to process the unexpected birth diagnosis of my daughter Paloma, with Down Syndrome. The show is presented through monologues and songs that I have written, to express and explain what I went through as a mother  the days leading up to, and the few days after her birth. This show is my love letter to my daughter, told the best way that I know how, through my own words and songs. I will be playing each song on my acoustic guitar, accompanied by my daughter on cello. 

I am currently rehearsing the script,  promoting the Festival performances via online (@aseafullofstarsthemusical on  Facebook and Instagram  ) print media, and currently fundraising for the money it takes to do all of these things.

The funds raised through this campaign will go toward paying for printing postcards and posters to promote the show, as well as program printing and travel expenses.  

All funds raised through ticket sales once the show is up will go toward the  Down Syndrome Diagnosis Network .   

PLEDGE $1 or MORE

All contributors will receive a special thanks on the Sea Full of Stars Facebook page and the shows program.

PLEDGE $50 or MORE 

All contributions of 50 or more will receive the thanks listed above AND a working digital copy of the script as well as production photos, sketches and more!

PLEDGE $100 or MORE

All contributions of $100 or more will receive the thanks, the digital book, AND two tickets to 'A Sea Full of Stars at the Emerging Artists Theatre New Works Festival in New York, 2019 ($10 Festival admission button not included). *Showtime is October 9 at 9pm. Donors who receive tickets will be contacted with pick up instructions*

PLEDGE $250 or MORE

A contribution of $250 or more will receive the thanks, the digital book, the tickets, AND a limited edition glossy show poster!

PLEDGE $500 or MORE

A contribution of $500 or more will receive a producer credit in the show program, two tickets to A Sea Full of Stars in the New Works Festival at the Emerging Artist Theatre in New York, AND a printed hardcopy of the the working script, sketches, production photos and more!

 

Risks & Challenges

This project will be presented at The New Works Festival at the Emerging Artists Theatre this year (2019). The schedule's been set. A script has been crafted and rehearsals are in progress. That is not being challenged. What is at stake, though, is the future of the project beyond this stage. Our goal is to pay all of the extra expenses of mounting this production upfront, so that ticket sales can go toward the Down Syndrome Diagnosis Network.

Other Ways You Can Help

You do not have to contribute monetarily to be a part of the success of this show. You can share our social media pages and tell everyone you know about our performance and campaign !

story:
Hey Everyone!

My name is Tatiana, but you can call me Cha Cha! 
I am a mother of two and I love to dance.

The purpose of my campaign is to:

  • Spread awareness and support  the dance communities, local artists in Eastern Idaho, Utah and Las Vegas
  • Promote said artists and dancers, involving their work/skills
  • Inspire other artists and dancers to find creative outlets and community, during this Covid-19 pandemic
  • Rehabilitate my craft and dance resume

Funding Breakdown

I am looking to raise $2,834.33 for my entire project: 6 videos

  • Videographer- $1,125.00 
  • Venues- $420.00
  • Costuming- $174.45
  • Music Licenses- $525.00
  • Music Edits- $100.00 
  • Video's Cover-Art- $150
  • Travel- $339.88 (This amount specifically pays for my flights.)

The Impact

Why am I doing this?

From a young age, dance has provided me with opportunities of comradery, business, entertainment, culture and self-exploration.
I have always wanted to share my passions for dance and movement, so much that I have found joy in motivating others to pursue dance opportunities as well.

Rexburg, Idaho

While living eastern Idaho for a few years, I immersed myself in dance leadership opportunities: directing, choreographing, collaborating, etc. Through these work experiences, I was able to meet a TON of amazing artists from as young as 4 to 50+ (still young by the way). I had created such a soft spot for the artists here and only wished they could have more local advantages. For example, although there are a number of dance studios within the area, I had hope for more dance-funded opportunities; however, outside of dance recitals and showcases, larger opportunities are held out-of-state. I want to promote these hardworking dancers and their love for dance/movement. I want them to know that just because there are not as many local chances, that it does not mean other opportunities are not out there. I am here to provide but one of the many. As stated in my funding breakdown, my flight price is specifically for Idaho.  There will be three videos filmed here: contemporary, modern and street dance.

Utah

Oh Utah! This area is actually where my Tahitian-collaboration dance video will take place, simply because the majority of dancers live here! While Utah is also known for popular Tahitian-dance competitions, I am not in collaboration with any of them. Within this state, I will be using music from two amazing music artists: Jay Warren and Mimi Knowles 

Las Vegas

One video will be filmed here, of one great family-friend. That is all I will divulge :)

I strongly believe that the creative processes of art--through dance, movement, videography and other mediums--can impart clarity towards a person's goals and identity, as well as provide a safe-space for self-exploration within their craft.

These videos will be showcased through a virtual convention known as PMX: Pacific Media Expo, on 11/21 & 11/22.

Obstacles

What are my challenges?

While it is redundant, money and time are my most difficult challenges.

For instance, it was never my goal to travel out for these videos, but it needs to happen.
All of my choreography, alone and through collaboration, were submitted via text and different social media platforms. I have been choreographing and mocking up this project in my room, and in my parents' kitchen when my children have no babysitters.

As for money, I would gladly pay for this entire project out of my own pocket, but that is not an option.  I am not paying for babysitters while I'm gone; my family has offered to assist. 

This is also a project that, to many people, seems like a fad: "Not super important", "Just for fun", "There is no end goal", "A waste of time", etc.
And to those remarks, I would say, "Yes. This is a lot of fun and fulfilling. I do not know where this will take me, but I have this passion for myself and those around me. I am not about to throw it out and label it as a fad. Dancing is an extension of my nature."
 

HOW TO HELP

I will take any amount you are happy to donate.
Whether or not donating is possible, I would appreciate it if you could:

  • Share my campaign with everyone!
  • Support PMX by joining the free, virtual expo!

Support PMX by joining the free, virtual expo!

story:
OVERVIEW

After a long period of confinement, IN TANDEM LAB is back on stage!! We are excited to announce HERSTORY, set to premiere on August 4th, 2021. Presented in partnership with the Ohio Theater as part of the annual Ice Factory Summer Festival, the show will be one of the earliest live theatre openings that will take place in New York City! 

Initially commissioned by HERE Arts Center, the first version of the play on Zoom was produced in November 2020 during the pandemic. Now, Herstory is opening as a live theater piece this upcoming August. Reworking the online version to become a fully staged play, In Tandem Lab continues with its mission of generating new theatrical experiences inspired by a classic material. This time, Shakespeare's Tempest's female characters have been the source of inspiration as we asked: why are the women in that play mostly silent or absent?

We would love you to get involved and support our return to the stages for our official premier.

WHAT'S HERSTORY ABOUT?

A woman leaves an inheritance. Two younger women who have apparently no relationship with each other are receiving it if they create something together. Excavating the drawings and short stories of an artist, these two women will stop living arrested by their unknown past and come out of isolation by giving life to a woman's story. How can we start telling the stories written in our genes and passed from one generation to another? Inspired but the female characters of Shakespeare's Tempest, Herstory attempts to write an intimate take on revenge, isolation, and the personal prisons we all must overcome.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

This campaign is designed to help us raise funds to cover half of HERSTORY's production expenses to be part of the Ice Factory Festival at The New Ohio Theatre in NYC. With your generous support, we will be able to fully recognize and honor the great work of the artists making HERSTORY possible. Paying our collaborators has always been a principle of our company. Still, after these past months where theater has been hit so hard by the pandemic, it has become more than ever an essential aspect of In Tandem Lab's values. We are requesting US$4,000 to cover the following elements:

  • Artists fees
  • Costume & Set Designer
  • Videographer fees
  • Light operator fees.
  • Essays expenses
  • Travel cost for one of the artists

We have selected some exciting rewards for you, such as entrance tickets to the play,  INTANDEM LAB's tote bag, postcards, and an online meeting with the creators!

THE IMPACT

Silence and entrapment are part of women's histories beyond time and space. At In Tandem Lab, we consider it essential to explore new dramatic territories by creating, commissioning, or reinterpreting classic themes. Herstory excavates women's pasts from the 17th century up to the digital age in the quest for understanding the long history of entrapment and silence that has shaped some of us today. This project is vital to start the conversation and offer alternative narratives to our past inspiring stories from alternative perspectives. 

At the same time, and after almost 17 months of isolation, we are happy to go back into the theater and reconnect with live audiences. As theater makers, we trade in change. This has been evident during the pandemic where so many artists have produced shows using any medium available. Now the possibility of sharing the work with a live audience becomes the central impulse to be together in a room dreaming again.

THE COLLABORATORS

Laura Butler-Levitt, co creator & performer

International actress, director, and choreographer currently living in Vietnam.  She has performed, offered theater workshops, and taught in Turkey, Berlin, Japan, Lithuania, Romania, Italy, US, Australia, Colombia, Vietnam & Puerto Rico. She is a member of Caborca, and a a co-founder of One-Eighth Theater. 

NYC productions: Octopus’s Garden (Caborca); Numbness: chapter 2 (One-Eighth Theater, an Archive Residency production with New Ohio Theater and IRT Theatre); Salomé (M-34); and Distant Star (Caborca); She holds an MFA in Acting from Columbia University, and a BA in Drama from the University of Puerto Rico.

Heather Hollingsworth, co creator & performer

Heather Hollingsworth , a New Orleans native, is an actress, producer, and member of the New Orleans Funk and R&B review Royal American Social Aid and Pleasure Club. She has performed in various plays, workshops and readings with Classic Stage Company, Cherry Lane, MabouMines, The Ohio, LAByrinth, The Women's Project, and The Public. She co-wrote and performed Ask Dr. Mueller, a stage adaptation of the memoirs of writer-outlaw-actress Cookie Mueller; co-wrote, produced, and starred in the short film US. A Family Album, which premiered at the San Francisco International Film Festival and can be seen on the Shorts HD network. She recently appeared in Natalia Iyudin’s THE GARDEN with Sophia Lillis, Ross Kauffman’s Boy Boy Girl Girl with Katie Holmes and SCION for TWO MINUTE HORROR STORIES on the WB. For more, visit her at HeatherHollingsworth.com

Javier Antonio González, writer

Playwright, director, and filmmaker who has served as the artistic director of Caborca since its founding. Some of his authorial work with the company includes: Lying Lydia; Distant Star (adapted from Roberto Bolaño's novel); Zoetrope; Open up, Hadrian; Barceloneta, de noche; FLORIDITA, my Love; and his first feature film, The Entitlement (2018). In 2016, he directed his original translation of A Midsummer Night's Dream in San Juan, Puerto Rico for Teatro en el Parque. His work has been published in the anthologies, Plays and Playwrights 2011 (New York Theatre Experience), Encuentro: Latinx Performance for the New American Theater (Northwestern University Press) and in The Puerto Rico Review. Javier holds a BA from the University of Puerto Rico and an MFA from Columbia University School of the Arts. He was a Van Lier Directing Fellow, a member of the Public Theater’s Emerging Writers Group and a recipient of the Global Connections–In the Lab grant from Theatre Communications Group. He has taught at DreamYard Prep, LaGuardia Community College, and most recently he directed Electra at Barnard College. 

Peiyi Wong, Costume & Set Designer

Scenographer and interdisciplinary artist based in Brooklyn, NY.  She designs sets, installations, and costumes for live performance and film.  Recent credits include scenic + costume design for the Drama League Award-winning TiQ projects: The Seventh Voyage (Sinking Ship) and All the Different Ways Commodore Matthew Perry Could Have Died But Didn’t (New Georges), The Trial of the Catonsville Nine (Transport Group/Abrons Arts), Kafka’s A Hunger Artist (Sinking Ship/The Tank), MukhAgni (Under the Radar); scenic/installation design for You Are Under Our Space Control (Object Collection/LaMama), Memoirs of a…Unicorn (NY Live Arts/Collapsable Hole, 2018 Bessie Outstanding Design), Charleses (The Tank, Hewes Award nomination), Now is the Time (Little Lord/Abrons); costumes for some higher glimmer (Buran Theater), Broadbend AK (Transport Group/The Public), Namour (ARRAY feature film, on Netflix).  Faculty at Playwrights Horizons Theater School, NYU Tisch.  MFA, CalArts.

Chloe Morrell, Production manager

Chloe Morrell is an NYC based stage manager and production manager. Her past theatre credits include The Carmen Variations (InTandem Lab), Make Believe (Second Stage) Dark Play or Stories for Boys (Edinburgh Fringe 2019), Prelude to the Apocalypse (La MaMa), and Solarplexus (Edinburgh Fringe 2018). Along with theatre and live events, Chloe has production experience in TV and film productions, including Broadway World exclusive, Rachel Unraveled. Chloe is currently the production manager for InTandem Lab, where she coordinates productions, workshops, readings and more. In addition to InTandem Lab, Chloe does administrative and production work for The Laurie Berkner Band.

Gisela Cardenas, Director

Gisela Cardenas has worked in the UK, Peru, Brazil, Romania, The Netherlands, Norway, and the USA. Awards: Princess Grace Theater Fellowship (2007) Special Project Award (2012), & Work in Progress Residency  (2019), 2008 Phil Killian Directing Fellow (Oregon Shakespeare Festival), 2008 Women's Project Director's Lab, recipient of the TCG/ NEA 2009 Career Development Program for Directors, member of the SDC Foundation and HERE Artist Resident.

Credits as Director and Writer: "Agamemnon" (Drama Desk Nomination), Watanabe's "Antigone" ("Sibiu International Theater Festival—Romania); Part 1 of "An Oresteia" (Classic Stage Company), Maria Irene Fornes' Tango Palace & Dr, Kheal (New York Fornes Festival), Euripides' Medea (Perú), Brecht's In The Jungle of The Cities (The Netherlands-Peru), Richard III (Norway), Wesker's The Kitchen, Asmussen's "Nobody Meets Anyone" (Brazil), Instructions to Decode A(n In)human Transformation (Writer), Blanco's Thebes Land and Herstory (2020)Upcoming: The Carmen Variations (Director ) Canis Familiaris (Playwright) and HERSTORY for the stage Ice Factory 2021 - The New Ohio Theatre.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Help us spread the word!! Tell your friends!!  look out for tickets and join us in the theater!! Isn't it great to be back?

And of course, come visit and follow us in social media: 

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/InTandemLab/

IG: @intandemlab

Link to our webpage: https://intandemlab.org/her-story/

Any kind of support, financial, non financial, virtual or not virtual, is very very appreciated. So thanks a lot!

With love,

Gisela Cardenas.

Now, Herstory is opening as a live theater piece this upcoming August. Reworking the online version to become a fully staged play, In Tandem Lab continues with its mission of generating new theatrical experiences inspired by a classic material. This time, Shakespeare's Tempest's female characters have been the source of inspiration as we asked: why are the women in that play mostly silent or absent?
We would love you to get involved and support our return to the stages for our official premier.
WHAT'S HERSTORY ABOUT?
A woman leaves an inheritance. Two younger women who have apparently no relationship with each other are receiving it if they create something together. Excavating the drawings and short stories of an artist, these two women will stop living arrested by their unknown past and come out of isolation by giving life to a woman's story. How can we start telling the stories written in our genes and passed from one generation to another? Inspired but the female characters of Shakespeare's Tempest, Herstory attempts to write an intimate take on revenge, isolation, and the personal prisons we all must overcome.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET
This campaign is designed to help us raise funds to cover half of HERSTORY's production expenses to be part of the Ice Factory Festival at The New Ohio Theatre in NYC. With your generous support, we will be able to fully recognize and honor the great work of the artists making HERSTORY possible. Paying our collaborators has always been a principle of our company. Still, after these past months where theater has been hit so hard by the pandemic, it has become more than ever an essential aspect of In Tandem Lab's values. We are requesting US$4,000 to cover the following elements:

Artists fees
Costume & Set Designer
Videographer fees
Light operator fees.
Essays expenses
Travel cost for one of the artists

We have selected some exciting rewards for you, such as entrance tickets to the play,  INTANDEM LAB's tote bag, postcards, and an online meeting with the creators!

THE IMPACT
Silence and entrapment are part of women's histories beyond time and space. At In Tandem Lab, we consider it essential to explore new dramatic territories by creating, commissioning, or reinterpreting classic themes. Herstory excavates women's pasts from the 17th century up to the digital age in the quest for understanding the long history of entrapment and silence that has shaped some of us today. This project is vital to start the conversation and offer alternative narratives to our past inspiring stories from alternative perspectives. 
At the same time, and after almost 17 months of isolation, we are happy to go back into the theater and reconnect with live audiences. As theater makers, we trade in change. This has been evident during the pandemic where so many artists have produced shows using any medium available. Now the possibility of sharing the work with a live audience becomes the central impulse to be together in a room dreaming again.
THE COLLABORATORS

Laura Butler-Levitt, co creator & performer
International actress, director, and choreographer currently living in Vietnam.  She has performed, offered theater workshops, and taught in Turkey, Berlin, Japan, Lithuania, Romania, Italy, US, Australia, Colombia, Vietnam & Puerto Rico. She is a member of Caborca, and a a co-founder of One-Eighth Theater. 
NYC productions: Octopus’s Garden (Caborca); Numbness: chapter 2 (One-Eighth Theater, an Archive Residency production with New Ohio Theater and IRT Theatre); Salomé (M-34); and Distant Star (Caborca); She holds an MFA in Acting from Columbia University, and a BA in Drama from the University of Puerto Rico.

Heather Hollingsworth, co creator & performer
Heather Hollingsworth , a New Orleans native, is an actress, producer, and member of the New Orleans Funk and R&B review Royal American Social Aid and Pleasure Club. She has performed in various plays, workshops and readings with Classic Stage Company, Cherry Lane, MabouMines, The Ohio, LAByrinth, The Women's Project, and The Public. She co-wrote and performed Ask Dr. Mueller, a stage adaptation of the memoirs of writer-outlaw-actress Cookie Mueller; co-wrote, produced, and starred in the short film US. A Family Album, which premiered at the San Francisco International Film Festival and can be seen on the Shorts HD network. She recently appeared in Natalia Iyudin’s THE GARDEN with Sophia Lillis, Ross Kauffman’s Boy Boy Girl Girl with Katie Holmes and SCION for TWO MINUTE HORROR STORIES on the WB. For more, visit her at HeatherHollingsworth.com

Javier Antonio González, writer
Playwright, director, and filmmaker who has served as the artistic director of Caborca since its founding. Some of his authorial work with the company includes: Lying Lydia; Distant Star (adapted from Roberto Bolaño's novel); Zoetrope; Open up, Hadrian; Barceloneta, de noche; FLORIDITA, my Love; and his first feature film, The Entitlement (2018). In 2016, he directed his original translation of A Midsummer Night's Dream in San Juan, Puerto Rico for Teatro en el Parque. His work has been published in the anthologies, Plays and Playwrights 2011 (New York Theatre Experience), Encuentro: Latinx Performance for the New American Theater (Northwestern University Press) and in The Puerto Rico Review. Javier holds a BA from the University of Puerto Rico and an MFA from Columbia University School of the Arts. He was a Van Lier Directing Fellow, a member of the Public Theater’s Emerging Writers Group and a recipient of the Global Connections–In the Lab grant from Theatre Communications Group. He has taught at DreamYard Prep, LaGuardia Community College, and most recently he directed Electra at Barnard College. 

Peiyi Wong, Costume & Set Designer
Scenographer and interdisciplinary artist based in Brooklyn, NY.  She designs sets, installations, and costumes for live performance and film.  Recent credits include scenic + costume design for the Drama League Award-winning TiQ projects: The Seventh Voyage (Sinking Ship) and All the Different Ways Commodore Matthew Perry Could Have Died But Didn’t (New Georges), The Trial of the Catonsville Nine (Transport Group/Abrons Arts), Kafka’s A Hunger Artist (Sinking Ship/The Tank), MukhAgni (Under the Radar); scenic/installation design for You Are Under Our Space Control (Object Collection/LaMama), Memoirs of a…Unicorn (NY Live Arts/Collapsable Hole, 2018 Bessie Outstanding Design), Charleses (The Tank, Hewes Award nomination), Now is the Time (Little Lord/Abrons); costumes for some higher glimmer (Buran Theater), Broadbend AK (Transport Group/The Public), Namour (ARRAY feature film, on Netflix).  Faculty at Playwrights Horizons Theater School, NYU Tisch.  MFA, CalArts.

Chloe Morrell, Production manager
Chloe Morrell is an NYC based stage manager and production manager. Her past theatre credits include The Carmen Variations (InTandem Lab), Make Believe (Second Stage) Dark Play or Stories for Boys (Edinburgh Fringe 2019), Prelude to the Apocalypse (La MaMa), and Solarplexus (Edinburgh Fringe 2018). Along with theatre and live events, Chloe has production experience in TV and film productions, including Broadway World exclusive, Rachel Unraveled. Chloe is currently the production manager for InTandem Lab, where she coordinates productions, workshops, readings and more. In addition to InTandem Lab, Chloe does administrative and production work for The Laurie Berkner Band.


Gisela Cardenas, Director
Gisela Cardenas has worked in the UK, Peru, Brazil, Romania, The Netherlands, Norway, and the USA. Awards: Princess Grace Theater Fellowship (2007) Special Project Award (2012), & Work in Progress Residency  (2019), 2008 Phil Killian Directing Fellow (Oregon Shakespeare Festival), 2008 Women's Project Director's Lab, recipient of the TCG/ NEA 2009 Career Development Program for Directors, member of the SDC Foundation and HERE Artist Resident.
Credits as Director and Writer: "Agamemnon" (Drama Desk Nomination), Watanabe's "Antigone" ("Sibiu International Theater Festival—Romania); Part 1 of "An Oresteia" (Classic Stage Company), Maria Irene Fornes' Tango Palace & Dr, Kheal (New York Fornes Festival), Euripides' Medea (Perú), Brecht's In The Jungle of The Cities (The Netherlands-Peru), Richard III (Norway), Wesker's The Kitchen, Asmussen's "Nobody Meets Anyone" (Brazil), Instructions to Decode A(n In)human Transformation (Writer), Blanco's Thebes Land and Herstory (2020)Upcoming: The Carmen Variations (Director ) Canis Familiaris (Playwright) and HERSTORY for the stage Ice Factory 2021 - The New Ohio Theatre.
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Help us spread the word!! Tell your friends!!  look out for tickets and join us in the theater!! Isn't it great to be back?
And of course, come visit and follow us in social media: 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/InTandemLab/
IG: @intandemlab
Link to our webpage: https://intandemlab.org/her-story/
Any kind of support, financial, non financial, virtual or not virtual, is very very appreciated. So thanks a lot!
With love,
Gisela Cardenas.

story:
Farmgate Theatre

Outdoor theatre that connects: Farm made, farm played

 

Have you ever bought produce from the end of a farm laneway, at one of those colourful little stands full of fresh homegrown goodies? These are called Farmgate sales, because you buy directly from the farm. Farmgate Theatre is a new theatre company on Prince Edward Island that approaches our theatre in much the same way: we make it on the farm and you come here to get it.

We, being Cameron MacDuffee and Karen Graves, are two professional performers, with over 50 years experience between us, that recently moved to PEI and bought a 100 hundred acre farm. One of our dreams has been to have a farm theatre and this year we are making it come true. We are launching our company by presenting a brand new, original piece of outdoor theatre entitled The Road to Belong.

The show

This is a passion project that is being created collectively by sixteen island-based artists from a variety of disciplines. It gives all of us a chance to create, perform and earn some income after a year of having very little opportunity to do so in the performing arts, and we are working hard to raise the funds to make it happen.

The Road to Belong is an exploration into the experience of belonging: with self, with others and with nature. In a time fraught with divisive politics and the added stress of pandemic isolation, we are pouring our creative energy into developing a deeper understanding of what it means to belong, and look forward to sharing our discoveries. The artists in the show have been commissioned to create individual pieces on the theme that will be woven together through a collaborative process led by our director and dramaturg Charlotte Gowdy. The show itself will have the audience travel about the farm encountering different scenes and scenarios, literally and figuratively walking The Road to Belong with us. 

The artists

One of the great strengths of our project is the diversity of our collective members. Our company includes published, award-winning writers like David Weale, young up and coming artists Reequal Smith and Kendi Tarichia, visually impaired performer/creator Bruce Horak, nationally recognized actors Julain Molnar, Greg Gale, Alicia Toner and Jan Rudd, seasoned classical musicians Jeffrey Bazett-Jones and Adam Hill, and the Mi'kmaq Poet Laureate of PEI Julie Pellissier-Lush. We all bring to this project both a wealth of professional experience and varied cultural perspectives. In addition we have the remarkable award-winning talent of Charlotte Gowdy to help us realize our work. Charlotte has directed at the Stratford Festival, studied clown in Paris, performed as an actor across Canada, been an associate artistic director, and worked extensively in devised creation as well traditional dramaturgy. 

The plan

We have already begun the creation of The Road to Belong, and have a very clear path laid out to get us from here to our first show on September 10th, 2021.

Group meetings began in January 2021 and we have continued to meet once a month over Zoom, where we share material, discuss ideas and take suggestions from our director. Additionally, each artist meets with our dramaturg once a month to help develop their individual pieces.

May 23rd and 24th we are having a content development workshop on the farm. This is our first chance to gather in person as an ensemble, and will be an invaluable opportunity to see how the work will come to life on the land. We will get to work on our individual pieces, on group numbers, and begin figuring out how all the parts will fit together to create the larger story.

Throughout the summer we will continue content development work, both on Zoom and with in person ensemble meetings, and work on set, prop and costume designs.

September 1-9 we will be rehearsing the show at the farm. This is when we bring all the pieces together leading up to our performance days September 10, 11, 12.

______________________________________

The total production budget for The Road to Belong is just over $50,000.00. We are realizing this through a combination of:

Our Indiegogo campaign is for the amount of $8200. This money will go toward paying artist's fees for the project. These fees include:

  • commission fees for each artist creating original work
  • dramaturg fee 
  • workshop fees for creators, performers, director/dramaturg and stage manager
  • rehearsal fees for creators, performers, director/dramaturg and stage manager
  • performance fees for performers and stage manager
 

In supporting Farmgate Theatre you can help us to:

  • create meaningful and fulfilling work for ourselves in our field (pun intended)
  • secure funds to collaborate with extraordinary artists and ensure everyone is paid fairly
  • come out of the gate in our first season with an ambitious show and a stellar cast
  • bring an engaging, innovative theatre experience to our community
  • lay the groundwork that will lead to future shows, concerts and community events on the farm

 

Roadblocks

We have all been through an incredibly challenging year as a result of the pandemic. The performing arts have been hit hard, with many of us finding our careers have come to a full stop until further notice. On PEI, we are currently permitted to gather in sufficient numbers to put on an event for a small audience, and for that we are very appreciative. However, as we all know, the situation is very unpredictable. It is an ongoing challenge to plan for the best and prepare for anything, and we have several scenarios of how we will carry on our work if health guidelines change for the worse.

Current back-up plans in the event of a COVID 19 lockdown include:

  • Completing our creative work on group sessions on Zoom
  • Postponing shows to a date when restrictions are lifted
  • Perform the show for video camera (if we can gather the cast within regulations) and release tickets to an online screening of the show

 

Where you fit in, or ... What's a perk, anyway?

On this campaign page is a list of donation levels, and each one has a perk associated with it. You might wonder what the perks are all about. Do you remember when cereal boxes had toys in them? That's basically what perks are. They are for the kid in you, the one who wants to find a prize at the bottom of the box. They are rewards for your good deed, a thanks from us to you. We hope you find just the right one!

Maybe you want to help but are looking for a different way to lend a hand, an alternate to donating money ? Here are a few ideas.

You can:

  • email this campaign page to people you think would be interested.
  • share or post about us on Facebook, Instagram or Twitter, to help us spread the word about our plans.
  • plan to attend a show in September, to find out for yourself what it's all about.

 

Whether or not you are able to contribute to Farmgate Theatre, we thank you so much for taking an interest!

Sincerely,

Cam and Karen

story:
The Squid Shift Solution

Circus Convergence III  brings together three world famous sideshow troupes; The Squidling Bros. (Philadelphia),


 Swing Shift Sideshow (Las Vegas)

 Pain Solution (Oslo, Norway)


The Squid Shift Solution will tour throughout the eastern half of The United States.  Closing out at the SKIN NYC, 2015 Body Suspension Symposium.


In 2013 The Squidling Bros. and Pain Solution joined forces touring throughout the U.S. on their way to the Dallas Body Suspension Convention, involving local talent in different cities along the way.  The concept was to stimulate up and coming talent by sharing the stage with seasoned professionals and to inspire each other rather than compete.   Last year Swing Shift Sideshow joined in to strengthen this idea.  To create a show like no one has seen before inspiring the next generation and keeping sideshow and circus arts evolving. 

This Year Circus Convergence adds World Record Holding Strong Man Titano Oddfellow.  

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to Gorilla Glass and Body Art Forms sponsoring the tour with generous contributions we have a bit of head start but we still have a lot more expenses to cover in order to bring this show to the masses!

Round Trip Flights: Pain Solution and Swing Shift Sideshow to Philadelphia from Norway and Las Vegas

Vehicle and Driver Costs 

Gas and Tolls for 2 vehicles

Advertising: Shipping and printing of Posters/hand bills.  Ads in papers, graphic design

Total $5,000

In return for your generous contributions, we have some cool perks to offer. 

If we unfortunately fall short of our goal, we will cover costs in this order:

-Flights, Fuel and tolls, Advertising.

If we surpass our goal we can cover these additional costs:

Food (sustaining a healthy lifestyle on the road is expensive!) 

Hotels

The Impact

Circus Sideshow is not a thing of the past, it is very much alive!  Every night the performers in this show risk their lives for your entertainment.  Your contributions ensure that the performers in the show will earn a decent living and not have to worry about the expenses of being out on the road.


 The fact that there are three shows in one increases the expenses, but not the income earned through these performances.  This tour is designed to fortify sideshow as a genre and inspire the community at large. And this is why we need your help to make our collaboration a continuing and growing success.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute please:

Come to the show and tell all your friends about it!

Get the word out about the campaign and tell people who you think can contribute!

Use the indiegogo share tools and spread the word on facebook!

Thank you, thank you, thank you.

Wed. 1 The Smiling Moose (steel city kitty presents) Pittsburgh PA 
Fri. 3 Smith’s South Bend IN 
Sat. 4 Bada Brew Joliet IL
Sun. 5 Uptown Underground Chicago IL

Wed. 8 VENUE TBA Indianapolis IN
Thurs. 9 Ottawa Tavern Toledo OH 
Fri. 10 Tangent Gallery Detroit MI
Sat. 11 Cross Roads Bar and Grille Ypsilanti MI

Mon. 13 Cosmic Charlie’s with The Kentucky Burlesque Society Lexington KY

Wed. 15 Flying Monkey Arts Huntsville AL

Fri. 17 The Odditorium Asheville NC 

Tues. 21 Connie’s Ric Rac Room Philadelphia PA 
Fri. 24 The Living Room Brooklyn NY (SKIN NYC after party)
more shows TBA soon!!!

story:
Awkward Conversations with Animals I've F*cked by Rob Hayes is the 2nd full scale production by Vancouver's Stages Theatre Co. Last year, they presented a successful run of Seminar by Theresa Rebeck, starring Andrew Wheeler. In the past few years, they have also developed Naked Love  for the Vancouver Fringe Festival and BALLS!  for the rEvolver Festival. 

Stages Theatre Co. is committed to creating rare opportunities for artists with passion and integrity, working towards establishment in the theatre community. The company does so by presenting thought-provoking, ballsy, and often humorous works that we consider to be relevant, engaging, and, quite simply, a good f***ing time.

We are very excited to bring more theatre to Vancouver, especially with a script like this. Rob Hayes' play is a dark and funny play about a man who simply wants to love and feel loved. 

One-night stands are awkward. One-night stands with animals are more awkward. And when you're as desperate to please as Bobby, things get awkward as f*ck. He's just a guy with too much love to give, and a burning desire to give it to consensual adult mammals. 

"Hayes’ darkly funny script masks a disturbing psychological examination of mental illness and loneliness…this play is much more subtle and interesting than the brashness of its title." -The Stage

- I hope that you will want to support this project, as it will be one of my last in Vancouver for a little while. I will be pursuing my MFA in the fall and will be leaving this wonderful city, full of hard working artists and sincere patrons. I hope to be back but in the mean time, I cherish the fact that I have worked with some great people, on great projects, this one being one of them, I am sure. -Cory Haas

THE SHOW WILL TAKE PLACE MAY 2016. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for help of all kinds, monetary and otherwise. If you would like to volunteer to work as an usher, box office attendant, or just to help us get the word out, please email: stagestheatreco@gmail.com

• Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. All of your help can and will make a HUGE difference for us!

• Please share this page with your friends and family. (Use the social media share tools to do so!)


And that's all there is to it.

He's just a guy with too much love to give, and a burning desire to give it to consensual adult mammals. "Hayes’ darkly funny script masks a disturbing psychological examination of mental illness and loneliness…this play is much more subtle and interesting than the brashness of its title." -The Stage- I hope that you will want to support this project, as it will be one of my last in Vancouver for a little while. I will be pursuing my MFA in the fall and will be leaving this wonderful city, full of hard working artists and sincere patrons. I hope to be back but in the mean time, I cherish the fact that I have worked with some great people, on great projects, this one being one of them, I am sure. -Cory HaasTHE SHOW WILL TAKE PLACE MAY 2016. Other Ways You Can HelpWe are always looking for help of all kinds, monetary and otherwise. If you would like to volunteer to work as an usher, box office attendant, or just to help us get the word out, please email: stagestheatreco@gmail.com• Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. All of your help can and will make a HUGE difference for us!• Please share this page with your friends and family. (Use the social media share tools to do so!)


And that's all there is to it.

story:
A groundbreaking exploration of extremism, cult mentality, aggressive heteronormative pop culture and homophobic stereotypes.

Dear friends, lovers and supporters of the arts,

We're Anthony & Nathan, aka AnimalParts, a genre-destroying NYC-based performance company dedicated to creating unique and vibrant new works rooted in humor, heart and innovation.

We are thrilled to be partnering with NYC's Dixon Place this April to present a month-long run of our gay rap horror show and exploration of grief: Revenge of the Popinjay.

This marks our first opportunity to present work in NYC over a broader timeline--making us eligible to be seen and reviewed by major publications (like the NYTimes, New Yorker, Village Voice) and give a broader audience the ability to see our work.

This is our chance to take our vision and our art to the next level.

What is Revenge of the Popinjay?

Born from Anthony's real-life experiences with loss and mourning in the wake of his sister's death in 2010, Revenge of the Popinjay is a follow-up to our critically acclaimed investigation of "the powers of positive thinking", Tenderpits (FOUR STARS, The Times of London) and the second installment in our experimental Tenderpits Trilogy. In Popinjay, Anthony struggles to cope with his grief while uncovering a frightening link between himself, his lover, and an elusive gay rap star/serial killer targeting heterosexuals.

We use the ultra-violent and overtly sexual shock rapper, The Popinjay, to explore anger and pain while also examining the appeal of extremism, cult mentality, our complicity in the consumption of aggressive heteronormative pop culture, and homophobic stereotypes. By creating the first ever "heterophobic" rapper, and a New York City in which heterosexuals are the targets of violence and hate, we are able to grapple with these issues in an altogether groundbreaking way.

Revenge of the Popinjay combines storytelling, stand-up, physical theatre, performance art and original live rap music, to create a one-of-a-kind live performance event that satirizes the clichés of homophobic culture and questions the capacity for evil in all of us. 

Why We Need Funds

In order to make this presentation of Revenge of the Popinjay everything it can be, we need your help. Your contributions will go to-

rehearsal space, props, and costumes

sound and technical rentals

an awesome Stage Manager

a brilliant Lighting Designer

an amazing Publicist and Photographer

printing postcards and posters

development, workshops


Thank You

We believe in this show with all of our hearts and know that it has a real future. Please consider joining us in this exciting project, or help by spreading the word about our work and this campaign. 

with love and gratitude always,

Anthony & Nathan xo

  

(Nathan and Anthony in the recording studio. Anthony with Edward Albee at the first workshop of Revenge of the Popinjay, Dixon Place, 2012)

story:
Hello! My name is Anastasia Engasheva. I am in my graduation year at the Bolshoi Ballet Academy. My first meeting with ballet was when I was 5 years old and appeared on stage as a Little Red Riding Hood. 


 Since then ballet has been an essential part of my live. I have always wanted to express my emotions and feelings, thoughts and experiences - through dance. I created my first dance when I was 9 years old. The school’s headmistress was so impressed that she included it in the school’s New Year performance.

I grew up, my dances became more serious and deeper, and my choreography, more relevant and complicated. 

Not only do I now express myself in dance, but I also aim to conduct a dialogue with the audience: I tell a story, ask philosophical questions and give the viewer an opportunity both to see a good show and to reflect on its meanings. 

My ballet is called “The System.” It is a lyrical dystopia that tells the story of love between two people who live in a state where citizens are forced by a totalitarian leader to forget their emotions and feelings.


The main characters, risking everything to be together, decide to fight against "the system”. For the lovers this struggle is tragic, but the ballet’s finale highlights the triumph of humanism.  

For me, one of the most complicated tasks when creating a dance is to find the right music. My favourite band is MUSE. I am fascinated by the band’s songs: their hard guitar riffs combined with a symphonic orchestra, their lyrical piano ballads and emotional anguish. If this music collects stadiums, why can’t it collect theatres, I asked myself. But then, why would MUSE allow me to use their music in my ballet?    


I have chosen 11 songs by MUSE. To create the ballet, I looked for inspiration not only in the music itself but also in the lyrics of the songs and in the books that had inspired Bellamy to write them.  

I sent the description of the project and the libretto to MUSE. The result was incredible!  They allowed me to use the music!

 More than 30 people take part in this ballet as volunteers:

As well as:

Bolshoi Ballet Academy students


The implementation of my idea requires quite a lot of funds, for the project is not commercial (we will not charge for the tickets). Without your help, it might be impossible to stage the ballet. 

   Rent a video screen that will be as the set design

 Rent the stage

Create costumes

Print posters and programs

The premiere of “The System”, the first ballet in the world staged to the music of MUSE, will take place in Moscow in June 2015. We, the participants of the project, ask you to support us, and look forward to seeing you at the premiere!

story:
Projekt:Opera has been an idea for several years of sisters Ji-Eun Lee (pianist) and Kyeong-Eun (Lee) Zwick (opera singer), but last year when Ji-Eun met Conductor Hidetaka Niiyama (Conductor) the idea took root.  Today, nearly a year later, Projekt:Opera is a reality!  The concept of Projekt:Opera is to be a mostly professional, high-quality community opera production organization that will produce classical to modern operas in a minimalist fashion using creative costuming and minimalist set designs that integrate technology (video, lighting, etc.) to help control costs.  It is our goal to shift the cost center.  To be blunt:  We want to pay singers and musicians more and costumes/sets less!

Our first production is to produce scenes from Mozart's The Magic Flute, which will be held on Friday, May 29 and Saturday, May 30.  Our version of The Magic Flute will focus on key scenes of The Magic Flute interspersed with professional narration to help reduce the three hour length to less than two hours.  The opera will include sub-titles of the German language, basic costuming, light set design, and heavy use of video and lighting effects.  A cast of 9 professional opera singers and one amateur singer will be accompanied by a professional, but reduced orchestra. withIf this production is well-received we will produce a second opera later this year or early next year (January).

Why We Need Your Help:
Our singers have agreed to perform voluntarily.  Our musicians have agreed to play at a greatly reduced cost.  The venue, Studio 37 inside Ji-Eun Lee Music Academy, has agreed to host all rehearsals and the two performances entirely for free (up front) and has underwritten the entirety of the up front costs (costumes, set design, materials purchases, etc.) with the hope of receiving a share of the ticket sales after everyone, including singers, musicians, and technical crew, have been paid even though all of them have agreed to participate for free or at a reduced cost.  If we were to pay rent for rehearsals and performances, pay fair wages to all cast, musicians, and crew, and cover the basic costumes and set, we estimate the real cost would be around $8000 for the production of The Magic Flute.  We will be able to produce it for $3500.  We are hopeful ticket sales will cover much of this cost, but we are asking for your support to help cover the rest.  100% of remaining funds after the show's run will go toward the production of our second planned opera.  We appreciate your support and interest in helping keep opera alive!

Cast:
Papageno:  Steve Wrighton
Papagena:  Shannon Christie
Tamino:  Dan Ahlgren
Queen of the Night:  Carrie Zwick
Monostatos:  Larry Goens
Pamino:  Mindy Wisely
Second Priest/First Armor
First Lady:  Shannon Cuneo
Second Lady:  Emmi
Third Lady:  Theresa Treep
Narration:  David Pygman

Orchestra:
First Violin:  Maggie Davis
Second Violin:  Makalyn Paul
Viola:  Empty
Cello:  John Matterns
Flute:  Julie Matterns
Bass:  Mark McCullogh
Clarinet:  Kelly Niiyama
Piano/Synths:  Ji-Eun Lee

Technical Crew:
Set Design:  Staging:  Michelle Shea-Russell
Lighting, Video, Audio:  Doug Whisman
Lighting, Video, Audio Engineer:  Alex Ayala
Costuming:  Chris Russell

Tickets:  http://www.FishersMusic.com/tickets

story:
This summer, Carl Wickman's short play Candy Says has been chosen to be produced at the annual Fringe Festival in St. Louis, Missouri! 

In the near future, you can buy any sort of love you want at an hourly rate. Robotic prostitution is booming business. Candy Says is the delightful and bittersweet story of Candy, who struggles with her destiny, and her nervous customer of the night.

All proceeds will go towards set, production, lighting, merchandise, costumes, props, and cast/crew pay. 

-

For more information on the Fringe Festival, visit this website.

story:
This year, marking the 100th anniversary of its publication, Shedload Theatre is taking a new stage adaptation of Jack London's 'The Star Rover' to the Edinburgh Fringe. This is a first ever stage production of the story, which takes its audience into the fantastical world of a death-row convict who escapes the brutality of his everyday life through wild and vivid dreams of past lives. First conceived as a dissertation project for the MA theatre directing programme at University of East Anglia, the play pays tribute to the extraordinary legacy of writer Jack London, whose books 'Call of the Wild' and 'White Fang' have been a staple diet for young readers around the world. 

Now we need your help funding the final portion of the Edinburgh Fringe costs! Our fundraising target of £2500 will go towards the final part of the venue payment, as well as covering the cost of our set - (an enormous steel cage!), costume, and marketing. In exchange for your help you will receive CARDS, HANDMADE POLYMER CLAY MODELS, and maybe even free tickets. And naturally a lot of love and gratitude.

We are soon to start rehearsing, reworking, building, and creating a show that we hope will blow your minds. Now blow our minds by helping to fund us blow yours!
