story:
Imagine a world where you are unable to bring your child to the theater. It is difficult for them to sit still for two hours, silently, in the dark, and they are labeled a disturbance and/or asked to leave if they cannot comply. These traditional rules weren't designed with your family in mind. Bluelaces provides theatrical productions to a population that is typically denied the opportunity to experience live theater. We provide customized programming for our audience members, while allowing accompanying parents and caregivers to share an unforgettable experience together with their loved one. Our shows welcome every child and caregiver to participate in a flexible environment that suits their unique needs— running around the theater, touching and playing with props, sets, or ensemble members, or calming down in our quiet, interactive lobby. Each child in the audience is paired with his/her own dedicated “Adventure Guide,” an ensemble member who is familiar with the child’s triggers, sensitivities and special interests, and accompanies them through the performance to ensure the best possible experience.

Other companies modify pre-existing productions to make them “Autism friendly”; these adaptations are not originally intended for audiences with developmental disabilities. In contrast, Bluelaces celebrates and encourages each child in the audience to enjoy their own personalized experience without expecting them to adjust to a traditional theatrical model.

About 1 in 68 children has been identified with having Autism Spectrum Disorder, while 1 in 6 children has a developmental disability, ranging in severity.  Seeing this as one of our generation’s most pressing challenges, Bluelaces seeks to provide an experience for this underserved population that is unlike any other. Our productions are designed specifically for people of all ages with autism and other developmental disabilities, including but not limited to Down Syndrome, Cerebral Palsy, Intellectual Disabilities, Learning Disabilities, ADD/ADHD, genetic disabilities, and hearing and visual impairments.

In our past 2 years of productions, we’ve been fortunate to witness monumental milestones in the lives of our young audience members and their families. A child overcame his fear of water, interacting with it seamlessly in our theater for the first time ever. A father and child shared a tender moment hugging on the floor, an unlikely scenario on any other day. Bluelaces exists simply because everyone deserves to see theater. 

 

If you're wondering why engaging with a theatrical experience is impactful to someone with a developmental disability, lean into these quotes from our past audience members from our productions of Out There! in 2016 and 2017 and All Aboard! in 2017.

"Bluelaces is amazing! This has changed the way my son responds to theater, and changed the way I respond to him. I always tear up because I love to see the way he is drawn out of his own world, and he eagerly responds and participates in a way that we don't see at home very often. Also, frankly, its an hour for me to sit and relax. I dont have to worry about his safety or correcting his behaviors, because I know he is safe and respected while in that space."- Parent, All Aboard! ​2017

"It is an incredible gift to watch our children experience the magic of theater and story using the very things that trigger their experiences in the world- to see my son in an environment that isn't asking him to adapt, but instead says, 'We get you, come along and have some fun today!'" - Parent, Out There!  2016

"What [Bluelaces is] doing is so beautiful and important, the emotions thinking about this during the show was overwhelming, hard to hold back the tears. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"- Parent, All Aboard! 2017

"She has been talking about Out There! regularly in the 2.5 weeks since we attended and she thoroughly enjoyed the experience in a way I am not sure she has ever enjoyed anything else." - Parent, Out There! 2017

"The Adventure Guides worked 1-on-1 with each child, so everyone's unique, individual needs were met... I had tears in my eyes as my 8 y.o. said I wish we could do stuff like this!" - Parent, Out There! 2016

"This production is nothing like any entertainment production we've been to before. This show offers the opportunity for my sister to engage, or even not engage if she wants and makes her feel safe and also just like a superstar. I wish there were more shows like this for her!"- All Aboard! 2017

"Everything about this experience was great, from the social story that helped prepare our son, to the kindness and patience of the performers, to the staging itself. He had a blast, and so did we." Parent, Out There! 2017

"[My son] enjoyed the ability to be up and involved in the action.  Often if we go to shows he is required to sit and observe, not actually participate... Shows not designed for this population often have bright lights, loud music and required him to sit still which is not natural for [my son].  He likes to move around, touch things and ask A LOT of questions.  [Bluelaces] was encouraging and interactive with all of the kids.  It was fun and we absolutely will return.  Thank you!"- All Aboard! 2017

"My son got a chance to be himself with no judgments... I got a chance to relax and really enjoy a show with him. We didn't feel like outsiders. We were the normal ones that Saturday!" - Parent, Out There! 2016

"Bluelaces [believes] that all individuals, with or without a developmental disability, should have the opportunity to experience the magic of theater in a lively and welcoming environment." - BroadwayWorld.com, 2017

 

Bluelaces fulfills a distinctive niche in the New York City community, creating theater specifically and primarily for an audience of individuals with developmental disabilities. You will be joining us at the forefront of this emerging and essential field. You will also be supporting our unique business plan: we are determined to make our programming as accessible economically as it is artistically. We offer a sliding scale ticketing system to our audiences, since the cost of care for those living with autism and other developmental disabilities in the US is significantly higher than the cost of care for neuro-typical children.

With your support we've been able to produce three highly successful productions and a brand new summer camp! We have a brand new show on the way, and we can't wait to share it with you.

In SUDS, soap bubbles aren’t confined to the washing machine, and we make a mess of getting clean! Revel in the smell of clean laundry, rock out with our washboard jam band, and relax in piles of warm clothes fresh out of the dryer. SUDS gives us a chance to appreciate the sensory marvels of getting clean. You may never think of Laundry Day as a chore again!

February 10, 11, 17, and 18

The Actor's Fund Arts Center

160 Schermerhorn St

Brooklyn, NY 11201

Email ticketing@bluelacestc.com for more information!

Once a pipe dream of five undergraduate theater and pyschology majors at Northwestern University, Bluelaces began as Theatre Stands with Autism (TSWA). With the support of student group Purple Crayon Players, Bluelaces founders produced, directed, and performed in TSWA's first two, fully-mounted productions for children with autism: Diving In! (Spring 2013) and Strung Along (Spring 2014). In tandem with these two productions, they developed a series of creative drama workshops for their audiences, related to each show’s theme. These first two productions and corresponding workshops reached nearly 100 audience members and received universally positive feedback about the experiences from parents and educators.

Bluelaces was formed in New York City in June 2014 by original TSWA founders Melanie Gertzman, Alison Mahoney, Lindsay Amer, Anna Marr, and Claire Huntington. In founding Bluelaces, the group revised their mission to incorporate individuals of all ages, rather than just children. Additionally, Bluelaces began to welcome audience members with all types of developmental differences, with autism and sensory sensitivities as touchstones in creating their productions.

At Northwestern, our founding members received training from Chicago Children's Theatre’s Red Kite Project, a company dedicated to producing theater and conducting drama workshops for children with autism. Bluelaces senior staff members have also studied with London-based company Oily Cart, the company that pioneered theater for children with developmental and physical differences. The core founders for both TSWA and Bluelaces drew inspiration from both Red Kite and Oily Cart, with an added eye to one-on-one attention for each audience member, resulting in the development of our unique “adventure guide” model.

TSWA (now called Seesaw Theater Company) still operates independently at Northwestern University.

 

Click the back it button! 

Use the Indiegogo share tools! It's so easy!

Spread the word! Share our mission by making some noise about our campaign to friends, family, your company, or potential audience members.

Feel free to reach out to us with any questions, comments, or ideas on possible donors or organizations with whom we should connect.

Like/follow us on Facebook, Twitter, & Instagram.

 

Thank you for your support! 

www.bluelacestc.com
story_txt:
Imagine a world where you are unable to bring your child to the theater. It is difficult for them to sit still for two hours, silently, in the dark, and they are labeled a disturbance and/or asked to leave if they cannot comply. These traditional rules weren't designed with your family in mind. Bluelaces provides theatrical productions to a population that is typically denied the opportunity to experience live theater. We provide customized programming for our audience members, while allowing accompanying parents and caregivers to share an unforgettable experience together with their loved one. Our shows welcome every child and caregiver to participate in a flexible environment that suits their unique needs— running around the theater, touching and playing with props, sets, or ensemble members, or calming down in our quiet, interactive lobby. Each child in the audience is paired with his/her own dedicated “Adventure Guide,” an ensemble member who is familiar with the child’s triggers, sensitivities and special interests, and accompanies them through the performance to ensure the best possible experience.
Other companies modify pre-existing productions to make them “Autism friendly”; these adaptations are not originally intended for audiences with developmental disabilities. In contrast, Bluelaces celebrates and encourages each child in the audience to enjoy their own personalized experience without expecting them to adjust to a traditional theatrical model.About 1 in 68 children has been identified with having Autism Spectrum Disorder, while 1 in 6 children has a developmental disability, ranging in severity.  Seeing this as one of our generation’s most pressing challenges, Bluelaces seeks to provide an experience for this underserved population that is unlike any other. Our productions are designed specifically for people of all ages with autism and other developmental disabilities, including but not limited to Down Syndrome, Cerebral Palsy, Intellectual Disabilities, Learning Disabilities, ADD/ADHD, genetic disabilities, and hearing and visual impairments.In our past 2 years of productions, we’ve been fortunate to witness monumental milestones in the lives of our young audience members and their families. story:
We are a group of students from Rose Bruford College who started a theatre company in our first year of drama school. Our show 'Knots' went to the Fringe last year and was a success so we have decided to return with our new production 'Pilgrimmage' this year. 

In a world of barbed wire fences and concrete walls, what can one do but dream of world outside the borders? Set in a fictional land, Pilgrimmage follows a group of individuals as they adventure on a perilous journey to explore what's on the outside. Will it be just like the amazing stories? Or will it all be too good to be true?

Putting on a fringe show is never easy, artistically or financially. You need to cover the cost of theatre hire, music rights, set design, costume and props and it all adds up very quickly. As we are still students in full time education and also a newly formed group, finding the funds for all these things can prove difficult. With your help we will be able to access all these things and put on the best show we possibly can. Even the smallest contribution we will be grateful for!

story:
Aloha and mahalo nui loa for your interest in our campaign! Our wahine competition team of Hula Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa consists of 6 spirited, motivated women from various walks of life, brought together by our love for Hawaii, the art of hula, and our determination to perfect our craft in order to preserve a thriving culture. 

What is E Hula Mau® and Why is it Important?

E Hula Mau® is Southern California’s only Hula and Chant competition. It takes place annually over Labor Day weekend (Sept 1, 2, and 3 2017) at the Terrace Theatre at the Long Beach Performing Arts Center. Various hālau will perform in multiple categories including solo and group performances in both the ancient kahiko and modern ʻauana styles of hula. It is important for our wahine to represent Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa this year so that we may honor our esteemed lineage and our fellow Nā Mamo ʻohana while perpetuating and preserving the art of hula.

(pictured above: 2016 competition team - Kahiko)

 

Past Awards and Recognition at E Hula Mau®

E HULA MAU® 2014

Mākuahine Soloist - 1st Place

Mākuahine Group - 1st Place

Maiki Aiu Lake Award - Highest Points, Group Mākuahine ʻAuana

Kāne Kahiko - 2nd Place

Kāne ʻAuana - 2nd Place

E HULA MAU® 2015

ʻOli Soloist - 3rd Place

Mākuahine Group - 2nd Place

E HULA MAU® 2016

Wahine Group ʻAuana - 3rd Place

 

What We Need

 

Based on our calculations, expenses will total $18,000 for us to compete at E Hula Mau® 2017. Through our hard work and multiple fundraising efforts over the last several months, we have managed to raise 10,000, over half of our budget! We are hoping that, with this last-stitch effort, we can raise the remaining $8,000 through your generous donations!

 

What are these funds for?

 

  • Transportation, performance fees, and accommodations for musicians flown in from Hawaiʻi
  • Construction and fabric costs for costumes
  • Fresh flower adornments from Hawaiʻi
  • Lodging and rehearsal space for duration of competition weekend


What you get


As added incentive we hope to provide you with some exciting perks for your donations. Whether at the Liko level or the ʻŌhiʻa Lehua level, all contributions are humbly accepted with the utmost appreciation! Perks may range from facebook shout-outs to tickets to (and other bonuses at) our upcoming Ho’ike, October 7, 2017. This year we have special guests, Nā Hōkū Hanohano award winning hula musicians, Keauhou who will be flying in from Hawaiʻi to perform exclusively with our school. 

 

Meet Our Wahine!

Kehaulani: Kehaulani has been dancing hula since the age of five and has loved every moment of it and considers the hālau a part of her ʻohana. Dancing with this group of amazing women under Kumu Keoki's care and guidance holds a special and sacred place in her heart. Kehau hopes to honor our kupuna, our lineage, and Kumu as we perpetuate the hula at E Hula Mau®. Mahalo to the whole hālau for their support and aloha.  We hope to make you proud!

Kamanuleleokalani: Kamanu first discovered the beauty of hula she had believed it was a gift reserved for the natives of the land. Sadly pushing away any dreams of learning hula, she went on to study jazz, ballet, tap, hip hop, modern dance as well as her native Chilean Cueca dances. It wasnʻt until she settled into an acting career in Los Angeles that she reconnected with an old college friend Kehaulani who was studying to be Alakaʻi at Hula Hālau Nā Mamo O Panaʻewa. It was there she learned that hula was for anyone with a passion to learn it and perpetuate the culture.  After over 20 years of dance and 3 years of papa hula, she finds herself in her second E Hula Mau® competition and just as in love with the art as she was as a child. Mahalo nui to Kumu, Kehau, her husband and ʻohana for this great gift.

Keanunani: Keanu came to the hālau with 26+ years dance experience and directly off of a 5 year run as lead choreographer for an LA-based dance company, before discovering hula. Despite her vast experiences in the larger dance world, Keanu proudly boasts “this is the most supportive, most dedicated group of women I’ve ever worked with!" Competing for her second time, Keanu is once again honored and excited to represent such an elite group and to contribute in the preservation of such a beautiful tradition and culture. "I hope I make you wahine, our Kumu, and the entire hālau proud!” #panaewastrong

Leiʻohu: Since the age of 12, dancing has been a important part of Lei'ohu's life. She watched her family immerse into hula, igniting her journey and passion with hawaiian culture. Dancing with Hālau Nā Mamo O Panaʻewa has been an amazing experience! This is her first competition and she is ready to dance her heart out with the support of Kumu Keoki and her haumāna. Mahalo Kumu Keoki for the time and dedication you've spent with us, my hula girls, and my family.

Makanalani: Makana has been dancing with Na Mamo for the past 3 years.  She has wanted to be a hula dancer ever since she was a little girl.  Her mom used to watch Elvis Presley movies set in Hawaii, which started her passion. Makana is excited about being part of the competition team because " when you're a part of something bigger than yourself, it makes you better." She honestly has never been this happy until joining the hālau. She loves her hula ʻohana. They are the most kind, loving and supportive group of people she has ever known.  Makana is thrilled for this opportunity to share her aloha with all of you. 

Kaleilokelani: My name is Rosaleena Gullotto and my Hawaiian name is Kaleilokelani which means the garland of roses from heaven. I have been dancing hula for about eight years and have been dancing at Hula Hālau Nā Mamo O Panaʻewa for five years. I am very proud that I found this hālau because of all the haumana but most importantly my kumu. I have recently moved up to Wahine in our hālau because my kumu felt that I was ready to move up from kaikamahine. Throughout my years of hula I have always thought about competing. So when kumu said he was holding a meeting for all people interested in joining the competition team, I knew I wanted to join, but wasn't sure if I was ready. So, I asked kumu if he felt I was ready for competition and he  said yes, but only if I wanted to do it. I knew it would be a challenge for me but I knew I could do it if I worked really hard and had the encouragement of my kumu, my family, and the other competition girls. I am very happy I made the decision of joining this year's competition team and am looking forward to competing at E Hula Mau 2017

About Our Hālau

Located in sunny Southern California (Glendale), and established in 2010, Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa (The Cherished Offspring of Pana’ewa) and Kumu Hula (Teacher of Hula) Keoki Wang continues the traditions and legacies of his award-winning teachers including Kumu Hula Sonny Ching, Kumu Hula Noelani McIntosh and Kumu Hula Kunewa Mook through dance, songs and traditional Hawaiian chants. More information can be found at www.hhnmop.com

 

Risks & Challenges

Although this is not Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa’s first year competing at E Hula Mau®, we are even more ambitious, striving to do our best to represent our lineage. In order to ensure that all 6 women are able to perform, without sacrificing the quality of costumes, adornments, musicians, or other elements, we really do need to meet our projected budget of $18,000. We would like the opportunity to concentrate solely on putting all our aloha into our hula over worrying about expenses, We have a respected lineage and reputation to uphold and we want to make everyone proud!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand times are tough and not everyone is able to contribute financially. We appreciate your interest! Here are some other ways you can help!:

Share our indiegogo page to your various social media sites!

Follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/wahinenamamo and Instagram @wahinenamamo

Use hashtag #wahinenamamo whenever sharing our images, videos, campaign link, etc,

Spread the word any way you can!!!

I have been dancing hula for about eight years and have been dancing at Hula Hālau Nā Mamo O Panaʻewa for five years. I am very proud that I found this hālau because of all the haumana but most importantly my kumu. I have recently moved up to Wahine in our hālau because my kumu felt that I was ready to move up from kaikamahine. Throughout my years of hula I have always thought about competing. So when kumu said he was holding a meeting for all people interested in joining the competition team, I knew I wanted to join, but wasn't sure if I was ready. So, I asked kumu if he felt I was ready for competition and he  said yes, but only if I wanted to do it. I knew it would be a challenge for me but I knew I could do it if I worked really hard and had the encouragement of my kumu, my family, and the other competition girls. I am very happy I made the decision of joining this year's competition team and am looking forward to competing at E Hula Mau 2017About Our HālauLocated in sunny Southern California (Glendale), and established in 2010, Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa (The Cherished Offspring of Pana’ewa) and Kumu Hula (Teacher of Hula) Keoki Wang continues the traditions and legacies of his award-winning teachers including Kumu Hula Sonny Ching, Kumu Hula Noelani McIntosh and Kumu Hula Kunewa Mook through dance, songs and traditional Hawaiian chants. More information can be found at www.hhnmop.com Risks & ChallengesAlthough this is not Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa’s first year competing at E Hula Mau®, we are even more ambitious, striving to do our best to represent our lineage. In order to ensure that all 6 women are able to perform, without sacrificing the quality of costumes, adornments, musicians, or other elements, we really do need to meet our projected budget of $18,000. We would like the opportunity to concentrate solely on putting all our aloha into our hula over worrying about expenses, We have a respected lineage and reputation to uphold and we want to make everyone proud! Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand times are tough and not everyone is able to contribute financially. We appreciate your interest! Here are some other ways you can help!:Share our indiegogo page to your various social media sites!Follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/wahinenamamo and Instagram @wahinenamamoUse hashtag #wahinenamamo whenever sharing our images, videos, campaign link, etc,Spread the word any way you can!!!

story:
Welcome to our ECO fundraising page! 

We are excited to tell you about our new musical. 

About ECO

Eco is the story of a young woman caught in a dystopian world, as humanity faces the ravages of climate change.  The government has tried and failed to combat nature with technology. Some are forced to live in oxygenated facilities, while others suffer from acid rain, and still others have been given mysterious and uncontrollable powers. Amidst the chaos, a lost girl called Eco searches for her parents and ends up discovering her voice. With a contemporary-pop soundtrack, a cast of unique characters, and the style of a YA novel, Eco was created in part to empower young people to join the fight against climate change. This musical deals with deep themes while also serving audiences with an entertaining and imaginative tale of a girl who discovers her power as a leader and change-maker in troubled times. Jenna Mate has been working on the music for over ten years, and was thrilled to meet playwright Bethie Fowler in Graduate School. They have been working as a team for over three years. 

About this Opportunity

Being part of the New York Musical Festival is not only validation of the many years of development of ECO, but it's a vehicle to propel this project to the next level. We'd love to garner the interest of a producer who cares about the project as much as we do, and this festival is an important  launching pad toward that goal.

Get to Know Jenna and Bethie 

We are artists who care about making theater with a message. Both of us have worked extensively with young people, and also have produced work on a professional level. We each hold Masters Degrees in our chosen fields, and will give this project everything we've got! 

As female artists, this story is important to us, because the story is about a young woman who discovers her voice in a chaotic world. As inhabitants of planet Earth, we feel that this musical could be a wake up call for people to get empowered in caring for our environment. 

Our Goal is to Raise $10,000

This will go toward:

  • Hiring a Musical Director 
  • Hiring a Music Copiest to create the sheet music
  • Hiring a Director to shape the readings 
  • Compensating Actors for their talents and time
  • Hiring a General Manager to oversee the readings in the festival 
  • Marketing Materials
  • Printing Programs
  • Paying Musicians for their time
  • Site fees for the Festival 
  • Rehearsal Space

We are so grateful to have your participation, and in exchange, we are thrilled to offer you some perks. Check them out! 

Thank you for taking the time to learn about ECO. Your support means the world to us. If you don't have the funds to contribute right now, but want to get involved, share this page on social media, contact us as a volunteer, or just spread the word! 

 

We are all members of Mother Earth. It's time to find our voices.

story:
Short Summary

The Dance COLEctive (TDC), a Chicago-based dance company, is undertaking a refreshed, project based approach to making and performing dance via solo and collaborative projects initiated via the creative vision and curiosity of Margi Cole, as well as partnering artists. Also dedicated to teaching and mentorship, TDC motivates and nurtures the next generation of artists in the studio and beyond.  REboot serves to realize and advance the company’s new mission.

The Dance COLEctive in collaboration with Third Way Projects presents:

REboot

September 14, 15, & 16, 2018

Dovetail Studios

2853 W. Montrose, Chicago

7:00pm

Dances created by:  Peter Carpenter, Margi Cole & Colleen Halloran

Dances performed by:  Keesha Beckford, Keisha Bennett, Margi Cole, Keyierra Collins, Lydia Feuerhelm, Dardi McGinley Gallivan and Chloe Grace Michels

Find out more about the show here.

What We Need 

The Dance COLEctive needs to raise $5,000 to help support the presentation of this concert.  All the funds we raise will be allocated to paying the people who are integral to the production and performance of this concert, specifically our performers, choreographers, and technical staff. These generous artists contribute immeasurably to the work in the studio and on the stage, and they can never be paid enough for their creative time. Money raised represents about a ⅓ of the overall budget which is supplemented by ticket sales, a few smaller grants and The Dance COLEctive.  

 

$5,000 pays for:

Artist Fees: $3,800 (2 choreographers, 6 performers)

Technical Crew:  $1,200 (1 lighting designer, 1 stage manager/crew)

 

What You'll Get

$5        Eternal Gratitude

$15      Shout out on Social Media platforms

$25      Program Mention + Shout out on Social Media platforms

$50      Website Mention + Mention in our event program + Shout out on Social Media platforms

$100    Virtual Thank you on Instagram + Website Mention + Mention in our event program + Shout out on Social Media

$250    2 VIP Tickets to REboot + Website Mention + Mention in our event program + Shout out  on Social Media

$500     Invite to a rehearsal sneak peek virtually + 2 VIP ticket + Website Mention + Mention in our event program + Shout out on Social Media

 

All donations are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.

 

The Impact

For more than 22 years The Dance COLEctive has produced high caliber work by Margi Cole and her collaborators.  TDC’s 20th anniversary in 2016 was a significant benchmark that distinguished the company as a Chicago institution.  After inspiring and mentoring so many, TDC has implemented a new programmatic model, retaining its innovative approaches to choreography and performance while transitioning from a set ensemble to a pick-up company model. This change was motivated by Cole’s desire to focus more deeply on artistic exploration with a wider range of performance and collaborative options than the initial company structure allowed.

REboot is the first concert since TDC reshaped its mission and organizational structure. Our interest in collaboration  is our strongest and most constant creative value. This concert exemplifies the artistic growth we have set out to achieve. Your support will enable us to succeed financially,  and, more importantly artistically.  Thank you for considering this opportunity to help keep us thinking, collaborating, making and moving!

 

Can't Donate? Here Are Other Ways You Can Help

Use social media to share this campaign - Facebook, Email, Tweet, Instagram, text, tell friends about it!

  • LIKE The Dance COLEctive on Facebook and Twitter, and follow us on Instagram to see what we’re up to! Share our social media pages and activities with your friends!
  • Make your contribution double!  Find out if your employer takes part in Matching Gifts programs!
  • Come see us perform!  We would love to have your support as an audience member. There is nothing better than a live performance.

story:
What is "UBER Taxi Cab Confessions" about?

UBER has become a daily part of an ever increasingly large number of people's lives.  Driving an UBER is no exception. The experience can be one of life's great adventures: from the touching, to the shocking, to the gross and the downright naughty. Author and part-time Uber driver Joe Mahedy has documented his experiences in a popular book, and is now following up with “UBER Taxi Cab Confessions: The Play." And the excitement is high.

“UBER Taxi Cab Confessions” is told through the eyes of a part-time Uber driver (Joe) who seems to find himself in bizarre ride situations more than worth documenting. From taking people to the hottest clubs and restaurants, to seeing the secret and hidden after hours spots of the rich and famous, being an Uber driver shines a light on a world that would otherwise remain closed. From the minute he turns his app “on,” almost anything and everything is possible.

Why a stage play?

“This is a book that translates into a play perfectly,” commented a spokesperson from the project. “The exchanges between drivers and passengers can be priceless and the scenarios that play out can be beyond shocking, which all make for good, smart, live entertainment; the likes of which Broadway hasn't seen in a while. We can't wait until it all comes together and we open.”

WHAT WE NEED

The biggest financial challenge to produce the showcase is renting the actual theater and the expenses that come with that (i.e. house stage crews, ushers, etc.). The cost will be around $4,000 for that alone. We also need a modified electric golf cart customized to look like an Uber taxi cab, which will cost us around $2,500, and finally, a balance to the crew.

WHAT YOU GET

We are offering a variety of perks as a thanks for any contribution you give. From reserved opening night seats to a signed script. It's all there. (And just think—if the show proves real successful, these items could be highly collectible one day!)

You can even be part of the CAST with a speaking part. Pretty cool to put on your resume, right?

THE IMPACT

Mahedy had a very successful career in television broadcasting in New York and he credits that success to many kind professionals who helped him when he started out. Through this play, he wants to offer the same help to serious college kids who need a chance to break into the arts, as a way of returning the favor.

During the opening weekend, a portion of the door proceeds will be donated to a local charity. We even want to make sure the production is family-friendly and plan to make the second night’s performance a G-rated version, which will give children a chance to enjoy a live theatrical performance and have a few laughs. For the third and final performance, we will return to our regularly scheduled program (R-rated) and hopefully, select a number of potential backers.                                                                                                                                             

Everyone on the team will be offered permanent positions, including the cast, if the show gets picked up for a show run.

How YOU can help!

We are looking at May 2018 for the showcase weekend. We cannot produce this showcase on our own. We need a little help from a lot of people who believe in this concept. Help us bring this book to life by donating and telling your family and friends about us! And even if you can't contribute money-wise, you can still help by getting the word out and making some noise about our campaign! Use the Indiegogo share tools. Any and all help will be appreciated from the bottom of our hearts.

campaign_city: New York, L.A., Las Vegas, United States

story:
The festival has brought talent from around the world to be a voice of change in post-conflict countries. For Rwanda, it has played a significant role in how we discuss the horrific past and the Genocide against the Tutsi in 1994. The festival has explored new ways to speak the unspeakable, understand painful events, and create an avenue for hope and healing.  

Healing, which is one of the gemstones in the festival, has shined through meaningful performances at the Kigali Genocide Memorial Amphitheatre. Music, dances, and plays have been therapeutic; challenging our sense of humanity, edition after edition.




“The festival is a platform that enables us to discuss issues that tormented our past and present. It’s a unique and daring exercise of introspection. I’ve been overwhelmed by the thousands of people who attend, and commit to be part of ensuing activities. Our only way is forward!” - Hope Azeda, Festival Curator.

 

Thanks to performers that pour out their talents and freeze moments into lasting memories, the exuberant audience finds connection in every second of the festival. The outcome has outweighed what we dreamed of; what we cannot shrink into words.

Attending the festival is free of charge. We would like to keep it this way for as long as the sun shines. We want to avail stories of hope, peace and unity to all. This flame needs your support.

The support is to sustain the operations and foster impact. It would provide meals and water for hard-working unpaid volunteers that spend several days, some even weeks, with administration and communities; often in the sun all day and at night during performance days to ensure workshops and performances are successful.

This opportunity would solidify essence of workshops and expand horizons for the youth to grow their talent. With your donations, we’ll be able to meet logistics, accommodations, and equipment costs for once-in-a-lifetime chance. A chance for local participants to meet and interact with world class professional art teachers during workshops.

We want to host more talents and spur teamwork in making the world a better stage.



 

The festival has won hearts of many. It’s not just an event but a place. A place that embraces our boundless potential as humans. Every edition highlights stories that resonate with everyday lives and prepares a generation of peace ambassadors across the globe. Without mentioning its role in creating friendships that evolve into lifelong companionships.

Your contribution is a chance to keep the flame glowing. If you believe in the power of arts to heal, please make a donation and share this campaign.

All money donated will go directly to the running costs of the festival, and will not be used for salaries of any administration or volunteers. If there is any money leftover from donations, it will be used directly to offset these same costs in next year’s edition.

 

I am because you’re. You are, because I am. We’re human together.

 

Photos by Daniel Ecwalu, Kigali Genocide Memorial, and The National.  

 

To learn more about the festival, visit www.ubumuntuartsfestival.com.

story:
A Real Boy

  • Directed by Chelsea Beth 
  • Co-Directed by Matrex Kilgore
  • Featuring:Chelsea Manasseri, Yamina Khouane, Brandon Sterret, Adam Martinez, Emily Christine Smith, Roxanna Taylor, and Genevieve Schroeder-Arce
  • Lighting Design by Courtney DeGinder
  • Props and Stage Mangement by Mindy Griffin
  • Scenic Design by Chris Conard
  • Puppets by Rachel Steed, Courtney DeGinder, Brock England and Mindy Griffin 
  • Graphic Design by LB Deyo
  • Written by Stephen Kaplan

Terry Hill loves her kindergarten students and when she fears that one of them is not being raised appropriately, she decides to take matters in her own hands and keep the child in her classroom to raise as her own. Things are complicated by the fact that this child’s parents happen to be puppets - and Terry fears the boy’s emerging strings will keep him from being a real boy.

How Will We Use These Funds? 

All donations received will go towards paying our actors, designers and collaborators.

We have already received a grant from the City of Austin which will cover much of our production costs, so every dime donated by you will go towards increasing the stipends offered to our amazing cast and crew! Our goal is to be one of the highest paying troupes in Austin, help us get to that goal! 

Why Us? 

Last Act Theatre Company is a production company run 100% by women, 50% of whom are POC. We strive to focus on female voices, and the voices of underserved communities. We also focus almost exclusively on developing new works, and bringing fresh content to Austin's stages. Shakespeare is great, but do we need a 20th production of Midsummer Night's Dream?

This project asks what makes a family, is there more than one type of family, and is letting people go the best way to love them? 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help out with a donation to our cause, fear not! There are several other ways you can show your support. We are always looking for Front of House volunteers, and ways to get the word out! Share this campaign, blog about us, reach out! We are happy to hear from you!

Ticket Info

You can purchase tickets to A Real Boy on our ticketing site.

How Will We Use These Funds? 
All donations received will go towards paying our actors, designers and collaborators.
We have already received a grant from the City of Austin which will cover much of our production costs, so every dime donated by you will go towards increasing the stipends offered to our amazing cast and crew! Our goal is to be one of the highest paying troupes in Austin, help us get to that goal! 

Why Us? 
Last Act Theatre Company is a production company run 100% by women, 50% of whom are POC. We strive to focus on female voices, and the voices of underserved communities. We also focus almost exclusively on developing new works, and bringing fresh content to Austin's stages. Shakespeare is great, but do we need a 20th production of Midsummer Night's Dream?
This project asks what makes a family, is there more than one type of family, and is letting people go the best way to love them? 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't help out with a donation to our cause, fear not! There are several other ways you can show your support. We are always looking for Front of House volunteers, and ways to get the word out! Share this campaign, blog about us, reach out! We are happy to hear from you!
Ticket Info
You can purchase tickets to A Real Boy on our ticketing site.

story:
ABOUT US

(Special thanks to Chris Kragl for the Deutsch translations!)

 

  • What is Cancioneiro Queer?

A performatic concert created by Brazilian performer Marcelo Kuna, Cancioneiro Queer ("Queer Songbook") is a musical revue of songs from Weimar Republic, Brazilian Musical Theatre, Broadway, Off Broadway, and Opera that discusses queer bodies and love in different forms through song. More information on Instagram @cancioneiroqueer and on www.facebook.com/cancioneiroqueer.

 

PORTUGUÊS

O Que é Cancioneiro Queer?

Um concerto performático criado pelo artista do corpo e cantor Marcelo Kuna, Cancioneiro Queer é um espetáculo cênico-musical com canções da República de Weimar, Teatro Musical Brasileiro, Broadway, Off Broadway e Ópera que discute corpos queer e o amor em suas diferentes formas por meio da canção. Mais informações no Instagram @cancioneiroqueer e no site: www.facebook.com/cancioneiroqueer.

 

DEUTSCH

Was ist Cancioneiro Queer?

Cancioneiro Queer ist der Name eines performativen Konzerts des brasilianischen Künstler Marcelo Kuna. Cancioneiro Queer ("Queeres Liedgut") ist ein musikalisches Kabarett mit Liedern der Weimarer Republik, des brasilianischen Musiktheaters, vom Broadway, Off Broadway und der Oper. Es geht um Stücke, die queere Liebe und Körperidentitäten in verschiedenen Formen thematisieren. Mehr Informationen über Instagram @cancioneiroqueer und www.facebook.com/cancioneiroqueer.

 

Photo by Sofia Pacheco/29º Inverno Cultural UFSJ

 

  • Who is Cida Moreira? 

Brazilian actress, pianist and singer who works with music as the backbone for her theatrical and cinematic performances. Her career spans more than 38 years, and she has developed a unique style in Brazilian performance and culture. In her long resume you'll find eleven albums, eleven movies, four TV miniseries, three Brazilian telenovelas, countless theatre works as musical director, aside from her work managing and directing her own musical career. She's worked with some of the best Brazilian directors, actors and singers, and she's especially known for her collaborations with a new generation of Brazilian artists such as Thiago Pethit (@thiagopethit) and Filipe Catto (@filipecatto). 

 

PORTUGUÊS

Quem é Cida Moreira?

Atriz, pianista e cantora, sendo que a música é sua expressão primordial, e todo seu trabalho artístico, seja no teatro ou cinema, é permeado por sua atuação musical. Com uma carreira multifacetada de quase 40 anos, desenvolveu um estilo único, o que a coloca como uma artista singular no panorama brasileiro. Em seu extenso currículo podemos enumerar onze discos, onze filmes, quatro minisséries de TV, três novelas, incontáveis direções musicais em teatro e três direções gerais; além de gerir e direcionar todo o seu trabalho musical, em inúmeros shows musicais. Trabalhou com grandes diretores, atores e cantores, além de ser especialmente reconhecida por suas colaborações com uma nova geração de artistas brasileiros como Thiago Pethit (@thiagopethit) e Filipe Catto (@filipecatto).

 

DEUTSCH

Wer ist Cida Moreira?

Cida Moreira ist eine brasilianische Schauspielerin, Pianistin und Sängerin, deren künstlerische Heimat die Musik ist, auf deren Grundlage sich ihr umfangreiches theatralisches und filmisches Oeuvre entwickelte. Ihre Karriere umfasst mehr als 38 Jahre, in denen sie die brasilianische Performance- und Theater-Kultur mit ihrem einzigartigen Stil bereicherte. In ihrem langen Schaffen blickt sie auf 11 Musikalben, vier TV Miniserien, drei brasilianische Telenovelas und zahllose Theater-Produktionen als Musikdirektorin zurück. Neben diesen Projekten gestaltete sie ihre eigene Karriere als Musikerin. Sie arbeitete mit den besten brasilianischen Film- und Theaterregisseuren, Schauspielern und Sängern zusammen und ist für ihre Zusammenarbeit mit einer neuen Generation brasilianischer Künstler wie Thiago Petit (@thiagopethit) und Filipe Catto (@filipecatto) bekannt.

 

Photo by Ana Colla/Grande Hotel Ronaldo Fraga​

 

  • Why are we going to Berlin? 

As the 1800 Franz von Suppé song goes: "Du bist verrückt mein Kind, du musst nach Berlin" (You are crazy, my child. You must go to Berlin). So, we've decided to take our queerness to the "city of creativity" in order to create and perform an original work called "Ignoble Cabaret". It is a mix of our original repertoire from Queer Songbook with some of the hits performed by Cida Moreira during her widely recognized career as a songstress of the Brechtian repertoire.

 

PORTUGUÊS

Por que vamos à Berlim?

Como diz a canção de 1800 de Franz von Suppé: "Du bist verrückt mein Kind, du musst nach Berlin" (Você está louca/o, minha filha/o. Você deve ir à Berlin). Então, nós decidimos levar nossa loucura à "cidade criativa" para criar e apresentar um trabalho original chamado "Cabaret Indigno". Ele e um misto de canções do nosso repertório original do Cancioneiro Queer com alguns dos sucessos apresentados por Cida Moreira ao longo de sua amplamente reconhecida carreira como intérprete do repertório brechtiano. 

 

DEUTSCH

Warum gehen wir nach Berlin?

"Du bist verrückt mein Kind, du musst nach Berlin" (Franz Von Suppé, 1800), so heißt es in diesem bekannten Lied. Wir sehen in der "Stadt der Kreativen" den idealen Ort um unseren queeren Lebensstil in unserem Stück „Unwürdiges Kabarett" darzustellen und zu thematisieren. Es ist eine Kombination aus Stücken des „Queeren Liedguts" mit einigen Liedern von Cida Moreiras, die als Sängerin von Brechts Werken bekannt wurde.

 

Photo by Ana Colla/Grande Hotel Ronaldo Fraga

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

 

With your support, be it in donation, in spreading the word or even in checking us out on social media and posting about us, we can make this original work happen!

  • We have secured some of the funding with grants from Brazil, but we still need to pay for some travel expenses, rehearsal spaces, and production fees in Berlin. 
  • Not only you can guarantee your ticket by purchasing our $15 perk, but you'll also help us pay for general expenses.
  • If we don't reach everything, any amount we can raise will still help us in paying for a piano rent, and in securing rent for local instruments and theatre

 

WHY CROWDFUNDING?

 

  • It's not every day that artists from Brazil can cross the ocean to present a work in such a charming theatre like the Delphi (if you don't know it, you can check it out at http://theater-im-delphi.de/). 
  • In fact, Brazil is undergoing its worst political and economical crisis in history, and art production has suffered dramatically from that, on a national level. "Cancioneiro Queer" has been produced independently since its inception, and this is the first time that we receive money from the State Bureau of Culture in Minas Gerais (BR) so that we can tour internationally. 
  • LGBTQ art is common in Berlin, a city that – despite a brief moment in its past – is and has been home to queer pioneers, and especially to great queer art! Brazil has been honing generations of very important queer "artivists", but the track record of Brazilian society and its acceptance of LGBTQ people has not been so commendable: it is the country with most trans deaths in the world! Our form of political resistance is to spread conscience about this situation happening in Brazil, through art. 

 

 

LET'S BE BAD!

If you're a starving artist, or just short of money to make a contribution, you can also help us by spreading the word ;)

We are on Instagram @cancioneiroqueer, and Facebook: www.facebook.com/cancioneiroqueer

You can find Cida Moreira on Instagram @cidamoreiraoficial, and on Facebook: www.facebook.com/cidamoreiraoficial

You can also use all of the Indiegogo share tools so that you can tell your family, friends and frenemies all about us ;)

 

www.instagram.com/cancioneiroqueer

www.facebook.com/cancioneiroqueer

story:
Short Summary

  • Chloe Hennessy is a student writer from the NW.
  • This campaign is to raise money for a fully staged production of the play "Cinder-hella". The play is going to be performed in the local public parks. Free to the community.
  • Funds raised will be used to purchase basic costumes and set, cover the printing costs of scripts, and to launch minimal advertisement.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The total cost of this production is expected to be somewhere around $1,000. That's including set, costume, advertisement, and application fees for the public parks. That is not including transportation cost or liability insurance.

The Impact

  • The project will give the community the opportunity to see a new work for no cost, and will give the playwright the opportunity to have this work seen.

Risks & Challenges

  • There is a significantly long process to getting the space to perform this show approved.
  • We've started in advance (two months ahead) in order to assure we'll have everything we need to have an awesome show.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this fundraising project with anyone you know that might be interested in helping or seeing the show themselves!
  • Share this campaign using the "Indiegogo" share button.

Thank you so much for your thoughts, support, and help!

story:
The intention of our team at ShakespeArts is to become a non-profit organization that contributes to the culture of Quogue and the surrounding area during the summer season (and hopefully throughout the year). This summer, we put up our own medley of scenes from Shakespeare including a special rendition of "Twelfth Night," and a cameo from "Romeo and Juliet", among others. We are committed not only to performing Shakespeare, but also to increasing opportunities for individuals to experience the arts. As a non-profit, part of our mission is to offer audiences of all ages the benefit of open classes in Shakespeare, acting and theater, dance, music, voice, singing, yoga, tai chi, Zumba, health and wellness, and much more! We also want to support the artistic endeavors of others through hosting readings of plays, cabarets and dance performances featuring emerging playwrights, local talent, and much more! We will put on 'pop up' performances at multiple locations in our area, possibly in your own backyard! 

Please support us as we hit the ground running!

Here's a breakdown of our budget:

story: Sophea is young adult in a 12 year old body. She has developed a passion for dance and has been pursuing it at a ballet school in the Spokane area (not allowed to associate our cause with it) for several years. She is looking for the opportunity to attend a national (not allowed to associate our cause with it) youth ballet event and has begun to earn the funds to cover her trip through Krispy Kreme doughnuts fund raising program and here on Indiegogo. In between her school and dance schedules, she hopes to raise enough money to pay for her registration and entry fees, transportation, food & lodging. She will also need pairs of pointe shoes, a couple costumes, hair accessories and make-up. Any and all help is greatly appreciated. All donations, big and small, help make her dream come closer to reality.

story:
the company

An artistic collective which was formed by Northwestern University alumni, Muse10 focuses on fostering new work that sparks critical dialogue. Your contributions are vital in helping us execute our vision for this thought provoking piece of new work.

the show

Written by Bex Ehrmann and Alexandra Shields, Charred explores the aftermath of a tragedy. Caroline, a teenager with obsessive-compulsive disorder, loses her family in a horrific accident. Following their death, her trauma drives her into a magical realm, where she is forced to face her invasive thoughts personified. Charred combines the surrealism of Alice in Wonderland with the social awareness of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time to create a thoughtful, horrifying, and searing new work.

the donation

  Building the world of Charred is no easy feat, and we need all the help we can get. This play aims to both pull audiences into a fantastic new universe and ignite important conversations about mental health in our society. It cannot do so without the support of family and friends like you. Muse10 is using lights, sound, costumes, puppetry, and more to help make Charred an unforgettable experience. Any amount you can contribute will be greatly appreciated in helping us cover these expenses and bring this play to life.

Donations are instrumental in helping us create a high quality production that does this complex script justice and help us make groundbreaking theatre like this accessible to the community. What's more, they also provide your business with good marketing and publicity, should you choose to purchase an advertisement in our program.

The entire team is hugely grateful for your support and eager to introduce the world to Charred on September 3rd-5th.  We would love to share this memorable piece with you.

story:
"Sleep At Your Own Risk" is a one-man comedy about a guy struggling through the insanity of sleepwalking to hold onto the love of his life…and not walk out of the apartment naked.

"Brendan is no small talent.... a manly man, he tells us the story with sweet affability. ...and Mr. Wahlers carries off these absurdities with panache."  

                                                                                    -Cheryl King, NY Theater Now

Hi! I'm  Brendan Wahlers and I am an actor/producer and drama teacher in NY/NJ and I will be performing the one-man show "Sleep At Your Own Risk".

"Sleep At Your Own Risk" is an important show about one man's journey in battling his affliction with the phenomenon known as sleepwalking. Almost 5 years in the making, this labor of love has been accepted into one of the most prestigious theatre festivals in the world-- FringeNYC-The New York International Theatre Festival. This is a great honor and an exceptionally important step in sharing this story with the world.

With your help, I will be able to produce a high quality festival show that was created with the love and talent of dozens of people over the past few years.

With your help, this story will help to shed light on a little talked about phenomenon that is highly misunderstood, sometimes funny, and even sometimes deadly. This story just may give someone the courage to save their own life...and possibly the lives of others.


What We Need & What You Get

Break Down:

Participation Fee    $700 (Got To Be In It To Win It!!!)

Advertising                $600 (People need to know about the show, Yay!)

Staff                              $500 (Lights/sound, etc, We love tech staff!)

Rehearsal Space     $400 (Free living rooms aren’t always available)

Insurance                   $125 (A Must)

Miscellaneous          $125 (There’s always unexpected extras)

Total=                          $2,500 

  • If we don't reach our goal, whatever money collected will first go to Techical Staff and then to Advertising.

****ALL PERKS ARE STILL AVAILABLE EVEN IF IT SAYS "CLAIMED".****

You're Not Alone

Matthew Ethan Davis wrote this play as a way to share his story and spread the word about sleepwalking and its dangers. He wanted to let other sleepwalkers know they are not alone. Apparently he was right!!!!

(CBS News) Sleepwalking is much more common in the U.S. population that previously thought, researchers announced Monday....In a new study, published in the May 15 (2012) issue of the journal, Neurology, researchers found about 3.6 percent of U.S. adults - about 8.4 million people - sleepwalk each year. What's more, almost 30 percent of adults said they've strolled while snoozing at least once throughout their lifetime.

Why We Do It...

 If you know anything about independent theatre, you know that it is almost always a labor of love and it can't exist without the charity of others. Monitary profit is not familiar term. We do it because we love to art of storytelling, we love to entertain, but most of all, we love to help and inspire others!!!

Other ways to Help...

Please help me spread the word to friends and family about this -- send emails and connect with me on Facebook and Twitter. Please use the Indiegogo Share Tools (see below) and let's get the word out to as many people as we can!
story_txt:
"Sleep At Your Own Risk" is a one-man comedy 
about a guy struggling through the insanity of sleepwalking to hold onto
 the love of his life…and not walk out of the apartment naked.
"Brendan
 is no small talent.... a manly man, he tells us the 
story with sweet affability. ...and Mr. Wahlers carries off 
these absurdities with panache."  
                                                                                    -Cheryl King, NY Theater Now Hi! I'm  Brendan Wahlers and I am an actor/producer and drama teacher in NY/NJ and I will be performing the one-man show "Sleep At Your Own Risk".
"Sleep At Your Own Risk" is an important show about one man's journey in battling his affliction with the phenomenon known as sleepwalking. Almost 5 years in the making, this labor of love has been accepted into one of the most prestigious theatre festivals in the world-- FringeNYC-The New York International Theatre Festival. This is a great honor and an exceptionally important step in sharing this story with the world.
With your help, 
I
will be able to produce a high quality festival show that was created with the love
and talent of dozens of people over the past few years.

With your help, this story will help to shed light on a little talked about phenomenon that is highly misunderstood, sometimes funny, and even sometimes deadly. This story just may give someone the courage to save their own life...and possibly the lives of others.

  What We Need & What You Get Break Down:



Participation
Fee    $700 (Got To Be In It To Win It!!!)
Advertising                $600 (People need to
know about the show, Yay!)
Staff                              $500
(Lights/sound, etc, We love tech staff!)
Rehearsal Space     $400 (Free living rooms aren’t
always available)
Insurance                   $125 (A Must)
Miscellaneous          $125 (There’s always
unexpected extras)
Total=                          $2,500  


If we don't reach our goal, whatever money collected will first go to Techical Staff and then to Advertising.

****ALL PERKS ARE STILL AVAILABLE EVEN IF IT SAYS "CLAIMED".****
    You're Not Alone
Matthew Ethan Davis wrote this play as a way to share his story and spread the word about sleepwalking and its dangers. He wanted to let other sleepwalkers know they are not alone. Apparently he was right!!!!

(CBS News) Sleepwalking is much more common in the U.S. population that previously thought, researchers announced Monday....In a new study, published in the May 15 (2012) issue of the journal, Neurology,
 researchers found about 3.6 percent of U.S. adults - about 8.4 million 
people - sleepwalk each year. What's more, almost 30 percent of adults 
said they've strolled while snoozing at least once throughout their 
lifetime. 
  Why We Do It...
 If you know anything about independent theatre, you know that it is almost always a labor of love and it can't exist without the charity of others. Monitary profit is not familiar term. We do it because we love to art of storytelling, we love to entertain, but most of all, we love to help and inspire others!!!
  
Other ways to Help...
Please help me spread the word to friends and family about this -- send 
emails and connect with me on Facebook and Twitter. Please use the 
Indiegogo Share Tools (see below) and let's get the word out to as many 
people as we can!

story:
The New Classics Company

This summer, the New Classics Company, a young upstart theatre company, will be returning to the Guyer Art Barn in downtown Hyannis, MA, to present another season of exciting original theater!

With two years under our belt so far, NCC has produced some of the most exciting and original theater on Cape Cod, including Georgie's Full Swing and I've Got a Bad Feeling About This: A Tribute to George Lucas. In addition we've produced an array of special events, including free improv, staged readings, concerts, and more.

2015

This year we've got an incredibly exciting lineup planned, including three new shows, and a whole host of special events! Including a brand new children's show, Alex Comes Clean, a new adaptation of Lewis Carroll's classics, Alice, and a special one weekend only performance of "Laugh it Up Fuzzball: New Classics Presents A New Hope!" We're also excited about increasing our output of special events, including Improv workshops and our first ever 24 hour play festival!

Thanks in large part to our continuing success, we've built a large staff of volunteers and artists, who generously devote their invaluable time and effort. There's no way we could do it without them and we're so happy to have so many of them back this year.

But we still can't do it alone. Did you know that we're projecting our publicity costs alone this summer to run $500? We're also facing over $1,000 in general use costs, such as rental fees, tools and equipment, box office materials and more! Not to mention we'd love to be able to provide our wonderful volunteers with limited stipends. This is where you come in.

Here at New Classics our mission is simple, to provide professional quality original theater with the lowest cost to our audiences possible. This means that once we're up and running, our profits provide us just enough support to keep running. But we need your help to get started! That's why we're trying to raise $3,500 to help jumpstart our hugely exciting 2015 season!

Where Your Money Goes

Most important to us at NCC is that you feel safe knowing exactly where your money is going. That's why we've laid our projected costs over the next few months for you below.

Theater Rental: $500

Box Office/Press Costs: $600

Tools/Theater Maintenance & Upkeep: $450

Set Construction: $1,000

Costumes Rental/Construction: $400

Props Rental/Construction: $350

Lighting Equipment Rental: $200

All of these costs add up quickly, and with your help we can ensure not only that our productions are top notch, but that any profits will directly go to benefit the future success of the company and ensure that our wonderful volunteers will see some repayment for the tireless efforts.

What You Get

At NCC we hate asking for donations, and that's why we see crowdfunding as a way for you to reserve your tickets ahead of time. And that's why for every donation of $10 or more, you'll receive a free ticket to any one of our shows this summer. In addition we have more extensive perks, including signed posters, season tickets, premium season passes, and producers credits!

Other Ways to Get Involved

Most importantly though, NCC recognizes that times are tight. Nobody knows better than us how hard it can be sometimes to offer financial support. That's why we've got plenty of other ways for you get involved this summer. We're always looking for volunteers, so if you find yourself in the Cape Cod area this summer, drop us a line and find out how you be a part of the team. NCC is in dire need of assistance with box office and house keeping duties, set construction, and tech help for our shows. We're also always looking for people interested in joining us as artists. If you have a script you'd like us to consider send it our way. If you're a performer interested in joining one of our shows or our improv troupe send us your resume and headshot. If your band is interested in performing with us send us some samples of your work. We're always looking to get new and enthusiastic artists involved, so get in touch today. You can always reach us through email at newclassicscompany@gmail.com

If you're not in the Cape Cod area you can still get involved! We rely hugely on social media for our marketing and publicity efforts, so check us out today at www.facebook.com/newclassicscompany. Like and share us and be sure to tell all your friends! We're so excited to be coming back this summer, and we really hope you can join us. Thanks for all your help and we'll see you at the barn!

story:
OUR STORY

Once Upon a Kingdom Theatre met SOLO School of Fine Arts last year in Washington, DC during International Children's Theatre Festival. During that exciting weekend in Washington we became close friends with SOLO and were really sad when we found out we lived so far away. At the end we took home the award for Best Director while our new friends were awarded the Grand-Prix. After this we decided to start "Children's Theatre Exchange", because we knew that we just must continue our artistic dialogue with each other and share with new audiences.

ABOUT THIS PROJECT

Children's Theatre Exchange provides an opportunity for children who participate in theatre groups in various cities to find friends with similar interests; exchange and share their theatre experience; broaden perception of the theatre world; learn to engage in open discussions about each other's work skillfully and professionally; and find joy in collective creation with new people.

A LIFETIME WORTH OF FUN IN ONE WEEK

In the course of one week, children will share their original shows with each other and the general public. The young actors will participate in the following acting workshops lead by professional theatre practitioners:

  • Advanced Acting,
  • Shadow Theatre,
  • Set Design,
  • Theatre Criticism,
  • Advanced Back-Stage work,
  • Guided Art Tours.

Children will lead discussions and theatre debates at the round-table, write and publish theatre reviews, and of course spend unforgettable days full of friendship and creativity.

OUR GOAL

Our goal this season is to bring SOLO School from Atlanta, USA to Ottawa. As the Host-Theatre of this creative gathering we are trying our best to cover costs for:

  • Theatre space rentals for shows,
  • Studio rentals to hold workshops,
  • Transportation for students in town,
  • Food for participants,
  • Accommodations in host families.

TO DO ALL THIS WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Please pass this message on to anyone who you think can help! All donations are  greatly appreciated, even a couple of dollars can determine whether the OUK and SOLO theatres will meet face to face this June and if hundreds of children in Ottawa will get a chance to see two wonderful shows.

NEW! We have some new pictures from our Dress Rehearsals! Here is little sneak peak for you!

"The Magic Paintbrush" by Once Upon a Kingdom Theatre


"The Flying Ship" by SOLO Theatre

story:
About The Great Somewhere

Asterism Theatre Company presents the world premiere of Trey K. Blackburn's The Great Somewhere.

Coming in fall 2015 to a downtown theatre near you!

A tornado strikes a small Iowa town, and the Woodridge children come home to clean up and search for their parents. Estranged by time, distance, and perspective, brothers Clark and Hudson attempt to rekindle their connection in the the face of devastation. But when Hudson refuses to be the best man in Clark's upcoming wedding to his partner, Roger, the sibling's unyielding beliefs threaten to blow their home and family apart.

What happens when the home you grew up in is destroyed by the forces of nature and belief? If you've ever journeyed away from your place of birth, only to find you can't quite shake it off of your pant leg, this play is for you.


About Asterism Theatre Company

  • We're emerging artists and we believe it's important to support and work with other emerging artists. That means creating opportunities within our company for unheard, untried, untested voices.
  • We believe that a play should be treated with as much respect as a person, and that it is only through examining a text from all angles that it will be able to truly able to stand up and walk on its own.
  • We believe in creating the maximum theatrical experience with a minimum of material elements. 
  • We believe there's room for everyone's story. We desperately want our work to reflect a broad range of experiences, backgrounds, and viewpoints that are underrepresented in modern theatre.
  • We believe theatre should be, first and foremost, a product of and for the community. The work of Asterism is to reflect the joys and challenges of the communities we live in.

What We Need & What You Get

We'll be real with you: starting a theatre company is no easy task. Fortunately, both of us are as frugal as we are creative. We're asking for $10,000, which will allow us to produce The Great Somewhere as well as ensure Asterism is around for years to come. Here's where your money will go:

  • Pay for a venue (We love poor theatre, but it would be nice to have a roof over our heads. And the audience's)
  • Compensate our actors (They're the heartbeat of ourproject.)
  • Hire a production staff (Including designers, a stage manager, and a running crew)
  • Create a publicity campaign (Have you ever been to a show with no audience? It's sad.)
  • Secure props & costumes (We've never sent anyone onstage without clothing - at least not accidentally - and we're not about to start now)
  • Book rehearsal space (Our spacious New York apartments aren't exactly ideal for making theatre.)
  • Purchase insurance (Safety first!)
Last, but not least:
  • We have plans. Big plans. After producing The Great Somewhere, any money that is left over will be used to fund future projects and fulfill our additional aim of bringing theatre to rural and urban communities that don't have ready access to it.
Know that we intend to produce The Great Somewhere regardless of whether we reach our monetary goal, and ever penny you donate will go towards realizing this play and launching our fledgling company.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Show our Facebook page a little love!
  • Follow us on Twitter!
  • Sign up for our mailing list!
  • Spread the good news of Asterism by word of mouth (we hear people still talk to each other in real life)!
  • Give us a high five (local or long-distance accepted)!
  • And most of all...come see our work. We'd love to have you.

story:
The Drowned World

How far would you go for a moment of human connection? What would you do to feel the touch of another? In a world poised on the brink of self-destruction, where humans have divided, isolated and quarantined each other, this is the story of four people. How they lived, loved, and died.


What Is Going On?

This play is poetic, vicious, and unrelenting. And so beautiful it makes my heart ache.

This project and I have been simmering together for almost a decade, waiting for the right time to make it a reality. This is the time. Our world is struggling more and more with making human connections. There is so much that distances and divides us: from the small to the large, the addictions to screens to the political affiliations. This seems like a good time to be reminded that we’re all human, and we all – when we get right down to it – want more or less the same things. 

We all know the devastation of loneliness. We all know the sting of feeling like you don’t belong.

Who Are We?

I’m Virginia. If we haven’t met yet, hopefully we will soon. I’m one of the Co-Artistic Directors of mad/magic, the company producing this play. In fact, it’s our inaugural production. And actually, this play was the impetus behind us forming the company to begin with. My co-conspirator (and the other Co-Artistic Director) is Rebecca.

This project is the collaborative effort of 6 fantastic humans: me, Rebecca Robertson, Paul Corning Jr., Casey Jordan, Leon Ingulsrud, and Benita de Wit. I am humbled beyond words to be in the creative presence of these talented people.

How Can You Help?

As Leon eloquently put it, this is a “heart over pocketbook” production. It’s very important to us that this show is accessible to anybody, so our tickets are donation-only.

We are, however, trying to cover cost…$3500, to be exact.

Thankfully, we’ve had generous in-kind donations of rehearsal space and some materials, but we are still needing to handle the performance space, costumes, collaborator stipends, royalties, insurance, and incidentals. That’s where you come in.

With your help, we can reach our goal, bring you this beautiful piece, and still pay our rent.

And now - here’s the fun part! To sweeten the deal, we’re offering you some perks. You can check them out to the right… They’re inspired by the script, and I hope they make you smile. (Any of the outing/adventure perks will be scheduled at a time that works for everyone involved.) Think of them as little tokens of my appreciation. This project means a lot to me, and your help is greatly valued.

If you aren’t able to donate, don’t worry – I still love you. Plus, there are other ways you can help!

- Tell your friends

- Share this page on any of your various social media platforms

- Reach out if you’d like to help out on show days


Anything else?

And, as always, THANKYOUTHANKYOUTHANKYOU for taking the time to visit this page, donating, sharing, etc., and we hope to see you at the show!


The Drowned World

by Gary Owen

Sept 9-12 @ 7:30pm, Sept 12 @ 2pm

The SITI Company’s Peter Zeisler Studio

520 8th Ave (b/w 36th & 37th)

Ste 310
