story:
For five years, 

We, The Discordia Dames, have produced a burlesque festival in downtown Greensboro. This festival serves a multitude of purposes. Firstly, the festival brings world class burlesque and performers from all over the country to Greensboro. Secondly, we donate everything outside of our production costs to a local non profit, this year we'll be selecting a charity which focuses on fighting HB2. We use our art to strengthen not only our performance community, but the community as a whole. 

What We Need & What You Get

We still need about $2,000 in funding. If we can do this, then 100% of our ticket sales, raffle tickets, etc. can towards this years nonprofit. This funding will provide the following: 

-Venue Rental: This includes the venue rental, venue manager, sound and lighting technician, and security. 

-Headliner expense- This includes the headliners flight and fees. 

-Event Insurance- This covers liability insurance for any events to the venue or performers. 

Risks & Challenges

Since we give everything outside of the production costs to a local 501c3 non profit, we start every year with nothing but faith in ourselves and hard work. Several performers in the troupe and in the local community donate their time and performance fees to the festival's production. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also assist just in coming to the festival and sharing the event on social media.

story:
Best. Summer. Ever. 

True story: Bohemian Grove is a summer camp in Northern California where the country's most powerful men gather to shrug off the mantle of responsibility, cavort under the redwoods, entertain each other with musical extravaganzas, and walk around peeing on absolutely everything.

Our story: July, 1967. A fog of bitter rivalry hangs heavy over the camp. Ronny and Dick are vying against each other for the lead in the Our Free World camp pageant. PBJ engages in sadistic displays of dominance over his best bud, Hubie. Newspaper magnate Ignatius P. Freeley is collecting enough unpublishable dirt to take down the free world. Meanwhile, Nancy and Ayn's accidental summoning of the demon Molochia, combined with the intrusion of a band of hallucinating hippies and a groovy but meddlesome gonzo journalist, threatens to shut the camp down. Can the campers forget their differences and band together to defend what's most important: the centralization of American power?

 

The Campers

Conceived & created by Rachel Kerry & Jessie Winograd 
Devised by Brain Melt Consortium
Directed by Rachel Kerry

Allyson Elliott as Ronny
Helena Farhi as PBJ
Travis James as Moonstone Kupferberg
Alexander Katz as Ayn
Connor Prickettt as The Demon Molochia
Ian Prince as Nancy
Jonathan Rentler as Feather Rashbaum
Sarah Wilhelm as Hubie
Jessie Winograd as Dick
And Ewa Maria Wojcik as the voice of I. P. Freeley.

 

Send Us Kids to Camp! 

While the real Bohemian Grove may be attended by the rich and powerful, Brain Melt's Camp BoHoGro! needs your support to get up and running! Your donation will help us pay for: 

-Dream Up Festival Entrance Fee

-Rehearsal Space

-Costumes, Props and other incidentals

Total Fundraising Goal: $2000

 

Other Ways to Help?

Come see the show! Tickets now on sale here: http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?showcode=camCB8

Help us spread the word about Camp BoHoGro! by sharing this page with your friends on social media!

story:
BREAKING NEWS:  An anonymous donor has magnanimously offered to make a 1:2 dollar match (50 cents on the dollar) if we make our goal!!

We believe we can do it with your donation. No amount is too small so whatever you can give will be appreciated!

The Reviews Are In!  Help us

Harvard dominates the second act as the older Tommy. He delivers songs in impassioned ASL while dancing and working in sync with Will Hayes, who sings the part in a vulnerable tenor.
 - The Washington Post

We started Open Circle because there wasn’t a dedicated space in the DC Metro area where artists with disabilities could hone their craft playing roles not always provided to them in the mainstream professional theatre world alongside their peers without disabilities. Although,DC is a great place to audition and get cast for a diverse pool of actors - many casting directors are willing to consider actors' talents and not worry about body type - other performing artists with disabilities to find their path and didn’t have the boldness to go out and audition.  We wanted to show how disability can enhance an aesthetic, a performance, rather than be perceived as an obstacle to it.

Another important goal was for our audiences to be as diverse as the performers on stage, so we make each and every performance accessible to people of ALL abilities – providing ASL interpretation embedded in most performances, captioning, audio description, and wheelchair accessibility for EVERY performance, not just a select few. That's why we've picked the Silver Spring Black Box Theater in downtown Silver Spring, Maryland as our venue. It's a fully accessible space (both onstage and backstage) with easy access to Metro.

Our comeback show was The Who’s Tommy and was directed by our Artistic Director Suzanne Richard (2005 nominated, Jesus Christ Superstar) with Jake Null (2016 Helen Hayes Award Winner, Avenue Q,) as the musical director, Cassie Meador (Executive Artistic Director) and Matthew Crumbie (Associate Artistic Director) from Dance Exchange as choreographers along with Jen Bevan adding theatrical staging and choreography.  We wanted to do something challenging with a show that has some important issues. Tommy and the “deaf, dumb, and blind boy” is really a metaphor for the things that Pete Townshend was going through in his childhood, his recovery from his childhood, and his dealing with being a rock star. But we wanted to reclaim the metaphor and look at this through the lens of the real disability experience – we liked to call it - THE METAPHOR STRIKES BACK!

What would it be like if Tommy really were Deaf…Tommy really were blind.  Well, in our production, Tommy is really going to be Deaf and when he turns around to speak for the first time he’s going to speak in American Sign Language not English! And he’s Deaf the whole rest of the time because what is “being healed”?  You know, he’s fine.  He can speak now, that’s what’s important.  He can be "heard" and understood.

One third of our cast was professional actors with disabilities. We don’t like to cut corners. We had an cast amazing of actors that can SING the show and can SIGN the show -- all creating one ensemble. For example, we were very excited to have Equity actor Russell Harvard, Broadway, film, and TV star who is Deaf, on board as older Tommy.  Everyone working onstage and backstage is paid as are all the creative designers who do amazing things to bring my vision to life.

So we need YOU to join us to help fund more productions! As Tommy says, “From you, we get the glory!”

BREAKING NEWS:  An anonymous donor has magnanimously offered to make a 1:2 dollar match (50 cents on the dollar) if we make our goal!!

We believe we can do it with your donation. No amount is too small so whatever you can give will be appreciated!

Your fully tax-deductible donation will go to support the following production expenses in our upcoming shows:

  • Actor contracts
  • Rehearsal ASL interpreters
  • Directors and Designers
  • Set, Costumes, Props, and Video
  • Musicians
  • Tech Crew
  • Theatre Rental
  • …and much more!

A detailed list of what you can get for donations of $50 or more are detailed on our Individual Donation page at http://opencircletheatre.org/donate/individuals/

The success of this show will have a meaningful impact on all the artists in the company, especially the artists with disabilities who don’t always have prime opportunities to perform.

Testimonial from Monica Lijewski, Equity actor and member of the ensemble of The Who’s Tommy:

I was a professional actor since the time I turned 19 years old.  I’m now 53.  I was injured five years ago in a work accident as an actor and now live with a spinal cord injury. Since then, I have not worked as an actor nor did I ever think I would again.  A chance conversation with a fellow actor friend put me in touch with a woman named Susie Richard. And coincidentally it turns out that Open Circle was reopening its doors after a five year hiatus and was hoping to produce an ambitious show called The Who’s Tommy. When Susie found out I had been an accountant for 11 years as my day job, she actually put me in charge of the company’s finances. And then she encouraged me to audition for the show and I was cast!  I can’t tell you what that means for someone who hasn’t been on the stage for five years…whose life was turned upside down and who suddenly walked into an audition room and felt like a whole, normal person again. We are professionals and we stand or we sit alongside our peer professionals and produce great theater. I couldn’t have hoped to come across anything better at this time of my life.

Open Circle Theatre produces extraordinary works of professional theater.  Theater, unfortunately, is not an inexpensive endeavor. To do it, we can’t rely on ticket sales and we can’t rely on grants.  We have to apply to you, the theatergoers, who enjoy our work. We don’t like having to ask for money but it’s what we must do to do what we must--which is produce great art. A donation, no matter how small, will help us produce The Who’s Tommy and other works of theater with professional artists like me for years to come. THANK YOU!

Our Mission

Look around. The fabric of humanity is comprised of individuals of many shapes, sizes, and colors. Yet most of what we see on television, in film, and on the stage does not reflect what our society looks like. People with disabilities, specifically, can be perceived as being “less than” or, in the theater, “not as talented or capable” as their peers. Open Circle Theatre’s mission is to change that perception and stereotype by demonstrating that disability on stage can make a production MORE intriguing, MORE innovative, and MORE beautiful by combining the talents of all of humanity.

Open Circle Theatre needs your help and support to change that perception in our community and in our world.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t afford to contribute right now, please help us get the word out by telling your friends and family about this campaign and the show, LIKING Open Circle Theatre on Facebook (or better yet LOVING us!) and sharing our Facebook links.  You can even choose Open Circle as a charity you can contribute to when you are shopping for qualifying products on Amazon through their AmazonSmile program that you can learn about at: http://opencircletheatre.org/donate/amazon-smile/. Either way, please come see the show!  For more details, visit our Current Production page at http://opencircletheatre.org/events/current-production/.

THANK YOU!

story:
Last spring, Prof. Randy Messersmith from Scottsdale Community College came to Orange Theatre with a proposal... How about a co-production? 

The idea was to bring members of Orange Theatre to SCC's nationally-recognized School of Film + Theatre as resident artists for the fall semester. Together with the students in the Theatre Arts program, we'd create an original work. The students would work as an ensemble, learning how build a piece from scratch alongside professional artists. Through workshops and rehearsals, they'd gain an understanding of both the historical tradition and contemporary practices in experimental performance and create a unique work of their own.

The result: Ida.

We decided to base our play on Ida, a novel by Gertrude Stein, that revolves around a woman who is well known for being well known. To create our play, the students are drawing upon both Stein’s book and their own personal experiences with its themes. The show features a live band led by Mario Yniguez, and it combines original music, movement, and live video technology with text from Stein's novel and other sources to create a contemporary, dynamic work of theatre. 

And it's hitting the road.

One of our primary goals was to give the students the opportunity to put on a show at a new venue. After two weekends of performances at the Performing Arts Center at SCC, we'll transfer Ida to a beautiful historic building in downtown Phoenix for the final weekend of October. The students are learning how to equip this raw space with everything it needs to become a functioning theatre–rare and valuable practical experience for college students.

Why do we need you?

A project like this takes a lot of resources. It's a bigger undertaking than the productions both Orange Theatre and SCC usually mount. We are employing a team of five professional artists who are mentoring and working alongside a cast and crew of 20+ students. A five-person band is writing and rehearsing original songs. We're equipping the venue downtown with lighting, sound, and video equipment. In addition, the whole production will be submitted to the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival, where it will be judged alongside productions from across the region and the nation.

And we're doing all this in a community college setting, which makes this unique learning experience accessible to students from diverse socio-economic backgrounds.

We've been honored to receive support from SCC and a grant from the Arizona Commission on the Arts to make this project happen, but these sources alone don't cover all the expenses. Your contribution will help us make this show the best it can be and, most importantly, provide an extraordinary learning experience for two dozen young artists.

Your donations will support the following important components of this project:

  • a padded stage floor, safe for movement and dance
  • video equipment
  • props
  • costumes
  • touring expenses

To thank you for your contributions, we've created several great perks... Donating to this campaign is the only way to get a guaranteed front-row seat to Ida, so don't wait!

Other ways you can help:

If you can't afford to donate right now, that's ok. Please share this campaign with friends and family, and make sure to come see the show. 

 


Orange Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)(3) public charity. Contributions for the purposes of Orange Theatre Group are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Short Summary

  •       This isn't your ordinary dance video. Most dance companies center their videos around popular songs and flashy moves. But at Reaction Dance Company NYC, we've decided to create art for a higher purpose: a cause.
  •      Through the stories of 3 couples, we will show how the major issues of the day "Black Lives Matter", Anti- Muslim sentiments and LGBT movement effects their relationships.These stories more importantly will show why our society should value love over hate. This video will be taped short film style with interlayed images, acting bits, and dance sequences.
  •       We hope to create not just one video, but a series. Our video, and hopefully videos, will go beyond just online publication and make their way to live events/discussions. Help us stop bigotry in America, by contributing to our cause.

What We Need & What You Get

  •          Making videos can be really expensive. We need space to rehearse in which in New York can start at $20 and go as high as $80 an hour. Our videographer needs transportation money to scout locations and pay for his filming and editing. Not to mention, we'd like to pay for our seven dancers who are forgoing paying gigs on the weekends to instead dedicate their time to a film that they believe in. Lastly, if we want to create a series we need a small nest egg to start up rehearsals and castings.
  •         Contributions of all giving levels are worth it.  Just a $25 donation can give us one hour worth of rehearsal time. In return you'll receive a downloadable version of our blooper reel, an autographed post card with the picture of the cast, and a shout out on social media. We have other great rewards like a personalized dance birthday video to your favorite song at the $150 level and even a possibility of being an extra in our next video. 
  •         Even if we don't reach our entire goal. The money will go to all the basic costs of getting this video done like rehearsal space, transportation, and any money needed for costumes or shooting locations. 

The Impact

  •    We don't want to just stop at one video. We want to show this at live events throughout NYC with discussions afterward. This will help the public understand the plight of the marginalized, create jobs for artists, and hopefully create a series with your help. 
  •     If anyone is going to make this successful its us.  When our dance group first started, just three friends dancing in a back yard, we won two awards from Pace University for fusing styles together and for dance group idea. In our first year as a dance company we performed 23 times. We make our ideas reality.

Risks & Challenges

  •   Honestly, we've already encountered our biggest challenge starting to film and having it not work out the first day. But that day only proved how dedicated the whole cast and crew were to the project. No one wanted to leave when our locations didn't work out, either because of weather or being kicked out of an apartment.  Everyone pulled together and made the best out of our time together by shooting promotional photos instead. We've realized we needed more time to make this project work which will only make a better quality video instead. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help can also be in the form of spreading the word. Tell your friends, your family, co-workers, groups you are part of, and anyone else you can think of. Share on as many social media outlets as you can fb, twitter, and email. If you are old fashioned tell them in person or over the phone. 
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who is Joy?

Over a year ago an idea came to me. First, it was the title "The Other Side of Joy". I knew that I had a story I wanted to share with the world. A country girl who grew up in South Carolina that embarked on a journey in the entertainment world. My life has not been all glitz and glam and I found myself really asking the question, "Who is Joy?" As much as this is my story I believe parts of my story is everybody story. Joy is everywhere! To experience JOY we must go through pain and there is always the other side of things. I want people to leave my show with an experience. To take one thing whether it be a story I tell, a joke, or a song I sing. You leave feeling full and with a better understanding of who I am. At the end of the day, we are all the same. Dealing with life which includes insecurities, love, loss, and learning how to pick up the pieces. When you leave my show I want others to be able to pick up a piece of their own life based on the experience they just witness by embarking on the other side with me. 

When you contribute to my campaign you will be helping me honor myself. While motivating all women that we are all living out our one-woman show daily. 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • $8,000 is needed to bring my production to life. This amount helps me pay for my theater, marketing, writing coach, and director. Including in this price my contributors are helping me pay for my mentorship program, "She Takes the Stage" that I am a part of with Christina Dunbar. You can check out the program at www.christinadunbar.com 
  • When you donate you will receive perks that include journals, group business calls, VIP tickets and dinner, and one on one live chat with me where you can ask anything. 
  • If I do not reach my goal any money I have collected will be put toward the production and marketing. 

The world needs more Joy!!! 

"The word that I would like to eradicate is unspeakable. I think that everything should be spoken. I think everybody testimony should be spoken. I think everybody shame should be spoken".   Viola Davis 

Risks & Challenges

There are many challenges when creating your own body of work. We could minimize the risk when people contribute to the vision. With ten years invested in my career that includes; modeling, acting, tv commercials, this experience provides me with the insight and knowledge of what it takes to create an offer something influential and inspirational. 

Some people are not in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can't help.

  • I am asking everyone to spread the word about "The Other Side Of Joy" tell a friend, share on your social media and please use the Indiegogo share tools!

"In this life I want to live in the most stunning way, again, and again, and again!

                                                                                                                   Joy McElveen
story_txt:
Who is Joy?
Over a year ago an idea came to me. First, it was the title "The Other Side of Joy". I knew that I had a story I wanted to share with the world. A country girl who grew up in South Carolina that embarked on a journey in the entertainment world. My life has not been all glitz and glam and I found myself really asking the question, "Who is Joy?" As much as this is my story I believe parts of my story is everybody story. Joy is everywhere! To experience JOY we must go through pain and there is always the other side of things. I want people to leave my show with an experience. To take one thing whether it be a story I tell, a joke, or a song I sing. You leave feeling full and with a better understanding of who I am. At the end of the day, we are all the same. Dealing with life which includes insecurities, love, loss, and learning how to pick up the pieces. When you leave my show I want others to be able to pick up a piece of their own life based on the experience they just witness by embarking on the other side with me. 
When you contribute to my campaign you will be helping me honor myself. While motivating all women that we are all living out our one-woman show daily. 

What We Need & What You Get
 

$8,000 is needed to bring my production to life. This amount helps me pay for my theater, marketing, writing coach, and director. Including in this price my contributors are helping me pay for my mentorship program, "She Takes the Stage" that I am a part of with Christina Dunbar. You can check out the program at www.christinadunbar.com 
When you donate you will receive perks that include journals, group business calls, VIP tickets and dinner, and one on one live chat with me where you can ask anything. 
If I do not reach my goal any money I have collected will be put toward the production and marketing. 


The world needs more Joy!!! 
"The word that I would like to eradicate is unspeakable. I think that everything should be spoken. I think everybody testimony should be spoken. I think everybody shame should be spoken".   Viola Davis 

Risks & Challenges
There are many challenges when creating your own body of work. We could minimize the risk when people contribute to the vision. With ten years invested in my career that includes; modeling, acting, tv commercials, this experience provides me with the insight and knowledge of what it takes to create an offer something influential and inspirational. 

Some people are not in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can't help.
I am asking everyone to spread the word about "The Other Side Of Joy" tell a friend, share on your social media and please use the Indiegogo share tools!
"In this life I want to live in the most stunning way, again, and again, and again!                                                                                                                   Joy McElveen

story:
Short Summary

  • Actors Shakespeare Company is in its 17th season, and its second year in Elizabeth, NJ. We are rebuilding and reconnecting with our donor base, audience members and company supporters.
  • A Christmas Carol is our first full production of the season and a family favorite.
  • Funding will bring 100 middle and high school students and dozens of families to our short run of 4 performances, December 1-4.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funds go toward creating and sharing the performance: lights, costumes, props, music, actor salary, advertising, and subsidizing school and community group ticket discounts. 
  • Bring A Christmas Carol into your home and your community with a company mug or a free performance.
  • If we do not reach our goal, funds will be redirected to subsidize student tickets for our spring 2017 projects: a Hamlet variation and a five person Romeo and Juliet.

The Impact

  • Elizabeth, NJ is a quickly growing community, with a focus on creating events and programs for its citizens.  A Christmas Carol contributes to that goal by providing an annual family event for all ages, backgrounds and faiths.
  • Our 2015 production was well received, with more public school students planning to attend this year as part of their in-school programming.
  • ASC has a nearly two decade record of reaching hundreds of students and families every year, regardless of our performance location, through events and school programs.  This project was created with them in mind.

Risks & Challenges

  • Elizabeth, NJ is our new home and we are still building connections with the community, after moving to Snyder Academy in the summer of 2015.
  • We are working with Snyder Academy, our company supporters, and the community of Elizabeth to advertise this program and provide ticket incentives.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this campaign via email and Indiegogo's share tools for social media.
  • Come see the show and bring your friends and family.  Tickets available here. 

Thank you for your support - your contribution goes further than you realize!

story:
ABOUT LA FIN

“It often happened to me as a child that I wanted to kill myself to annoy other people.”

In this original dark comedy theatre production, LA FIN, Sarah Bernhardt  (1844-1923), the "great" French actress (who really slept in a coffin every night), realizes she has just one hour of her life left. She must now find the ultimate theatrical death. In order to find it, she begins to dramatically and humorously reenact the details of her stage deaths and her many true-life- attention-seeking-«attempted »-suicides, from her childhood charades to garner her mother’s attention to the longest gaudy detailed dying sequences in performance one could ever imagine. Through all her "deaths," she shows her love of life.

All the while, people visit her "deathbed." Her mother, her son, her manager, an anxious lover. Through each depiction of death, she inevitably portrays snippets of her frenetic love affairs, collision with anti-semitism, provocation of audiences and critics, painful domestic truths, humiliation tactics and hunger for the ultimate performance. 

As the performance waivers between the surreal and the historical fact, one can find a little window into the essence of the Divine Sarah. The great actress. The great PR agent. The great French Dier. The great freak-type that has ceased to exist in our icons today.


 

WHO WE ARE 


Creator and Performer / Rebecca Karpovsky

Rebecca Karpovsky is a NYC based actor, producer, and writer. Along with her work as an actor in film and theatre, Rebecca has been an active producer in both worlds as well. Her feature film, PINSKY, which she, co-wrote, produced and starred in premiered at the Moscow International Film Festival, won "Best Narrative Feature" at the Santa Fe Independent Film Festival, and is now distributed by Breaking Glass Productions. La Fin all started over three years ago when Rebecca was working with teacher/director Wynn Handman. After working through Sarah's letters one line struck hard:  "I am just as unsatisfied the morning after, as I am the night before." And from  then on it was full swing ahead for Rebecca and the team...


Co-Producer / Adrien Le Ray

Adrien Le Ray was trained as an actor in the School "Pierre Barayre" in Paris. He co-created and acted in the Musical "Les Franglaises" that has been performed over 800 times in France, Switzerland, England and Canada, and received the 2015 Molière Award (French equivalent of the Tony) for best musical. More recently, he appeared in  Oscar Winner director Claude Lelouch's "La Vertu de l’ Impondérable", (released summer 2019). He also wrote, directed and appeared in several music videos of famous French YouTuber PVNOVA. 


Director / Gera Sandler

Gera is a stage director, actor,  TV and Radio personality. He graduated from the School of Performing Arts "Beit Zvi" in 1997, receiving six prestigious awards. Sandler played in the Gesher Theatre in "Don Juan" by Moliere. For the past twelve years, Sandler has been one of the leading actors in the Yiddish Theatre in Israel and the US As a stage director, he directed 7 productions, among them 4 operas including Don Pasquale by Donizetti in Jerusalem Chamber Opera. Sandler also hosted three TV shows on Israel’s Channel 9. Sandler's film credits include "Jellyfish" (winner of three awards at Cannes Film Festival, including the "Golden Camera" award), "Stones", "Dance Mom" (winner of first prize at the all-Israeli short film competition "Volgin"), "Children of the USSR" and over thirty other movies and series in Israel.


Movement Style Director / Janice Orlandi

A movement specialist in period styles, historic dance, psychophysical techniques, character transformation and physical dramaturgy. Trained and co-taught with Loyd Williamson and Richard Schechner. Recent directing credits include: Bette Davis Ain’t for Sissies (Five Stars at Edinburgh Fringe Festival, St. James Studio London; Theater Row, Laurie Beechman, 59E59), Garbo Dreams (Red Room NYC). Movement Director: The Contrast (Mirror Repertory Company St Clements), An Ideal Husband and Tartuffe (Sonnet Repertory NYC). A certified teacher of Michael Chekhov and Williamson Technique. Period style specialist of Elizabethan and Restoration, Baroque, Regency, Victorian, Edwardian, 1920’s-1970’s. Artistic director at Actors Movement Studio NYC, faculty at TISCH School of the Arts, Atlantic Theater Company, Tom Todoroff Conservatory, University of the Arts Philadelphia, Rutgers University, New York Conservatory for Dramatic Arts. Her work as an educator, director, actress and movement coach has been seen at Williamstown Theater Festival, State Theater School Denmark, Lindenberg Center for Culture Netherlands, Princeton Repertory Shakespeare Festival, Classic Stage Company, Circle Rep Lab. Founding Member of Shakespeare in the Parking Lot. 


Costume Designer / Irina Kruzhilina

Irina Kruzhilina is a New York-based costume designer and visual dramaturg for the performing arts. Her work has been shown all over the world, from Tokyo Disney to Times Square, from Brooklyn Academy of Music to the National Theatre in Prague, and from Avery Fisher Hall to the Barbican Center in London. Ms. Kruzhilina designed costumes for dozens of theatre, dance, opera, puppetry, and performing arts installations. She has collaborated with acclaimed directors and companies such as Doug Fitch, Lars Jan, Geoff Sobelle, Mabou Mines, David Chambers, Ruth Margraff, Else-Marie Lauvik, DNA works and SCRAP performance group. Recent productions include the under water performance installation ‘Holoscenes’ for Early Morning Opera at Times Square and Miami Art Basel, and 'Orphic Moments' at the Salzburg Landestheater. For Disney she created costumes for the nighttime spectacular 'Rivers Of Light’ at the Disney Animal Kingdom and the parade 'Dreaming Up!' for the 35th anniversary of Tokyo Disney. Ongoing projects include: Cherry Orchard (directed by Dmitry Krymov), Boney Manilli (directed by Edgar Arceneaux), Fantasticks (directed by David Levi) and Love for Three Oranges (directed by Rob Melrose). In addition to her design work Irina serves as a visual dramaturg helping directors, designers and performers to create unique visual narratives for performances. A native of Moscow, Russia, Ms. Kruzhilina is dedicated to connecting Western and Eastern European theatre through international collaborations. 


Production Designer / Sarah Leriche

Sarah Leriche graduated from the New York Film Academy with a degree in cinematography. Since graduating, she has worked on several feature films and theatre projects with light design and camera. She recently produced and developed an immersive theatre project called Cosmos in Hibernation 

 

Sound Designer - Composer / Simon Brown

Born in Ithaca, New York, and raised in New York City and Western Massachusetts, Simon Brown studied at Westfield State University with Andrew Bonacci, and at Brooklyn College with Douglas Geers and Morton Subotnick. He lives in Brooklyn, New York, and works as a teaching artist and conductor at the Youth Orchestra of Saint Luke’s. simonmbrown.com


Stage Manager / Julia Parnas

It all started when Julia Parnas was asked to fill in as a stage manager for a friend and did it on a whim. She fell in love with it, discovering a new talent. Having worked on a few projects, that include Through the curves, Schema, and The onlooker’s trail, she finds herself lost to the world of theater, taking on more exciting and challenging projects, such as La Fin. 

Poster Design / Natasha Shendrik 

Work in Progress

 

What We Need

While we raised some of the funds from our incredible Masquerade Ball and Fundraiser, we still need a bit over half the production cost. We need funds for :

Set Design/Supplies: $1800

Rehearsal/Venue Rental: $1700

Costume Design/Builder/Materials: $1600

Sound Design/Equipment: $1200 

*** Everything is made from scratch! Including a portable coffin. 

Rehearsal

 

What You Get

Some perks include...

- A virtual written "Merci" in the The Sarah Bernhardt Project Facebook page

-A personalized perfumed "Merci" letter in the mail  from Sarah Bernhardt 

- Tickets to the Premiere on June 13th.

- Executive Producer Credit on La Fin

 

The Impact

At a time of uniformity in creation and in society we need to meet unique exceptional characters that inspire us to be and act differently. To be truly ourselves. Sarah Bernahrdt was not only an important figure of her time but she also speaks to us today. What it means to be yourself. A freak. A vivid and the beautiful freak. Once the project is performed in NYC it will travel around the world from professional stages to academic ones and eventually performed by a multitude of actresses in different languages. The entire world knew who Sarah Bernhardt was in 1873. Imagine being THAT good of a PR agent with no Twitter, no radio, and no cellphones! We are bringing her back for the 21rst century. The world could use a reminder about this unique being in order to take powerful risks of their own. 

 

Risks & Challenges

This is an entirely self-produced project that has an indefinite life span. Every team member has joined becuase of their belief in the project. The production team that has come together for this project, came together because of the premise of the project itself and the story being told, knowing it's a very tight budget.  None of the team members came on board to turn a profit.  Working with low budget and time contraints means everyone's in it from the heart. Without having an institution backing us, we don't have the luxury of built in rehearsal spaces and facilities or time. With this campgain and fundraiser, we will be able to rent more space and cover personal funds that go into this project. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

-Share this Indiegogo campaign to friends, family, or theatre lovers

-Spread the word about the play and the project overall! 

-Attend the play itself!

-Read about the project: Thesarahbernhardtproject.com and share information from there. 

-Like the The Sarah Bernhardt Project Facebook page

-Follow the Project on instragram @thesarahbernhardtproject

story:
mother daughter sisterwife

Hi, friends! I'm Lauren and I'm an interdisciplinary theatre artist living and working in Brooklyn, NY. If you know me, you know the venn diagram of my greatest interests looks something like this: 

And I've finally decided to do something about it. 

Using Glossolalia (a collection of poems written by Canadian poet Marita Dachsel from the imagined perspectives of Joseph Smith’s thirty-four polygamous wives) as a source text, I’m investigating the practice of plural marriage as an act of object theatre. I'm calling the project mother daughter sisterwife, and it will premiere as a work in progress in St. Ann's LABAPALOOZA! this June. 

"here I feel 

      like a patriarch"

Since November, I've been working to excavate the stories of Mormon pioneer women with my friends and collaborators, Anna Szapiro, Hannah Record, and Allison Altman. 

Now, our many-wived house on the prairie needs your help.

Current experiments include but are by no means limited to: bird songs, taxidermy as puppetry, extinguishing invisible fires, dead baby gardens, and speed braid competitions. 

Your contribution will help to pay for: 

  • Rehearsal space. On average, studios in the city cost $35/hr, or, roughly $5 more than a ticket to the festival.   
  • Props, costumes, and set. (Did we mention taxidermy as puppetry? Plus tall grass, a shot gun, that dead baby garden, and of course, matching prairie dresses.) 
  • Equipment rental fees

“There are many versions of the story, 

& you should be wise enough to know

that truth is filtered through tongues.” 

 

This project marks my first formal presentation of work in New York City, and it's no small task to produce a piece of live performance. On behalf of my sisters, we so appreciate your time, consideration, and contribution toward the goal of realizing our vision. 

With endless gratitude, 

L, A, H, &A

 

Photos, from top: Hannah Record and Anna Szapiro by Teddy Wolff; Caity Rautenstrauch by Lauren Tuvell.

story:
What is Breaking Surface?

Breaking Surface tells the story of a Man’s search for inspiration, through a curious relationship with his unseen Muse.  He follows her into the pages of his notebook and on a watery adventure, coming face to face with his own limitations.  Told through dance, acrobatics and airy imagery the audience is led into a world where gravity is overthrown and pages leap from a notebook.  As our hero sinks deeper and deeper into this whimsical world, it transforms around him.  The chair that once anchored him pulls him from the ground and the pages of his book flicker and drift away, to be reborn as a fleet of miniature paper boats. The tiny boats merge into a single vessel that sales on to adventure bringing him back to where he began, but changed. 

Throughout the tale, the exploration of movement is deeply linked with the idea that man's imagination cannot be physically explained on the ground. It peeks into a playful world of childhood fantasy, where human bodies defy gravitational laws. Water sounds accent instrumental music by Trevor Exter, John Morgan Kimock and John E Oyzon.  Originally presented by AiRealistic at the Theater for the New City in 2013, this production is produced by 5th Wall Studio. 

 

How It All Started

This show is born out of a passion for flight and a love of live theater.  Both creators, Gwyneth Larsen and William Mulholland, adore silent theater and the brilliance of a simple theatrical game.  So, they started to play. As they played, they talked about their relationship with inspiration- how sometimes it's so seamless it's just there. It feels almost as if it's channeling to you from another world, and how sometimes no matter how hard you try, you cannot hear the voice of your muse. 

This is their story. It starts where two worlds meet; in the tension of a point of contact just before it is made. In the space between lips before they touch, or the inhale before a story begins. The moment just before you step into the unknown. Once you lift your foot, you’re on the journey. Even if you turn to go back, something’s already happened, you are changed. The first step is magic, the surface has been broken and you are immersed.

 

"We rise by lifting others."

This production is a roots to bones passion project.  It's born out of our love of flight, but it has become so much more. Each performance will have only 36 seats and will incorporate water, our style of flying, acrobatic dance, puppetry and beautiful performers.

We have an incredible cast, crew and production team that are working night and day to help us bring this show to you, but as you can imagine creating independent theater in NYC is costly! Can you help us reach our fundraising goal of $15,000?

If you choose to give to us, we thank you in advance for believing in theater as an essential part of life and helping bring this vision to life.

 

Where has Breaking Surface been?

Brooklyn Lyceum - New York, 2011. 

Theater for New City - New York, 2013 - presented by AiRealistic, Breaking Surface premiered to rave reviews and a sold out run. It was performed by Gwyneth Larsen, Aiden O’Shea, and an ensemble of five performers. 

 

The Creative Team Behind BREAKING SURFACE

Gwyneth Larsen (Co-Creator/Director) - is a director, choreographer, performer and passionate collaborator. She began her career with the internationally acclaimed folk music & dance company The Vanaver Caravan & went on to work with De La Guarda, Fuerza Bruta, Cirque Du Soleil Special Events, Bregenz Opera, The Metropolitan Opera and in the stunt industry for numerous productions including: Law and Order SVU, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, The Americans, and as Madonna and Megan Fox’s stunt doubles among others. She was also a founding member of AiRealistic and co-founder of 5th Wall Studio. She graduated from Sarah Lawrence College with a focus in Greek mythology, modern dance and photography. Her parents, mythologists Drs Stephen & Robin Larsen nurtured in her a profound love of story and myth and a deep respect for nature. In Breaking Surface, she is thrilled to be integrating these foundational beliefs with her physical passions and the mystical world of her youth.

William Mulholland (Co-Creator/Director) - is also the founder of Bridge Acrobatics, & co-founder of AiRealistic and 5th Wall Studio. He has performed at The Metropolitan Opera in multiple productions. Other credits include: De La Guarda, Fuerza Bruta, Cirque Du Soleil, Pilobolus & the Hollywood Stunt industry. He trained as a gymnast at the Olympic Training Center & became a member of the US National Team, an All-American & team captain at the University of Nebraska, where he studied advertising, marketing & dabbled in theater & dance. He has had the honor of working with a broad variety of high-level gymnasts, circus performers & dancers. In helping these artists blend & expand their skill sets he developed a class series to meld a range of diverse physical techniques & give meaning to the ‘tricks’ done in contemporary movement. Over the years, Bill has cultivated storytelling through physical expression in many arenas, culminating with Breaking Surface. This show combines theater / dance-acrobatics & flying to create a new voice; one that blends childhood dreams of superpowers with the ability to define ones own reality through deep imagining.

Trevor Exter (Composer/Musician) - has been a professional singer and cellist with his own approach to all aspects of composing, songwriting, producing, performing and touring. He has a couple of bands where he gets to make a spectacle of himself, and some producers like to use him as a secret weapon.  He also plays Fender bass. He has released music under his own name and also as part of XVSK with drummer John Kimock.

John Morgan Kimock (Composer/Musician) - is a sought-after drummer, composer and arranger from Sonoma County, California living in Brooklyn NY.  His musical collaborations have taken him around the world with a wide range of acts, starting at the age of 5 when John began making bizarre appearances with the likes of tuvan throat singers, Todd Rundgren or with his father Steve's outfit Zero. From 2011-2014 John performed/produced in a two-piece band with Trevor Exter called XVSK.  XVSK was largely an experimental folk band with improvisational elements and occasional guests like Bernie Worrell (Talking Heads, P-Funk) Todd Reynolds (Steve Reich, Meredith Monk), and Dana Colley (Morphine).  They released a full-length album in 2014.

John E Oyzon (Composer/Musician) - has been a student of Tibetan Buddhism since 1999 and was a professional singer and dancer in New York City, both on and off Broadway, for more than a decade. He graduated from the University at Buffalo with a dual degree in dance choreography and stage acting. His movement style is informed by modern dance, physical theater, Tai Chi, West African, modern dance, Capoeira, house and ecstatic dance styles, but he is most moved by sincerity. He is currently residing in Phoenix, Arizona, where he facilitates dance workshops, plays music for yogis and kirtans, and teaches music to children.

 

Spread the Word

Please help us go viral with this campaign by spreading the word about this groundbreaking aerial dance theater production via email, Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and good ol' word of mouth. Post this campaign on your social media sites. Email a campaign link to your friends!  

Meeting our goal:  THAT'S GREAT! Breaking Surface will be produced and returning to NYC!

Exceeding our goal:  AMAZING! Breaking Surface will have an even more outstanding production with higher quality design in sets, lights and costumes. 

Doubling our goal:  HOW EXCITING! Breaking Surface will have increased marketing resources to spread the word on this great show! 

 

Things You Should Know

  •  Please read the rewards carefully to determine those that are location or date specific, or subject to limited quantities. Specific event information will be posted on www.breakingsurface.org and you will contacted personally via email. We will try to accommodate any date/time to fit individual schedules.

  • Travel, lodging and transportation are not included in any reward.

  • Must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent/legal guardian to attend all events.

  • Some rewards may require that you (and your guest, if applicable) sign a non-disclosure agreement upon your arrival.

 

Thank you for being a part of
story_txt:
What is Breaking Surface?
Breaking Surface tells the story of a Man’s search for inspiration, through a curious relationship with his unseen Muse.  He follows her into the pages of his notebook and on a watery adventure, coming face to face with his own limitations.  Told through dance, acrobatics and airy imagery the audience is led into a world where gravity is overthrown and pages leap from a notebook.  As our hero sinks deeper and deeper into this whimsical world, it transforms around him.  The chair that once anchored him pulls him from the ground and the pages of his book flicker and drift away, to be reborn as a fleet of miniature paper boats. The tiny boats merge into a single vessel that sales on to adventure bringing him back to where he began, but changed. 
Throughout the tale, the exploration of movement is deeply linked with the idea that man's imagination cannot be physically explained on the ground. It peeks into a playful world of childhood fantasy, where human bodies defy gravitational laws. Water sounds accent instrumental music by Trevor Exter, John Morgan Kimock and John E Oyzon.  Originally presented by AiRealistic at the Theater for the New City in 2013, this production is produced by 5th Wall Studio.

story:
Taller Nacional de Comparsa Teatral. Nuestra historia.

Our History.

Zoila Sotomayor, miembro de nuestra Comparsa, expresó para el periódico El Heraldo de la ciudad de Barranquilla, algunos detalles del devenir histórico del Taller Nacional de Comparsa Teatral. Aquí va:

Una de las iniciativas que desde hace 12 años tiene lugar en medio de las carnestolendas de Barranquilla, y que se centra en las posibilidades expresivas del teatro, es el Taller Nacional de Comparsa Teatral del colectivo La Tropa de Melquíades, proyecto que surgió a partir del interés de un grupo de actores y directores escénicos por aprovechar el multitudinario escenario del carnaval para dar rienda suelta a la creatividad.

Es así como a partir del 2006, cada año, dos semanas antes del inicio del carnaval, empiezan a reunirse en la ciudad músicos, pintores, bailarines, actores y directores escénicos de distintos grupos de teatro de Barranquilla y el Atlántico, y de diversas ciudades del país, así como artistas internacionales especialmente invitados a hacer parte del taller, para construir personajes, armar escenografías y vestuarios, crear dramaturgias y bandas sonoras y lograr, en muy pocos días, la puesta en escena de una comparsa en la que desfila la magia del teatro para sorprender a los espectadores, y devolverles, convertida en poesía, la sutileza de una idea o emoción, o el reflejo de la abrumadora realidad.

En estos 10 años La tropa de Melquíades ha abordado distintos temas en sus comparsas. En 2006, puso en escena “Crisálidas”, una bandada de mariposas amarillas como canto a la vida; en el 2007, con “Migraciones”, se abordó el tema de las culturas en movimiento; en 2008 y 2009, “Con los ojos del corazón”, la comparsa dio vida a los personajes de El Principito, de Antoine Saint Exupéry. En el 2010, con “Memoria i-lustrada” los artistas plasmaron su visión acerca del Bicentenario de la República y los 10 años del asesinato de Jaime Garzón. En 2011, “El sueño de Abyayala” fue un homenaje a la tierra; en 2012, “Soñar para la tierra” escenificó la fuerza de la naturaleza. En 2013, con motivo de la celebración de los 200 años de Barranquilla, se puso en escena “Vacanquilla, paso de errantes”; en 2014, los artistas trabajaron el tema del desplazamiento con la comparsa “Errantes”. Y en 2015 y 2016 con motivo del fallecimiento del escritor Gabriel García Márquez, la tropa desfiló con la comparsa “Gabo Eterno”, que permitió volver a ver, gracias a la magia del teatro, a los principales personajes de la obra de nuestro Nobel de Literatura, comandados por un Melquíades alucinante y su grupo de alegres gitanos.

Texto completo: http://revistas.elheraldo.co/latitud/la-tropa-d...

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Zoila Sotomayor, member of our "Comparsa", expressed for the newspaper El Heraldo of  Barranquilla, some details of the historical evolution of the National Workshop of Theatrical "Comparsa". Here it goes:

One of the initiatives that has been taking place for 12 years in the midst of Barranquilla's carnival, and that focuses on the expressive possibilities of the theater, is the National Workshop of Theatrical Comparsa of "La Tropa de Melquiades" collective, a project that emerged from the interest of a group of actors and stage directors to take advantage of the multitudinous carnival stage to unleash creativity.

This is how, starting in 2006, every year, two weeks before the start of the carnival, musicians, painters, dancers, actors and stage directors from different theater groups from Barranquilla and the departament of Atlántico, and from different cities of the country, as well as international artists specially invited to take part in the workshop, begin to gather in this city to build characters, create sets and costumes, create dramaturgies and soundtracks and achieve, in a few days, the staging of a parade in which the magic  of the theater is use to surprise the spectators, and return them, converted into poetry, the subtlety of an idea or emotion, or the reflection of the overwhelming reality.

In these 12 years "La tropa de Melquiades" has addressed different issues in their comparsas. In 2006, he staged "Crisálidas", a flock of yellow butterflies as a song to life; in 2007, with "Migrations", the theme of cultures in movement was addressed; In 2008 and 2009, "With the eyes of the heart", the comparsa gave life to the characters of The Little Prince, by Antoine Saint Exupéry. In 2010, with "Memoria i-lustrada" the artists captured their vision about the Bicentennial of the Republic and the 10 years of the murder of Jaime Garzón. In 2011, "The Dream of Abyayala" was a tribute to the earth; in 2012, "Dream for the Earth" staged the force of nature. In 2013, on the occasion of the celebration of the 200th anniversary of Barranquilla, "Vacanquilla, paso de errantes" was staged; in 2014, the artists worked on the subject of the displacement with the comparsa "Errantes". And in 2015 and 2016, on the occasion of the death of the writer Gabriel García Márquez, the troop paraded with the comparsa "Gabo Eterno", a tribute that will allowed to see again, thanks to the magic of the theater, the main characters of the work of our Literature Nobel, commanded by an amazing Melquiades and his group of cheerful gypsies.

Full text: http://revistas.elheraldo.co/latitud/la-tropa-d...

La comparsa teatral. De hombres y pájaros.

Theatrical comparsa. Of Men and Birds.

Esta comparsa es el producto del laboratorio de creación "Taller Nacional de Comparsa Teatral-La Tropa de Melquiades" que busca brindar un espacio de aprendizaje y creación colectiva de artistas de distintas disciplinas provenientes de diferentes partes de Colombia, y de países como Alemania, Bélgica, Estados Unidos, México, Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Francia, entre otros,  que se reúnen en Barranquilla, en el marco de uno de los carnavales más importantes del mundo, declarado Obra maestra del Patrimonio Oral e Inmaterial de la Humanidad, título otorgado por la UNESCO.

Este año nos reunimos en torno a una propuesta dramatúrgica que plantea una serie de interrogantes acerca de esa costumbre masculina (común en el Gran Caribe y otros países) de encerrar un pájaro para disfrutar de su canto.  Mediante la creación de personajes diversos (pajarero, hombres-pájaros, mujeres con jaulas abiertas, pájaros libres, el hombre que carga su propia jaula), acompañados de músicos que interpretan piezas originales, esta puesta en escena itinerante rompe el esquema tradicional de los grupos y disfraces que desfilan en el Carnaval de Barranquilla, para desplegar de forma poética y festiva el asunto de las nuevas masculinidades y temas como la libertad, el encierro, la fragilidad y la necesidad de capturar la belleza de la naturaleza a toda costa.

Entre los grupos que en el lapso de 12 años han formado parte del taller y de La Tropa de Melquíades están: Luneta 50, Camach, Arropilla.co, Espejo Cóncavo, Canto Río (Barranquilla), Telón de Palo (Cartagena), Casa Naranja y Teatro Teca (Cali); Títeres del Destino, Gota de Mercurio, Tercer Acto, Actogato, Il Viandante, Buena Onda Social Club y Summun Draco (Bogotá), Guakaribaná y Fundación Enlaces (Galapa), Ceminajayo y Sapo Pelele (Malambo), Kamama (Soledad), Los Ruiseñores del Pacífico (Buenaventura), Jayehechii (Riohacha), Jóvenes por Jóvenes (Arjona), Corporación Nuestra Gente y La Barra del Silencio (Medellín), la Compañía Escuela de Títeres del Atlántico, estudiantes de Arte Dramático de Uniatlántico y de Bellas Artes de Cartagena y del programa de Música de la Universidad Distrital de Bogotá, ASAB. Además, han participado los colectivos internacionales Stones River (Alemania), Pichotte Compagnie (Francia), Pequeño Teatro Durazno (Uruguay), Le fanfaroux (Bélgica), Enviados de la Gloria (Argentina), Rodará y Espejo Ilusión (México), y como artistas invitados especiales los colombianos Jorge Blandón, Lucía Garzón, Beatriz Camargo, Misael Torres, Néstor Lambulei y Rubén Darío Mejía.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

This comparsa is the product of the creation laboratory "National Workshop of theatrical Comparsa - La Tropa de Melquiades" that seeks to provide a learning space and a collective creation of artists from different disciplines, and from different parts of Colombia, and countries such as Germany, Belgium , United States, Mexico, Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, France, among others, that meet in Barranquilla, in the framework of one of the most important carnivals in the world, declared Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity, title granted by UNESCO.

This year we gathered around a dramaturgical proposal that raises a series of questions about that male habit (common in the Greater Caribbean and other countries) of enclosing a bird to enjoy its singing. Through the creation of diverse characters (bird-handler, bird-men, women with open cages, free birds, the man who carries his own cage), accompanied by musicians who perform original pieces, this itinerant staging breaks the traditional scheme of the groups and costumes that parade in the Carnival of Barranquilla, to unfold in a poetic and festive way the subject of new masculinities and themes such as freedom, confinement, fragility and the need to capture the beauty of nature at all costs.

Between the groups that in the lapse of 12 years have been part of the workshop and La Tropa de Melquiades are: Luneta 50, Camach, Arropilla.co, Espejo Cóncavo, Canto Río (Barranquilla), Telón de Palo (Cartagena), Casa Naranja and Teatro Teca (Cali); Títeres del Destino, Gota de Mercurio, tercer Acto, Actogato, Il Viandante, Buena Onda Social Club and Summun Draco (Bogotá), Guakaribaná and Fundación Enlaces (Galapa), Ceminajayo and Sapo Pelele (Malambo), Kamama (Soledad), Los Ruiseñores del Pacífico (Buenaventura), Jayehechii (Riohacha), Youth for Youth (Arjona), Corporación Nuestra Gente and La Barra del Silencio (Medellín), the School of Puppets of the Atlantic, students of Dramatic Art of Uniatlántico and of Fine Arts of Cartagena and the Music Program of the District University of Bogotá, ASAB. In addition, the international groups Stones River (Germany), Pichotte Compagnie (France), Little Durazno Theater (Uruguay), Le fanfaroux (Belgium), Enviados de la Gloria (Argentina), Rodará and Espejo Ilusión (Mexico), and as special guest artists have participated. Colombians Jorge Blandón, Lucía Garzón, Beatriz Camargo, Misael Torres, Néstor Lambulei and Rubén Darío Mejía.

 

APOYANDO ESTA PROPUESTA AYUDARÍAS A:

SUPPORTING THIS PROPOSAL YOU WOULD HELP TO:

 

Garantizar la presentación de la comparsa teatral "De hombres y pájaros" en el marco del Carnaval de Barranquilla, y de los carnavales de los municipios de Puerto Colombia, Palmar de Varela y Galapa. En desfiles populares, poco afectados por la mercantilización de la cultura, que requieren de ofertas atractivas y distintas para sorprender al público con la fuerza del teatro. 

---------------------------------------------------

Guarantee the presentation of the theater troupe "Of men and birds" in the framework of the Carnival of Barranquilla, and the carnivals of the municipalities of Puerto Colombia, Palmar de Varela and Galapa. In popular parades, little affected by the commodification of culture, which require attractive and different offers to surprise the public with the force of theater.

 

¿EN QUÉ SE INVERTIRÁN LOS RECURSOS?

WHAT WILL RESOURCES BE INVESTED IN?

$10.000 USD 

  • $3000 USD Para hospedaje y transportes de artistas. For lodging and transports of artists.
  • $2500 USD Diseño y elaboración de vestuarios y materiales. Design and elaboration of costumes and materials.
  • $3000 USD Alimentación e Hidratación. Feeding and Hydration.
  • $1500 USD Escenografía y estructuras. Scenography and structures.

En 2011, “El sueño de Abyayala” fue un homenaje a la tierra; en 2012, “Soñar para la tierra” escenificó la fuerza de la naturaleza. En 2013, con motivo de la celebración de los 200 años de Barranquilla, se puso en escena “Vacanquilla, paso de errantes”; en 2014, los artistas trabajaron el tema del desplazamiento con la comparsa “Errantes”. Y en 2015 y 2016 con motivo del fallecimiento del escritor Gabriel García Márquez, la tropa desfiló con la comparsa “Gabo Eterno”, que permitió volver a ver, gracias a la magia del teatro, a los principales personajes de la obra de nuestro Nobel de Literatura, comandados por un Melquíades alucinante y su grupo de alegres gitanos.Texto completo: http://revistas.elheraldo.co/latitud/la-tropa-d...-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Zoila Sotomayor, member of our "Comparsa", expressed for the newspaper El Heraldo of  Barranquilla, some details of the historical evolution of the National Workshop of Theatrical "Comparsa". Here it goes:One of the initiatives that has been taking place for 12 years in the midst of Barranquilla's carnival, and that focuses on the expressive possibilities of the theater, is the National Workshop of Theatrical Comparsa of "La Tropa de Melquiades" collective, a project that emerged from the interest of a group of actors and stage directors to take advantage of the multitudinous carnival stage to unleash creativity.This is how, starting in 2006, every year, two weeks before the start of the carnival, musicians, painters, dancers, actors and stage directors from different theater groups from Barranquilla and the departament of Atlántico, and from different cities of the country, as well as international artists specially invited to take part in the workshop, begin to gather in this city to build characters, create sets and costumes, create dramaturgies and soundtracks and achieve, in a few days, the staging of a parade in which the magic  of the theater is use to surprise the spectators, and return them, converted into poetry, the subtlety of an idea or emotion, or the reflection of the overwhelming reality.In these 12 years "La tropa de Melquiades" has addressed different issues in their comparsas. In 2006, he staged "Crisálidas", a flock of yellow butterflies as a song to life; in 2007, with "Migrations", the theme of cultures in movement was addressed; In 2008 and 2009, "With the eyes of the heart", the comparsa gave life to the characters of The Little Prince, by Antoine Saint Exupéry. In 2010, with "Memoria i-lustrada" the artists captured their vision about the Bicentennial of the Republic and the 10 years of the murder of Jaime Garzón. In 2011, "The Dream of Abyayala" was a tribute to the earth; in 2012, "Dream for the Earth" staged the force of nature. In 2013, on the occasion of the celebration of the 200th anniversary of Barranquilla, "Vacanquilla, paso de errantes" was staged; in 2014, the artists worked on the subject of the displacement with the comparsa "Errantes". And in 2015 and 2016, on the occasion of the death of the writer Gabriel García Márquez, the troop paraded with the comparsa "Gabo Eterno", a tribute that will allowed to see again, thanks to the magic of the theater, the main characters of the work of our Literature Nobel, commanded by an amazing Melquiades and his group of cheerful gypsies.Full text: http://revistas.elheraldo.co/latitud/la-tropa-d...La comparsa teatral. De hombres y pájaros.Theatrical comparsa. Of Men and Birds.Esta comparsa es el producto del laboratorio de creación "Taller Nacional de Comparsa Teatral-La Tropa de Melquiades" que busca brindar un espacio de aprendizaje y creación colectiva de artistas de distintas disciplinas provenientes de diferentes partes de Colombia, y de países como Alemania, Bélgica, Estados Unidos, México, Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Francia, entre otros,  que se reúnen en Barranquilla, en el marco de uno de los carnavales más importantes del mundo, declarado Obra maestra del Patrimonio Oral e Inmaterial de la Humanidad, título otorgado por la UNESCO.Este año nos reunimos en torno a una propuesta dramatúrgica que plantea una serie de interrogantes acerca de esa costumbre masculina (común en el Gran Caribe y otros países) de encerrar un pájaro para disfrutar de su canto.  Mediante la creación de personajes diversos (pajarero, hombres-pájaros, mujeres con jaulas abiertas, pájaros libres, el hombre que carga su propia jaula), acompañados de músicos que interpretan piezas originales, esta puesta en escena itinerante rompe el esquema tradicional de los grupos y disfraces que desfilan en el Carnaval de Barranquilla, para desplegar de forma poética y festiva el asunto de las nuevas masculinidades y temas como la libertad, el encierro, la fragilidad y la necesidad de capturar la belleza de la naturaleza a toda costa.Entre los grupos que en el lapso de 12 años han formado parte del taller y de La Tropa de Melquíades están: Luneta 50, Camach, Arropilla.co, Espejo Cóncavo, Canto Río (Barranquilla), Telón de Palo (Cartagena), Casa Naranja y Teatro Teca (Cali); Títeres del Destino, Gota de Mercurio, Tercer Acto, Actogato, Il Viandante, Buena Onda Social Club y Summun Draco (Bogotá), Guakaribaná y Fundación Enlaces (Galapa), Ceminajayo y Sapo Pelele (Malambo), Kamama (Soledad), Los Ruiseñores del Pacífico (Buenaventura), Jayehechii (Riohacha), Jóvenes por Jóvenes (Arjona), Corporación Nuestra Gente y La Barra del Silencio (Medellín), la Compañía Escuela de Títeres del Atlántico, estudiantes de Arte Dramático de Uniatlántico y de Bellas Artes de Cartagena y del programa de Música de la Universidad Distrital de Bogotá, ASAB. Además, han participado los colectivos internacionales Stones River (Alemania), Pichotte Compagnie (Francia), Pequeño Teatro Durazno (Uruguay), Le fanfaroux (Bélgica), Enviados de la Gloria (Argentina), Rodará y Espejo Ilusión (México), y como artistas invitados especiales los colombianos Jorge Blandón, Lucía Garzón, Beatriz Camargo, Misael Torres, Néstor Lambulei y Rubén Darío Mejía.----------------------------------------------------------------------This comparsa is the product of the creation laboratory "National Workshop of theatrical Comparsa - La Tropa de Melquiades" that seeks to provide a learning space and a collective creation of artists from different disciplines, and from different parts of Colombia, and countries such as Germany, Belgium , United States, Mexico, Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, France, among others, that meet in Barranquilla, in the framework of one of the most important carnivals in the world, declared Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity, title granted by UNESCO.This year we gathered around a dramaturgical proposal that raises a series of questions about that male habit (common in the Greater Caribbean and other countries) of enclosing a bird to enjoy its singing. Through the creation of diverse characters (bird-handler, bird-men, women with open cages, free birds, the man who carries his own cage), accompanied by musicians who perform original pieces, this itinerant staging breaks the traditional scheme of the groups and costumes that parade in the Carnival of Barranquilla, to unfold in a poetic and festive way the subject of new masculinities and themes such as freedom, confinement, fragility and the need to capture the beauty of nature at all costs.Between the groups that in the lapse of 12 years have been part of the workshop and La Tropa de Melquiades are: Luneta 50, Camach, Arropilla.co, Espejo Cóncavo, Canto Río (Barranquilla), Telón de Palo (Cartagena), Casa Naranja and Teatro Teca (Cali); Títeres del Destino, Gota de Mercurio, tercer Acto, Actogato, Il Viandante, Buena Onda Social Club and Summun Draco (Bogotá), Guakaribaná and Fundación Enlaces (Galapa), Ceminajayo and Sapo Pelele (Malambo), Kamama (Soledad), Los Ruiseñores del Pacífico (Buenaventura), Jayehechii (Riohacha), Youth for Youth (Arjona), Corporación Nuestra Gente and La Barra del Silencio (Medellín), the School of Puppets of the Atlantic, students of Dramatic Art of Uniatlántico and of Fine Arts of Cartagena and the Music Program of the District University of Bogotá, ASAB. In addition, the international groups Stones River (Germany), Pichotte Compagnie (France), Little Durazno Theater (Uruguay), Le fanfaroux (Belgium), Enviados de la Gloria (Argentina), Rodará and Espejo Ilusión (Mexico), and as special guest artists have participated. Colombians Jorge Blandón, Lucía Garzón, Beatriz Camargo, Misael Torres, Néstor Lambulei and Rubén Darío Mejía. APOYANDO ESTA PROPUESTA AYUDARÍAS A:SUPPORTING THIS PROPOSAL YOU WOULD HELP TO: Garantizar la presentación de la comparsa teatral "De hombres y pájaros" en el marco del Carnaval de Barranquilla, y de los carnavales de los municipios de Puerto Colombia, Palmar de Varela y Galapa. En desfiles populares, poco afectados por la mercantilización de la cultura, que requieren de ofertas atractivas y distintas para sorprender al público con la fuerza del teatro. ---------------------------------------------------Guarantee the presentation of the theater troupe "Of men and birds" in the framework of the Carnival of Barranquilla, and the carnivals of the municipalities of Puerto Colombia, Palmar de Varela and Galapa. In popular parades, little affected by the commodification of culture, which require attractive and different offers to surprise the public with the force of theater. ¿EN QUÉ SE INVERTIRÁN LOS RECURSOS?WHAT WILL RESOURCES BE INVESTED IN?$10.000 USD 
$3000 USD Para hospedaje y transportes de artistas. For lodging and transports of artists.
$2500 USD Diseño y elaboración de vestuarios y materiales. Design and elaboration of costumes and materials.
$3000 USD Alimentación e Hidratación. Feeding and Hydration.
$1500 USD Escenografía y estructuras. Scenography and structures.

story:
As a poet, playwright, and multidisciplinary artist, I have been working on Liriope for the past three years.  Water was the writing prompt I started with when I wrote the ten minute version of the piece, with the image of Narcissus staring at his reflection in a pool connected to a maze of underground rivers he's not aware of.  Liriope is now a full length piece with a focus on Narcissus' mother Liriope, who tends to those afflicted with the silencing disease.  This site-specific staging at Jasper Ridge will be the culmination of my work as artist in residence at Stanford University.

Turning Jasper Ridge into a stage for a play has been an exercise in imagination and 

This campaign will help keep Liriope accessible to students and others who otherwise would not be able to afford to see it, and compensate our artists at a level proportionate to their dedication.  The video produced by this campaign will be available to Jasper Ridge to further their work in education and research, and propel Liriope to its next phase at a different location in the country or in the world, as part of a larger artistic dialogue on nature and the climate. 

Music Lead: Chris Chafe

Performers: Ronja Ver, Katarina Eriksson, Nuria Bowart, et al.

Support us, and spread the word about this campaign!

story:
What is Goldfish?

It was my acting teacher, Ray Virta, during my last semester of school at AMDA NY that first recommended the play to me. Upon meeting me he immediately told me to check out this play, and I think that very same evening after class I ran to the Drama Book Shop in NYC to pick up a copy...

"A young man raises his father. Then he leaves home. He meets a young woman who undoes him. The young woman has her own story: a mother who is a force of nature. It's a play about legacy-how do we become who we are?-and it's about leaving home. We raise our children to leave us, to walk out into the world. But then they do." 

I instantly fell in love with the play.

Cut to last spring, we are rehearsing for the LA Collegiate Playwright Festival. A fellow cast member sees me reading my copy of my beloved "Goldfish", and she snatches it out of my hand. After reading a few scenes while I rehearsed onstage, she proclaimed, "I want to do this. We're doing this. When can we do it?" That crazy woman was my now co-star and co-producer, Jessica Abrams. After I convinced my other castmate, Damon Mckinnis to get onboard, it was decided--we had to do this play!

What we need to raise--

We're trying to raise $3,000. This is needed to cover all production costs including the rights to the play, the venue for five shows and a tech rehearsal, all crew and tech, our costumes and set, and the access to perform as part of the Los Angeles Fringe Festival this June.  

We're offering some perks for those of you who are willing to help us out : ) 

And don't forget if you're in the LA area this June to come see the play that YOU helped make possible!!!!

--your girl, Sami Henry
