story:
Who is Cygnet Theatre?

Cygnet Theatre is a new English-speaking Shakespeare troupe in Paris, founded by actors & friends from all over the world. Long story short: We came to Paris. We fell in love (some with the city, some with the locals). Cliché, right? Perhaps so, but we're here because this city has captured us (heart, soul, and wallet), and we couldn't let go of the dream of performing classical works in their native language. So here we are. 

Our team is currently made up of :

  • Emily Guernsey, Cygnet's secretary. American. BFA in Acting from Elon University, NC. Length of time in France: Nearly five years. Favorite Shakespearean play: The Tempest.
  • Audrey Mikondo, Director of communications. French. Studied with Cours Florent, and performed with Bouffes du Nord.  Length of time in France: whole life. Favorite Shakespearean play: Love's Labours Lost.
  • Charlotte Pleasants, the Treasurer. New Zealander. BA in theatre studies from Victoria University Wellington. Length of time in France: about four years. Favorite Shakespearean play:  The Winter's Tale.
  • Taylor Scott, Cygnet's President. Canadian. BFA in Acting from the University of British Columbia. Length of time in France: two years. Favorite Shakespearean play: Antony and Cleopatra.
  • Joshua Stretton, France-England liaison. British. Degree in theatre from Goldsmiths in London. Length of time in France: off and on over the last five years. Favorite Shakespearean play: Henry IV part 1. 

One thing has become clear to the five of us: Paris doesn't yet host the type of English companies we are seeking to be. We love the vibrant scene of scratch nights, poetry slams, theatre festivals, and solo productions. While these events are crucial to fulfilling our lives as inventive expats, they cannot sustain artists or set them on a viable career path. We are setting out to change all that. So, after months of late meetings, intercontinental skype sessions, and prefecture visits, we are declared as an association in France, and ready to move forward with the creative side of things.

Cygnet Theatre is meaningful to us because we've studied extensively for careers in performance. Once we established ourselves here in Paris it became critical for us to focus on building opportunities for professional creative expression.

Cygnet Theatre is meaningful to you as a community member because as a company we will be working to produce not only classics, but eventually new works from unheard voices. We will be engaging not only with audiences, but with students, through various workshops. We will be entertaining with a vision of accessibility — anyone who wants to see our shows or apply to work with us will have the opportunity to do so.

 

Do these things mean something to you? Then read on for more detail into who we are and what we do — or head over directly to our perks and figure out which donation is right for you!

 

 

How is Cygnet Theatre different?

Cygnet Theatre is sincerely committed to the advancement of artists and production personnel by way of exploration, interpretation, development, and production of Shakespeare’s works. Apprenticeships and assistantships with Cygnet Theatre are designed to foster an understanding of the production process, and to nurture interest and involvement in anglophone theatre. In addition to this, all artists who work with Cygnet theatre are paid. As artists, we know all too well that a pizza for a day's work might help curb the hunger for a day or two, but doesn't satisfy the thirst for sincere respect and compensation for the work one has been trained to do. 

 

Why Shakespeare?

In short, Shakespeare’s works are universal. They are the story of the Everyman, the everyone. They are stories of love, of loss, of jealousy, of shame, of hubris… they are relatable. They are malleable. They can be told time and time again, and the characters’ journeys can be different every time. Shakespeare coined many words and phrases in the English language that we us on the daily, he is an intrinsic part of both theatrical and English history. This is why we keep telling his stories, and this is why we want the Bard to have a home in Paris.

 

Where does your Donation go?

Your contribution to Cygnet Theatre will help us build a company that encourages respect and compensation of local theatre artists. It will also help in the creation of a professional international and classical theatre scene in Paris. Take a peek at our perks listed on the side bar. We appreciate every penny, and will be sure to show you our gratitude, be it with words, tickets, or names in programs. 

Our overall costs for the season total 20,000 euros. From you, we are asking for 2,500 euros. This will cover the production costs of Twelfth Night, our first show of the season. We are furiously hosting fundraisers and applying for grants in order to make up the difference, and we’re not slowing down anytime soon.

 

Why contribute?

When you make a contribution to Cygnet Theatre, you are making a contribution to the artistic community in Paris as a whole. The goal of Cygnet is not simply to produce professional classical performances, but to grow into an example of what a theatre company can be here, and into an educational tool for the city. As Cygnet grows, we aim to develop tools to help foster and nurture the scene of classical theatre in Paris. Here are some of our plans:

As the troupe grows, we will:

1. Support new work from local and international playwrights

We believe that classical theatre is critical to the growth and development of future artists and playwrights. By supporting new work through a classical lens, we strive to acknowledge how one must learn from the past in order to create work that is pertinent to the now, and we plan on supporting these fresh, new stories in addition to producing timeless ones: because every voice deserves to be heard.

2. Offer workshops to local artists

Cygnet Theatre already hosts a number of actors trained in very different methods. As Cygnet grows, we will not only offer master classes taught by our company members, but we will bring in educators from all over the world to help strengthen the English performance industry here in Paris. Not only will this enhance the performance scene here, but it will begin to demonstrate to the world that Paris truly is a place where you can find exceptional French theatre right alongside exceptional English theatre. It will encourage artists across the world to commute here for theatrical projects and personal growth.

3. Educate students in classical and Shakespearean works

You know why we think classical theatre is important, but may be wondering: why should local schools and students care about it? For non-English speakers, Shakespeare is a great way to play with the English language, and to show how old language doesn’t need to invoke fear or dismay: to demonstrate how the English language has evolved and how Shakespeare even coined quite a few words! In addition to this, we plan on visiting drama classes and teaching them those little secrets that make Shakespeare more accessible, and more fun, for both native and non-native speakers. The goal is to inspire confidence in the English language, both on the tip of the tongue and on the stage. We are well-equipped to do this, as three of our founders have taught both theatre and English for years. By working with children and adults alike, our goal is to truly foster a new sense of community in the the English speaking world of theatre in Paris.

4. Super title our shows

Accessibility is incredible important to us here at Cygnet Theatre. You’ll notice our Indiegogo video has closed captions in French, and as soon as we are financially secure enough to do so, our performances will also be equipped with super titles in French for those that speak limited in English, alternating with English super titles for the hearing impaired. These are goals we hope to implement within year or two of opening the company. We realize this is ambitious, and that is why we are asking for your help to truly put forward theatre that is accessible to all.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

As with any creative venture, starting a theatre company is risky. The challenge is even greater when the performance language is not the national language – but we’ve been working towards these moments since we toddled on stage in our first kid’s theatre class. Every unpaid gig, every theatre history essay, every late-night script analysis session, and every failure have prepared us to tackle the inevitable hard times. We’re always learning. That doesn’t scare us. What scares us is looking back and wishing we had dreamed bigger.

 

Other Ways to Help

For a  fundraising campaign like ours, every dollar, euro, pound, penny, centime — every bit helps. However, as artists we of course understand that a financial donation is not always feasible (even if you're enthusiastic and supportive of the cause!)

If your wallet is a little light this month, there are other ways you can help us! The first big one is:

  1. Share this link! Share this page with anyone and everyone you think may be interested in Cygnet Theatre.
  2. Volunteer your time. We are always looking for volunteers as ushers or house managers for our shows, help transporting props, etc. There's a near constant need for volunteers at showtime! Shoot us an email at info@cygnettheatreparis.com to let us know you're interested!
  3. Volunteer your services! If you have a certain skill set you think could be of use to a budding theatre company (from consulting to accounting to anything creative), we'd welcome any and all help and advice. 
  4. Come to see the shows!

We'll leave it at that. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us though our email (info@cygnettheatreparis.com) or through our website (cygnettheatreparis.com). And, most important, from the bottom our hearts we offer a sincere

thank you. thank you. thank you.

 

~ Emily, Audrey, Charlotte, Taylor, Joshua, and all future troupe members.

Cygnet Theatre already hosts a number of actors trained in very different methods. As Cygnet grows, we will not only offer master classes taught by our company members, but we will bring in educators from all over the world to help strengthen the English performance industry here in Paris. Not only will this enhance the performance scene here, but it will begin to demonstrate to the world that Paris truly is a place where you can find exceptional French theatre right alongside exceptional English theatre. It will encourage artists across the world to commute here for theatrical projects and personal growth.
3. Educate students in classical and Shakespearean works
You know why we think classical theatre is important, but may be wondering: why should local schools and students care about it? For non-English speakers, Shakespeare is a great way to play with the English language, and to show how old language doesn’t need to invoke fear or dismay: to demonstrate how the English language has evolved and how Shakespeare even coined quite a few words! In addition to this, we plan on visiting drama classes and teaching them those little secrets that make Shakespeare more accessible, and more fun, for both native and non-native speakers. The goal is to inspire confidence in the English language, both on the tip of the tongue and on the stage. We are well-equipped to do this, as three of our founders have taught both theatre and English for years. By working with children and adults alike, our goal is to truly foster a new sense of community in the the English speaking world of theatre in Paris.
4. Super title our shows
Accessibility is incredible important to us here at Cygnet Theatre. You’ll notice our Indiegogo video has closed captions in French, and as soon as we are financially secure enough to do so, our performances will also be equipped with super titles in French for those that speak limited in English, alternating with English super titles for the hearing impaired. These are goals we hope to implement within year or two of opening the company. We realize this is ambitious, and that is why we are asking for your help to truly put forward theatre that is accessible to all.
 

 

Risks & Challenges
As with any creative venture, starting a theatre company is risky. The challenge is even greater when the performance language is not the national language – but we’ve been working towards these moments since we toddled on stage in our first kid’s theatre class. Every unpaid gig, every theatre history essay, every late-night script analysis session, and every failure have prepared us to tackle the inevitable hard times. We’re always learning. That doesn’t scare us. What scares us is looking back and wishing we had dreamed bigger.
 

Other Ways to Help
For a  fundraising campaign like ours, every dollar, euro, pound, penny, centime — every bit helps. However, as artists we of course understand that a financial donation is not always feasible (even if you're enthusiastic and supportive of the cause!)
If your wallet is a little light this month, there are other ways you can help us! The first big one is:

Share this link! Share this page with anyone and everyone you think may be interested in Cygnet Theatre.
Volunteer your time. We are always looking for volunteers as ushers or house managers for our shows, help transporting props, etc. There's a near constant need for volunteers at showtime! Shoot us an email at info@cygnettheatreparis.com to let us know you're interested!
Volunteer your services! If you have a certain skill set you think could be of use to a budding theatre company (from consulting to accounting to anything creative), we'd welcome any and all help and advice. 
Come to see the shows!

We'll leave it at that. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us though our email (info@cygnettheatreparis.com) or through our website (cygnettheatreparis.com). And, most important, from the bottom our hearts we offer a sincere
thank you. thank you. thank you.
 
~ Emily, Audrey, Charlotte, Taylor, Joshua, and all future troupe members.

story:
“Birds, so many birds. 

All white like sails.

They started far away.

They came closer.

They smothered me.

I closed my eyes. 

I took a breath.

I exhaled.

It was only feathers.

I purged them.

I awoke.

A great change is coming.

Only then did I emerge from the woods, gaunt and covered in ash.”

 
Kodi Lynn Milburn delves into the many tellings of the great medicine woman and other powerful women in history in this dynamic play with music. A twist on a traditional retelling, the play, directed by Isaac James Byrne with period style movement from Janice Orlandi and choreography by Emily Carroo, offers a modern perspective. 

 

Kodi Lynn Milburn wrote, composed, and will perform the show beginning in previews, Thanksgiving 2019, in her homeland of Nebraska and the Pine Ridge area. After her graduation from the New York Film Academy, majoring in Musical Theater & Film performance/production, Kodi brought her original immersive musical “Chrysalis” to its feet with the help of generous group funders, in collaboration with THE CREATORS COLLECTIVE, for the grand opening of the 100 Bogart st. gallery in Brooklyn. She released her albums “Midnight Ramblings” and “Morning Revelations” on Spotify, iTunes, and Apple Music, and has performed in performance venues around the world including R5 in Reykjavik, Iceland, the Plains Theater in Nebraska, and 54 Below in Manhattan. At 23, the young firecracker travels internationally with Little Matchstick Factory, the critically acclaimed theater company behind “The Other Mozart”(the story of Mozart’s sister in English and French) and “I am the Utterance of My Name”(an exploration on Mary Magdalene), while she prepares for previews of The Resurrection of Pocahontas.  

 

“This stories are due for a rehaul. We need to hear the other sides of history. These women are not just a canonized historical figures, but a resurrected spirits whose narratives have been repeated on a loop throughout the last 400 years. It’s time to give a voice to these women, to hear their feminine perspectives, to learn for future generations. We have never been more relevant than today.” -Kodi Lynn Milburn (creator)  

 

We believe this story needs to be broadcasted, over every loud speaker, in every ampitheater, small town playhouse, backyard, and Broadway stage. That’s where you come in. Every small donation or share, spreads this grassroots wildfire. We want every little girl with a big gift to see this, to see themselves in it. We want you to see yourself in it and be part of the revolution from the ground up.

 

Our goal for this campaign is to raise $2000 in small donations. We believe in the power of the groupfunding community, AND we are offering some unique and exclusive perks for those of you interested in an extra bang for your buck. The community surrounding the show has generously donated their offerings to the piece and those perks will go fast and are only available in partnership with the show. The limited goodies up for grabs are: 

 

  • Discounted tickets to The Resurrection of  preview (Thanksgiving 2019, Rushville, NE)
  • Photo sessions with Photos by Kodi Lynn 
  • SLT workout sessions with Cullen Shirtz
  • Private dance lessons with the show’s choreographer: Emily Carroo owner of Elite Dance Conservatory
  • THE CREATORS COLLECTIVE swag bag with CC merchandise
  • Kodi music starter pack including prints and pins designed by Sam Giuliano Art
  • Original watercolor paintings by Ryan Anthony Art 
  • #MMIW stickers 

 

95% funds raised from these items or unaffiliated donations, go towards the production’s costumes, travel expenses, artist and production/design team stipends, marketing, grant and residency application fees, set and light design, props, festival fees, music equipment and recording, research resources, rehearsal and performance spaces, as well as sound and lighting equipment. No donation is too small and if you cannot contribute monetarily but would like to help the show, please share this campaign, follow our instagram (@theresurrectionof) and facebook page with your network of friends and family. We also accept donations of services, artwork, etc. to sell as perks for our donors. 5% of the money raised goes directly to resources for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. Find out more at 

http://itstartswithus-mmiw.com/

“You carry her spirit. She was the seed, and you are the flower between two streams that since grew. You are her, and we are all connected.”

story:
Short Summary

     Raspberries is an effort to express and explore the idea that bigotry doesn’t occur randomly.  A person says and does the things they do, however hateful, to try to protect themselves and those they care about most.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

All of the proceeds that you contribute go toward: 

Actors // Designers // Fight Choreographer // Props // Rehearsal Spaces // Marketing // Programs // and other miscellaneous expenses that pop up while cultivating a new project!

 

Some of our fun perks include:

A unique piece of writing from the writer specified to you // homemade organic beeswax lotion // FaceTime with the director about her process // 2 VIP tickets to the show including a signed poster from the cast and creative team // and more exciting things featured to the right --> ! 

 

The Impact

     Your contribution will provide the opportunity to show an audience about the environment Wil, the writer, grew up in, and how we'll try to do justice to those who experienced them firsthand.  The hope is that it will continue to inspire conversation, thoughtfulness, and an evolution of compassion as it finds its feet with an audience.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, then join us at the show!

When: July 15th at 6:15pm, July 19th at 9pm, or July 21st at 4pm

Where: Hudson Guild Theater

You can purchase tickets by clicking on THIS LINK!

 

We hope to see you there and Thank You in advance for supporting new works with your contribution to Raspberries.

story:
Six Writers.

 

Six Directors.

 

Eighteen Actors.

 

One YouTube Channel.

 

Organic Theatre’s Inaugural 24-Hour Play Festival invites you to take a trust fall into new works in a virtual festival.

 

Who We Are:

Organic Theatre is built from the need to create ego-less theatre We are a brave, new kind of theatre-space creating a company of kindness and holistic compassion. We celebrate each artist’s individual creative process and talent. Inspired by our Inclusive Theaters and compelled to teach in the likes of Patch Adams, Organic Theatre creates a safe and profound space to reveal one’s art.

 

What We Need:

We need funds to help kickstart our inaugural  24-Hour Play Festival!

Our starting goal is $2000 to cover business start up fees, website development, and most importantly, our artists. We’ve recruited the best talent we know to write, direct, and act in our first 24-hour play festival.

Your contribution supports not only our coffee fund for six writers, six directors, and eighteen actors, but it contributes to the technology necessary to create our festival. Your kind donations will serve as Organic Theatre’s financial foundation, from which we can genuinely build opportunities.  

 

What Your Contribution Means to Us:

By believing in us, you are believing in a new kind of theatre. You are becoming part of a movement bigger than yourself…

story:
Social Justice Theater of the Carolinas-columbinus

I expected a lot of silly teenagers at rehearsal last Valentine’s Day. We were rehearsing Shakespeare’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” I expected the usual chaos pitch but as soon as the cast walked on stage, I could tell something was different–no chatty energy, no giggles or silliness. Something was up.

I looked at one of the actresses that has been with us for years. My eyes must have said, "So, what's going on?" "The shooting" she said. “We were just discussing the shooting." I had been immersed in our little theater all day. I had not heard about Parkland. They filled in the horrific details. We went on with rehearsal. There was work to be done.

Afterwards, several actors stayed behind. They vented their frustrations and anger. I talked about how I remembered where I was and what I was doing when I heard about Columbine... and how nothing had changed. They shared their memories of Sandy Hook; although they were quite young at the time, they remembered. We talked, cried and went home.

I thought that was the end of it. The next day while randomly thumbing through a stack of scripts I had ordered years ago, columbinus caught my eye. As I read the riveting script, the Social Justice Theater of the Carolinas was born and columbinus was chosen as our inaugural play.

SJTC is currently comprised of alumni of our Pittsboro Youth Theater which also calls Sweet Bee Theater “home.” Discussions after Parkland made clear that these young people were interested in applying their theatrical skills for more than entertainment.

SJTC will be performing columbinus live on stage 3 times April 19-20, 2019 which is the 20th Anniversary of the Columbine High School shootings.

Columbinus is a play by the United States Theatre Project Written by Stephen Karam and PJ Paparelli. We have chosen this play to commemorate the lives lost in that and all school shootings. Since the Columbine shootings over 200 people have been killed in school shootings in the US.

If it is possible to repair the frayed social fabric in our country, an eyes-wide-open look at modern life as is woven into the play columbinus may spur discussion–a necessary first step toward widespread understanding and then, hopefully, positive action. This play is important because it deftly unites rather than divides. Instead of focusing on hot-button topics like gun control, columbinus focuses on questions such as those the author, P.J. Paparelli, included in the forward:

"How do we treat each other?  Why do we treat each other the way we do?  Why do kids, who will soon ask these questions about their kids, continue to treat each other the same way?  Why does this cycle never change, even after the kids themselves resort to bombs and guns and butchering their fellow students to prove a point?  Why do we look for an easy answer- a pill to take, a program to turn off- when we know in our hearts that something deep inside us has to change?  What are we afraid of?"  

These types of questions create dialogue and bring communities closer rather than divide them. After each show, a counselor will lead a community discussion between the actors and the audience about school shootings.

In addition, there will be daily information, inspiration, pictures and videos on our Facebook page that chronicles our rehearsal and performance process. You will be able to watch as the actors grow into their characters and grapple with this very difficult topic. Followers will be given the weekly discussion topics in advance so they can journal along with the cast. They will be able to post their thoughts and hear back from cast members. This will enhance the discussion by adding to those "at the table".

The Project

The funds requested for this project will be used for our inaugural production, columbinus. The play will be produced whether or not all funds are raised. It is our hope that, with these funds, the play can be offered to the community for free in order to start a community discussion and include those that otherwise could not afford to attend. The first $2,500 will be used for royalties, scripts, costumes, lighting, theater rental, advertising etc. The rest of the funds raised will be used to take the play to other locations such as community centers, churches, schools etc. throughout North and South Carolina. Those funds will pay for gas, hotel rooms (if needed), royalties, technical staff, rental of sound and lighting equipment etc.

The Impact

This project will make a difference in the lives of the actors, the audience and the community! Communication is the key to avoid these and many other social problems. This play will spark discussions beyond the walls of the theater. We will ask each person that attends the play as well as our online followers to discuss these questions with 10 other people which we hope will create a ripple effect beyond the community and even the state!

Risks & Challenges

We face 2 major challenges. First, this play is difficult. It is most often performed in Universities. However, I think it is most powerful when done by teenagers because they are the ones that are most affected my school shootings. We have a talented and experienced group of actors committed to the show. However, rehearsals will be difficult for some. To help with this, we will bring in a councilor to assist with rehearsals.

The second challenge that we face is community buy in. This play, although beautifully written and very respectful to those who died at Columbine, is controversial. Below is more from the author about the play and how it was written:

"columbinus is not a play; it is a theatrical discussion.  Its creators, a group of multi-generational artists, wanted to create a fictional world of adolescence, born out of our collective experience.  Just as this fictional high school could be anywhere in America, so could the potential for a school shooting.  We quickly realized that we needed to talk with this generation of adolescents and hear what they had to say about their world.  At the same time, we needed to dive deep into the heart of Columbine and hear from the people who experienced the shootings, as well as teenagers living in Littleton today.  We collected as much oral and written fact about Columbine as we could gather.  The merger of these two worlds would be the subject for discussion."

Many people hear the word Columbine and want to shy away or bury their head. We will need to advertise in many different formats in order to get a diverse audience to attend.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, please!!!! We need help with social media, advertising, grant writing, finding other venues etc. We are a small group of youth actors and a few adults. We can and will make this happen. Please go to PittsboroYouthTheater.com to see our main business. We have a history of doing difficult things with few resources. But we can always use more help. More man power will mean that we reach more people!!!!

story:
Who are we?

SOL Theatre Collective (STC) is an ensemble, artist-driven theatre collective based in Vancouver. It was conceived from a desire to create a supportive community of like-minded artists, keen to celebrate the process of storytelling in healthy collaboration, where:

  • Inclusion is paramount - on and off the stage
  • Integrity counts
  • Curiosity and Exploration is of great value
  • Equality is central - because all voices matter

We are in pursuit of bringing innovative and high quality theater to the stage - where audiences are engaged, deeply moved, humored, entertained, and ultimately pulled into a full and nourishing theatrical experience.
 

What are we up to?

  • This is our first theatrical production as a  collective and we are excited to bring Lisa D'Amour's, "ANNA BELLA EEMA" to THE CULTCH in March 2020. For more information see: http://www.soltheatre.weebly.com
  • Lois Anderson and Gina Leon under the direction of Charles Siegel, are bringing to life a story of a reclusive mother and her ten year old daughter - living in a run-down trailer on land condemned for highway expansion. Isolation, survival and identity for the young Anna Bella are tempered by a rich fantasy world in which she creates a girl out of mud. "One’s ‘identity’ is a complex, fragile,  fluid mix of our parents, our past, and our dreams." - Charles Siegel, Director.
  • This is a wildly inventive play and we want to share this powerful and relevant story with audiences!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our work in the arts would not be possible without community support - you make it happen! 
  • We are raising money for production costs and as an Artist's Collective, we are a group of Union (CAEA) and non-union artists agreeing to bring a play to the public without asking for any salaries.  We invest financially in our production and the only payment for our work will be through our share of whatever profits beyond the expenses for the production the show will bring in.  
  • The funds received are for production costs which include: theatre rental and technician costs, theatre staff (box office, front of house), lighting design, sound design, set design, performance rights, theatre insurance, set and costumes - you will be part of building this production and you will be fully acknowledged on all forms of media related to our production, including social media platforms, in our play program and on our official website: www.soltheatre.weebly.com
  • When you donate money to our production and select the perk "Downtown Eastside Women's Centre", we donate half our received amount to the DEWC
  • When you donate money you can select perks which include early bird tickets for the production, original art, or the option to donate to Downtown Eastside Women's Centre

  • ABOUT DEWC: The mission of the Downtown Eastside Women’s Centre is to provide a safe, non-judgmental environment for women from all walks of life, who live and/or work in the Downtown Eastside. DEWC operates a low-barrier drop-in centre and emergency night shelter, offering safe, women-only space, supportive surroundings, meals and basic essentials, as well as a continuum of care that nurtures and empowers members towards long-term change.

    A COMMUNITY HUB: Hundreds of women access DEWC daily, where they can find hot, nutritious meals, toiletries and clothing, phone and computer access, as well as a safe space and emotional support, or something as simple as (in one member's words) a shoulder to cry on. The drop-in centre is a cornerstone of the Downtown Eastside community, hosting grief and support groups, counselling, arts workshops, healing circles, and meetings for the annual Women's Memorial March, as well as a spectrum of specialized support including HIV case management, victim services, skills development, advocacy, and housing assistance.

Budget Breakdown:

                   

The Impact

“A skillfully stylized…wise comment on identity, the violence and inevitability of separation, and the value of both adaptation and detailed self-awareness.” 
– The New York Times.

This play tackles all things topical including: 

  • the fierce bond between mother and daughter
  • identity and what this looks like when we face crisis
  • the invasion of home  and all the things we cultivate to survive
  • the separation of family when dysfunction is insurmountable 
  • identity, poverty, play, fantasy, and violence

You will be helping a burgeoning new theatre company bring to life an important piece of theatre!

This also marks the Vancouver Debut of ANNA BELLA EMMA by Pulitzer finalist, Lisa D'Amour! 

Risks & Challenges

The ultimate challenge is to create something of outstanding value - to give something meaningful to audiences... to inspire, to cultivate buzz, interest and ultimately to get people actively excited about and engaged in this powerful story. 

  • We are a small independent collective without the support of a major institution - this means:  wearing many hats, working really diligently to bring something outstanding to the stage, integrating community in the building of this production, and ultimately creating something meaningful to share with audiences 
  • As a collective we are undertaking this project at our own risk, because we believe in it as a valuable work of art that should be seen. As artists, who make our living by making art, we are investing in this, working on very limited budgets, but entirely committed to bringing story to life

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word - make some noise about our campaign. We would be so grateful if you can share our campaign.  

For more information go to OUR WEBSITE: https://soltheatre.weebly.com/

THANK YOU FOR ALL YOUR SUPPORT!
story_txt:
Who are we?
SOL Theatre Collective (STC) is an ensemble, artist-driven theatre collective based in Vancouver. It was conceived from a desire to create a supportive community of like-minded artists, keen to celebrate the process of storytelling in healthy collaboration, where:

Inclusion is paramount - on and off the stage
Integrity counts
Curiosity and Exploration is of great value
Equality is central - because all voices matter

We are in pursuit of bringing innovative and high quality theater to the stage - where audiences are engaged, deeply moved, humored, entertained, and ultimately pulled into a full and nourishing theatrical experience. 
What are we up to?

This is our first theatrical production as a  collective and we are excited to bring Lisa D'Amour's, "ANNA BELLA EEMA" to THE CULTCH in March 2020. For more information see: http://www.soltheatre.weebly.com


Lois Anderson and Gina Leon under the direction of Charles Siegel, are bringing to life a story of a reclusive mother and her ten year old daughter - living in a run-down trailer on land condemned for highway expansion. Isolation, survival and identity for the young Anna Bella are tempered by a rich fantasy world in which she creates a girl out of mud. "One’s ‘identity’ is a complex, fragile,  fluid mix of our parents, our past, and our dreams." - Charles Siegel, Director.
This is a wildly inventive play and we want to share this powerful and relevant story with audiences!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our work in the arts would not be possible without community support - you make it happen! 
We are raising money for production costs and as an Artist's Collective, we are a group of Union (CAEA) and non-union artists agreeing to bring a play to the public without asking for any salaries.  We invest financially in our production and the only payment for our work will be through our share of whatever profits beyond the expenses for the production the show will bring in.

The drop-in centre is a cornerstone of the Downtown Eastside community, hosting grief and support groups, counselling, arts workshops, healing circles, and meetings for the annual Women's Memorial March, as well as a spectrum of specialized support including HIV case management, victim services, skills development, advocacy, and housing assistance.

story:
A Brief Summary

I, KGDDance Founder, Katya Danko, am fundraising for our first full-length production Difficult Women. Inspired by the characters found in Roxane Gay's collection of short stories "Difficult Women" we explore female struggle, resilience and identity. We work-shopped a successful shorter version of this production last winter and dove back in this year, revamping and expanding for a full length, 60min production being held at The Tank Theater NYC this December. We need your help to build a provocative, thoughtful show to inspire all audiences!

About Our Company KGDDance

As a modern/contemporary dance company KGDDance provides a platform for truthful female-centric artistic narratives, told through movement and dance. As either a new work or movement adaptation, these stories deal with the complex strengths and vulnerabilities of women, and the truthful relationships they share with others as well as themselves. We are dedicated to exploring movement and collaborating with other artists to create a space in which these beautifully flawed characters can flourish and breathe.

For more info on us and our past projects visit www.kgddance.com !

About the "Difficult Women" Project

This project explores the female complexities within three of Roxane Gay’s stories: “I Will Follow You” (danced by Madeline Charles and Taylor Marie), “I am the Knife” (danced by Brittany Posas and Song Ravinan) and “Break all the way Down” (danced by Gabriela Vazquez).

Within each story line we explore female identity through the impossible situations and circumstances these characters have had to deal with. The key that links these stories together is one girl (dancer Bonnie Bushnell) who tries to understand her own identity while gaining inspiration from the women within these stories.

This performance will also feature the work of lighting designer Kent Sprague and original music by Trevor Danko.

We believe that woman have this amazing capacity to find immense strength through struggle and trauma. We want to inspire others, specifically women to enjoy what makes them vulnerable or “unlikable” or "difficult", it’s part of who they are. In light of recent feminist movements (the various women's marches, #metoo, #timeisup, etc), this show promotes the message that a woman of any class, race or religion never has to apologize for who she is or what she has been through.

 

 

The Team

Choreographer and Director: Katya Danko

Lighting Designer: Kent Sprague

Original Music: Trevor Danko

Performers:

Bonnie Bushnell

Madeline Charles

Taylor Marie

Brittany Posas

Song Ravinan

Gabriela Vazquez

For more info on our team visit www.kgddance.com/about

Impact

Your Support will go to:

-Compensation for Performers and Designers

-Budget for Costume and Props

-Rehearsal Studio Rental

-Marketing Materials

-Extra Emergency Funds

We accept donations of any and all sizes. Every dollar thrown into this project brings us another step closer to our goal. No Donation is too small!

When you donate check out our awesome perks!

-Tote bags

-KGDDance workshops

-Company Dance Videos

-Producers’ Credits

-Public and Personalized Thank you’s

By contributing to our project, you can choose from these amazing offers and you will also become a part of our KGDDance community, helping to promote accurate female representation within the arts, so that it becomes the norm for future generations of young women.

Risks & Challenges

The Challenge we are facing is getting our project to reach its full potential and to sell out each show. All the artists involved with this project are incredibly dedicated and passionate about the work and we want the show to reflect that.

Other Ways You Can Help

We would be so grateful if you could share our campaign with your networks, through social media, email and any other platforms possible!

The more we get our message out there the more impact we can have!

story:
What is Takes Chops Productions?

In the winter of 2019, Student Theatre at Marymount sponsored a small production of Scab to be performed in the school dining hall. The rehearsal process was challenging, cathartic, and beautiful- we couldn't stop after our 3 scheduled performances. So instead of succumbing to the post- show slump, we got the cast and crew back together (with a couple exciting new additions) and decided we would do it again. We formed Takes Chops Productions, acquired the rights to the show, and set about planning for our new and improved production. 

Cast and Crew

Production Team:

Director - Flynn Osman

Stage Manager/ Sound Designer - Tessa Welsch

Assistant Stage Manager/ Props Master - Claire Shutters

Lighting/Sound Design - Angelo Sagnelli

Costume Design - Ethan Wong

Assistant Costume Designer/ Hair and Makeup Designer - Abigayle Luttrell

Movement Coach/Choreographer - Samuel Hohn

Producer- Caroline McQuaig

Cast

Anima - Hailey Burger

Christa - Caroline McQuaig

Alan - Jeffrey Penton Jr.

Artie/Davie/Angel Two - Samuel Hohn

Jenna/Angel One - Jackie Kraft

Mom/Kellee/Mary-Androgyne - Haley Glickman

Budget Breakdown 

If you choose to give to our campaign, your money will be going towards:

- Venue Rental- We will be performing at The Gallery Space in the Access Theater in SoHo.

- Costumes designed by Ethan Wong 

-Props sourced and designed by Claire Shutters

-Lighting Equipment for designer Angelo Sagnelli to bring his vision to life

-Sets so our new recruit Peyton Tavares can build our world

-Marketing, so as many people as possible can come experience this play we love so much

Risks & Challenges

Creating theatre is always a financial risk, but we believe it is a worthwhile one. Theater space, especially in New York City, comes at a price and we cannot cover it alone. We also have big dreams here at TCP and some of the gorgeous costume and set designs we have in mind for this new production are going to require more than what we can source from our own homes. With your funding and our ingenuity and elbow grease, we can make this DIY production look like a Broadway smash. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to help us get this project off the ground without a financial contribution! You can support us by sharing this campaign with your friends and on social media and following us on Instagram (@takeschops).

story:
Hi, this is Caleb Hammond, theatrical and visual artist. I have been working for about a year now with an expanding group of collaborators on a project that is very dear to my heart. It is an immersive theatrical work involving over 30 collaborators, staged in a beautiful, cavernous, multi-room old brick garage in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The Irresistible will be a unique theatrical experience. Audience members will be fee to explore the playing space and have a drink at the bar while bearing witness to the performance of the highly engaging actors, dancers and the atmospheric music of the all-female punk band Huff This, as well as the evocative environmental and live-camera scenography. My collaborators have put an immense amount of energy into this production, and I am beyond thrilled to be presenting it next month. I hope to gain your support in these crucial last days as we bring this ambitious undertaking to completion!


What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this exciting production happen, I need to do a little bit of fundraising. The money will go to the purchase and install of scenic elements, rental of video, sound and lighting equipment, transportation of people and materials. Raising the full amount will also afford me the opportunity to pay modest stipends to the people who have been putting so much of their time, energy and hard work into making this production a success.

Contributors will garner my sincere gratitude, the gratitude of the whole production team, and will receive credit in the program and online as a supporter, as well as signed posters of the show. The higher levels of giving earn unique artworks which I will be creating in the months following the show, inspired by and expanding upon the imagery and themes of The Irresistible.

The funding goal is ambitious, but so is the project. If we don't quite reach the goal, the money we do raise will still help defray the considerable cost of mounting  a production of this scale. My collaborators have all been taking on multiple responsibilities to make this vision a reality. They have been tireless and committed - your support will go a long way to help them in our final push.

I hope that you will consider becoming part our team, by contributing to the campaign if you are able (and any amount helps!) and also by spreading the word by using the Indiegogo share tools.

I also hope to sincerely hope to see you at the show! It is sure to be a wild ride and an experience you won't want to miss!

Hi folks,

The previous amount we were trying to raise is no longer relevant. Thanks to partnerships and sponsors (announcing soon!) we're only going to cover the cost of renting the space! I'm so excited for what's been happening lately and I'm excited to tell you all about it soon!

Please help us raise the last $425!

Thanks,
Patrick Higgins

story:
Hello all! We are in production on two new exciting plays and now now NOW is the time to raise money and awareness! 

Lee Douglass is directing 

 

Of Burning Desire inspired by the Yukio Mishima novel, Thirst for Love.

 

Tricia Mancuso Parks is directing Divinity of Hell: from Shakespeare's Othello

Please be a supporter, be in our audience and tell others about the show!


Why we need your support...

It is a huge challenge to secure funding for even the most basic requirements when putting up a show starting with rehearsal space. We are working with incredibly talented and generous actors, musicians, designers, crew and consultants. We highly value their collaboration and we really want to pay them!! We are all motivated by these two complicated, intense and exciting plays and we have a deposit on a very cool theatre space. Now to raise the money!

How your gift helps...


CREATE JOBS! You are providing an opportunity for artists to practice their craft and connect with audience. That is a HUGE give back! Thank you . Thank you. Thank you! And your support, in all forms, says that you believe that theatre matters. 

“All the world's a stage.”  William Shakespeare, As You Like It


YOUR CONTRIBUTION COVERS (detailed production budget avail anytime requested)
3K        Theatre Rental, box office, house manager
3k        Rehearsal Space NYC  two plays
13k       ARTIST FEES   26 professionals

  • Please CONTRIBUTE everything helps tremendously.
  • Please SHOUT out the noise about our campaign. Share and Support.
  • Please COME see the one show two plays! 
  • THANK YOU 
  • THANK YOU 
  • THANK YOU 
  • LOVE, Lee + Tricia, the theatre directors 

OUR LUST CAST & PRODUCTION TEAM:

​OF BURNING DESIRE Inspired by Mishima novel Thirst for Love

Written and Directed by Lee Douglass

CAST 

  • Yuki Kawahisa                 Kaede    
  • Toshinori Hamada          Yasunobu 
  • Satomi  Shikata               Ume
  • Teruaki Akai                     Saburo
  • Akiko Tokouka                 Chiyo
MUSIC & DANCE
  • Kento  Iwasaki                      Composer        
  • Sumie Kaneko                       Shamisen
  • Yoko Reikano Kimura          Shamisen  
  • Elizabeth Brown                    Shakuhachi
  • Toshinori Hamada                Noh Singer, Kabuki Choreography

DESIGNERS

  • Teddy Jefferson                    Lighting and Set Designer
  • Diane Specioso                     Costume Designer

PRODUCTION TEAM

  • Ed Parada                               Photography and Videography
  • Hikaru Tamaki                      Japanese Translator
  • Yuki Kawahisa                      Japanese Translator
  • Toshinori Hamada               Edo period Japanese Translator

Of Burning Desire explores the complex responses of the feminine psyche amid social protocols and dictated behaviors that result in repression of Self and disconnection from one's own emotional life. 

In Japan, after the 15th century, the teachings of the "Three Obediences" reigned: 

"A woman has no way of independence in life: when she is young, she obeys her father; when she is married, she obeys her husband; when she is widowed, she obeys her son."

Even though this play is the story of  one woman, it is the story of multitudinous women throughout the ages, throughout all cultures. Even though this story takes place in early Edo period Japan, the arrested development of personal autonomy and the impact that has on how women perceive and interact with themselves and the world is still prevalent in 2015. 

Of Burning Desire is an operetta with a stunning mix of the traditional and the contemporary.  Drawing from classic Japanese theater forms (Kabuki & Noh) and composer Kento Iwasaki's brilliant fusion of opera and traditional Japanese music, the story unfolds through a dazzling array of dance, song and visuals. 


And

DIVINITY OF HELL :  from Shakespeare’s Othello  

Adapted & Directed by Tricia Mancuso Parks        

CAST 

  • Christianne Greiert*                    Desdemona    
  • Stuart Rudin*                                Brabantio    
  • Basil Rodericks*                           Othello    
  • Thomas Hildreth*                         Iago      
  • Sarah Krokey / Najla Said*        Emilia        
  • Charles Hendricks*                      Cassio
  • Cayenne Douglass                        Bianca      
  • Ann Osmond*                                Singer  
  • Al Ramos                                        Guitars
DESIGNERS
  • Teddy Jefferson                            Lighting Designer
  • Diane Specioso                             Costume Designer
PRODUCTION  TEAM 

  • Yetti Steinman                            Stage Manager
  • Ron Canada                                 Shakespeare Text Consultant      
  • Al Ramos                                      Counsel                      
  • Ed Parada                                     Photographer & Videography
  • Regina Ebel                                   Associate Producer

* Actors appear courtesy of Actor's Equity Association

“Divinity of Hell” is Shakespeare’s play Othello in little more than an hour focusing on the women in a male landscape, the handkerchief sequence and what drives this locomotion of uninterrupted action to it's tragic end. Why do this? It is a nightmare... Its is a heartbreak...Why do we lose our head in Love? "Awake!" Identify the divine in a hellish situation, be not sucked into the gossip of one's own insecurities and please do it before it's too late! "Light! I say light!"



​﻿

Our show dates are in! November 18-22.  Mark your calendar NOW! We are booked at a great downtown theatre complex. One Show. Two Plays.  LUST IS THE DRUG ! 

   At TNC  155 First AvenueNew York, New York 10003


unShout the Noise is a theatrical partner of CWNYi Creative Women New York, Inc. a non-profit arts umbrella organization that facilitates creative development and creative community.
story_txt:
Hello all! We are in production on two new exciting plays and now now NOW is the time to raise money and awareness! 
Lee Douglass is directing  Of Burning Desire inspired by the Yukio Mishima novel, Thirst for Love. 


Tricia Mancuso Parks is directing Divinity of Hell: from Shakespeare's Othello

Please be a supporter, be in our audience and tell others about the show!


Why we need your support...




It is a huge challenge to secure funding for even the most basic requirements when putting up a show starting with rehearsal space. We are working with incredibly talented and generous actors, musicians, designers, crew and consultants. We highly value their collaboration and we really want to pay them!! We are all motivated by these two complicated, intense and exciting plays and we have a deposit on a very cool theatre space. Now to raise the money!


How your gift helps...

CREATE JOBS! You are providing an opportunity for artists to practice their craft and connect with audience. That is a HUGE give back! Thank you . Thank you. Thank you! And your support, in all forms, says that you believe that theatre matters. 
“All the world's a stage.”  William Shakespeare, As You Like It


YOUR CONTRIBUTION COVERS (detailed production budget avail anytime requested)

3K        Theatre Rental, box office, house manager
3k        Rehearsal Space NYC  two plays

13k       ARTIST FEES   26 professionals




Please CONTRIBUTE everything helps tremendously.
Please SHOUT out the noise about our campaign. Share and Support.
Please COME see the one show two plays! 
THANK YOU 
THANK YOU 
THANK YOU 
LOVE, Lee + Tricia, the theatre directors 









OUR LUST CAST & PRODUCTION TEAM:

​OF BURNING DESIRE Inspired by Mishima novel Thirst for Love
Written
and Directed by Lee Douglass
CAST 



Yuki Kawahisa                 Kaede    


Toshinori Hamada          Yasunobu 

Satomi  Shikata               Ume
Teruaki Akai                     Saburo
Akiko Tokouka                 Chiyo

MUSIC & DANCE


Kento  Iwasaki                      Composer        


Sumie Kaneko                       Shamisen

Yoko Reikano Kimura          Shamisen  
Elizabeth Brown                    Shakuhachi
Toshinori Hamada                Noh Singer, Kabuki Choreography

DESIGNERS

Teddy Jefferson                    Lighting and Set Designer
Diane Specioso                     Costume Designer

PRODUCTION TEAM


Ed Parada                               Photography and Videography
Hikaru
Tamaki                      Japanese Translator
Yuki
Kawahisa                      Japanese Translator
Toshinori
Hamada               Edo period Japanese Translator

Of Burning Desire explores the complex responses of the feminine psyche amid social protocols and dictated behaviors that result in repression of Self and disconnection from one's own emotional life. 
In Japan, after the 15th century, the teachings of the "Three Obediences" reigned: 
"A woman has no way of independence in life: when she is young, she obeys her father; when she is married, she obeys her husband; when she is widowed, she obeys her son."
Even though this play is the story of  one woman, it is the story of multitudinous women throughout the ages, throughout all cultures. Even though this story takes place in early Edo period Japan, the arrested development of personal autonomy and the impact that has on how women perceive and interact with themselves and the world is still prevalent in 2015. 



Of Burning Desire is an operetta with a stunning mix of the traditional and the contemporary.  Drawing from classic Japanese theater forms (Kabuki & Noh) and composer Kento Iwasaki's brilliant fusion of opera and traditional Japanese music, the story unfolds through a dazzling array of dance, song and visuals. 





And

DIVINITY OF HELL :  from Shakespeare’s Othello  
Adapted
& Directed by Tricia Mancuso Parks

story:
Venue & Dates

Interconnected is being performed at the Sprenger - Atlas Performing Arts Center on 1333 H Street, NE Washington, DC 20002.  Our show are: Saturday, 7/11 4:30pm; Wednesday, 7/15 6:00pm; Friday, 7/17 8:30pm; Sunday, 7/19 12:00pm; Saturday, 7/25 4:45pm!! 


Short Summary

Hi there!  We are two creative individuals who have been friends for over seven years.  Four years ago we went to a coffee shop in DC and decided to write a play together.  We bought a notebook with the word 'Gratitude' on the cover and Brian wrote the first line.  We passed the notebook back and forth creating the script line by line.  Since I live in Boston and Brian lives in DC, we would each write a scene and make changes online.  Discovering how to blend our writing styles was a fascinating part of the process.  

A few months after we finished writing the play, we had it workshopped through Artist's Bloc.  Having it read out loud by actors and given input on changes to be made, we rewrote many scenes and felt as if it flowed much better.  It took many submissions to theaters, but we finally got accepted into the Capital Fringe Festival and cannot be happier!

The money you give will make this play happen.  Interconnected conveys some emotional truths and also shows what we can learn from confusion.  Help others reflect on, and be grateful for, their lives.  That's the power of your donation!


What We Need & What You Get

We need 7G's or $7,000!  Why do you need that much money, you ask?  GOOD QUESTION!  In producing this play, we are paying actors and production staff as well as marketing and traveling costs.  There are multiple set pieces we need to purchase to furnish a semi-real looking apartment, hospital room, diner and bar which will require a van and storage unit.

There are many perks if you donate a certain amount of money, which you can view on the right column.  Who doesn't like perks?!  


The Impact

This is the cheesy part:  Both Karen and I have wanted to do this since we were little kids.  So much so that Karen studied acting and directing in college, and I studied film and media.  Our love of the arts runs #deep.  Karen works at the American Repertory Theater and I just came out with a CD of original songs.  Both of us have performed with the education theater troupe Improbable Players.


Risks & Challenges

Even though Karen has a theater background and Brian has film experience, neither has produced a play from top to bottom.  This is a new challenge that we are taking on because we both are hard working, dedicated people who believe in sharing stories with audiences.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, we would love your help in getting the word out!  You can use the Indiegogo share tools or just tell the person in front of you in the grocery store about it!

story:
Friends, Theatre-Goers, Locals, lend me your ears :

Hello Friends, Thank you so much for taking the time to check out my Campaign.

I'm a local stage manager, emerging arts administrator and Durham native  who has always been madly in love with the gem of a city. The Hayti and rich legacy that African Americans have had in this city, especially in the Arts, has always held a special place in my heart.  I relish the opportunity to continue that legacy in Durham.
As a kid attending Durham School of the Arts, I fell in love with theatre. But it was my time spent living and interning in New York City that my love turned into a fervent passion. My passion along with crazy work ethics opened up the doors for me to work with a host of brilliant artists and companies.

My experience thus far has brought me to this current place as an artist/administrator.  I'm  eager to learn more, explore different genres and approaches along with innovating new ways collaborate.  

I  am on a journey to redefine how African Americans are introduced to and experience theatre. I want to bridge the gap between the Black artists and Durham's vibrant theatre scene.

My newest venture is Black Ops : Durham's Black Theatre Company. One of my main goals is be able to give black artists in this city a haven where they can be "ON" all of time and confident in their chances of being cast.

Please visit www.blackopstheatre.com to view our mission ... 


What We Need:

Under the artistic direction of JaMeeka Holloway-Burrell, Black Ops humbly request your financial support for our first year of operations.  Our goals during this inaugural season include  : 
  1. Produce TWO contrasting shows -- "The Shipment"  by Young Jean Lee and a re-imagining of Henrik Ibsen's "A Doll's House"  To stay true to our mission, the content of these shows stretches us beyond our comfort zones.
  2.  Hosting an array of workshops that will benefit the growing amount of Black Artists in Durham.  Our workshops will be open to the public and financially accessible.
  3. Participating in outreach that encourages creativity and imagination in youth from low income communities throughout our the city. 
These things sound cool, right?
Your donation to us will help us with:
Securing the rights for the shows, 
Providing workshops,
Space for performance and rehearsals,
Marketing, web design and promotion,
And More....
With your generosity we will also be able to give our audience a truly professional experience, as well as our team and collaborators, by being able to compensate them fairly for time and effort.  
Any additional funds will stay in The Black Ops account and go towards future productions and projects.
We are seeking to raise the bar.  Black Ops is short for BLACK OPPORTUNITIES!
We will give opportunities to professionals and aspiring professionals so they can glean practical experience, grow as humans, and expand their artistry. Primarily, my hope for the Black Ops is that we always challenge ourselves as actors, directors, administrators and technicians. 

Other Ways You Can Help

As we like to say in the Theatre... there are NO SMALL ROLES...

Please, please don't think that just because you're not able to give monetarily that you can't give at all ... you can also help by:

SPREADING THE WORD ABOUT OUR CAMPAIGN! Please Share! I dare you...

Maybe you'd like to donate space, time, your web design abilities, hang a light or two for free... Be creative. We appreciate everything.

Yes, I know my goals are huge, but they are also obtainable with the help of fine people like you.  This year I am looking forward to forging strong connections with other local theatre companies, local businesses and all of you.

Thank you so much for entertaining the dreams of a this young Arts Administrator from the Bullcity. 

Onward and upward in love,

JaMeeka

Artistic Director 

Black Ops : Durham's Black Theatre Company.

story:
Help me become a working actor!

Hello!!! My name is Emma Rickman, I'm a freshman acting major at Ball State University, and what I really want to do with my degree is perform in a company that focuses on Shakespeare. I was offered a spot in the Acting Apprentice Program at the Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey, which is an incredible opportunity for me to learn and grow as an artist. I'd be able to get the inside scoop on what it's really like to work in a company, and the time I'd spend there would take my training to the next level.

What exactly are you contributing to?

If I'm able to take this chance, I will be benefitting from more opportunities than you can shake a stick at...which is exactly what I'll be doing in the stage combat class ;) (maybe with a little more finesse?) Other classes include Acting/Scene Study, Voice and Speech, Movement, and Text Analysis. These, along with being on a deck crew and many performance opportunities, will culminate in a truly mind-blowing educational experience.

Sooo...why the funding?

I've set a goal of $4400, most of which will go directly to tuition and housing costs - a little more than 10% will be used for the IndieGogo tax as well as credit card fees. The total cost of the program is $4000, and I'm going to be providing all of that - hopefully with your help! I'll be working two jobs right up until the day I leave in order to help facilitate the funding, and this online campaign is another way to help me and fund my training. Even if I don't reach my goal, the money will still go towards my education, either here at Ball State or at another program.

It was a little difficult coming up with "perks" for this campaign, because the biggest thing I can give you is my eternal love and gratitude...that being said, I'm excited to offer what I can! I'd really love to make you a different kind of art out of some beautiful language, PLEASE give me that opportunity!!

I'll accept love!

Of course, not everyone is able to contribute financially - but that's okay! Sharing this post on your Facebook page or Twitter feed (or just good old-fashioned telling someone about it) will help bring my campaign to more peoples attention. Any support you can give would be more than appreciated...even reading all the way down to the bottom of this wall of text is awesome of you :)
Thank you so much for reading <3

story:
You have no idea how grateful I will be for helping me get to Italy! I ensure I will send you a postcard back! Or for generous contributors perhaps a little more! I know a few people that like Abruzzo region grapes...

The money raised with go towards tuition costs for this great program! As well as air fare to get to Italy. the program run from June 22nd - July 19th, 2015. Tuition for the program is $4850, which includes housing, all lessons, coaching, masterclasses, Italian language classes, Pilates and movement sessions. But sadly not flights. 

I will also benefit from working with COSIs phenomenal directors and learn from acclaimed Stage Manager Isolde Pleasants-Faulkner, and the entire stage management faculty.

I will gain valuable experience in running a rehearsal, and will gain hands-on experience in every aspect of the opera production. In addition to the practical experience, regular seminars will be offered to discuss “best-practices” and regulations in stage management, and provide an opportunity for individual questions and development.

AND I'll also have an opportunity to run COSI and Opera Studio concerts. Can you believe it?!!

In addition to ongoing mentoring and coaching from the stage management faculty, I will also participate in intensive Italian language training, private coaching with faculty and Pilates Instruction.

Successful completion of the program will give me one more Stage Management Apprenticeship Credit with the Canadian Actors’ Equity Association. (Of which I currently have 4 of the required 8 to join!)

story:
Hello!

Thanks for having a look at our Surrounded tour campaign. As a founding member and Artistic Director of The Unexpected Laboratory this project and opportunity is extremely important to me.  The company began as a way to make dangerous and interdisciplinary art that amplified the voices of people who felt that they were not yet old enough to stand as leaders in the arts and in society. Now in our third year, we have toured shows to Canada and various locations in the US, fostered the creation of award winning films, and offered educational programming in interdisciplinary creation to public high schools, universities, youth groups and organizations for people with physical and mental handicaps.

I hope to answer some of your questions, but if you have any additional questions, you can leave them in the comments section on this Indiegogo.

Thank you,

Travis Coe _____________________________________________________________________________

                                                                                               International Tour of "Surrounded"


WHAT ARE WE UP TO:

Chicago Artists, Will Greenburg and Travis Coe will join The Unexpected Laboratory's international tour of Surrounded 2.0. The Unexpected Laboratory has been invited to create a new iteration of Surrounded at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland in Glasgow! With this collaboration, we will take our performance to premiere at the Prague Quadrennial in the Czech Republic!

                          With this invitation we have decided to go on tour!

As well as creating Surrounded 2.0, Will and Travis will be:

1) Work shopping and continuing to developing their new two-man show, as a part of the Surrounded series. During our time abroad, we will continue our research on Violence in the 21st century, specifically dealing with youth violence in our media driven society. We hope to present the work in the Fall season in Chicago, IL.

2) Developing a system of physical training for the actor which we are calling "The Atomic Performer." We will continue our research on physical theatres, acting pedagogy, and martial arts. Through research, practice and inquiry we have been exploring and testing a system of physical preparation for the stage that engages the actor’s imagination, body, voice and emotional life to get to a state of readiness where the performer can energetically come alive. The work includes training in acrobatics, martial arts, partner work, and vocal exercises to bring to life the conscious actor who is in control of their body and energy as the base to begin crafting a performance.


WE NEED YOUR HELP.

With your help, getting to these places becomes a little easier. All we are asking for is the funds to buy plane tickets to Scotland and Prague. This will help us to have personal funds for living, food, and other travel expenses.

It cost 2,200 to get us to Scotland, Prague and back home to Chicago where we hope to share our new project after work shopping it overseas.

(2x) Flight from Chicago to Scotland: $495

(2x) Flight from Scotland to Prague: $100

(2x) Flight from Prague to Chicago: $495

Our summer will start June 1st when we will meet the whole company in Scotland to begin our new phase of creation, training, and work shopping. This summer includes one ensemble show, workshops, a documentary, a manuscript of our development and our second international exchange.

"India Project" partnership with Visions Global Empowerment

This is a dream come true! At the age of 21, we are both finding opportunities for exciting adventures where we get to create our work and exchange with others in a global dialogue.

We are pleased to invite you to be a part of the biggest project yet! And we can't thank you enough for your support.

                                                                                              –Travis Coe and Will Greenburg
story_txt:
Hello! 
Thanks for having a look at our Surrounded tour campaign. As a founding member and Artistic Director of The Unexpected
Laboratory this project and opportunity is extremely important to me.  The company 
began as a way to make dangerous and interdisciplinary art that 
amplified the voices of people who felt that they were not yet old 
enough to stand as leaders in the arts and in society. Now in our third year, we have toured shows to Canada and various locations in the US, fostered the creation of award winning films, and offered educational programming in 
interdisciplinary creation to public high schools, universities, youth 
groups and organizations for people with physical and mental handicaps. I hope to answer some of your questions, but if you have any additional questions, you can leave them in the comments section on this Indiegogo. Thank you,Travis Coe _____________________________________________________________________________                                                                                               International Tour of "Surrounded"WHAT ARE WE UP TO:Chicago Artists, Will Greenburg and Travis Coe will join The Unexpected Laboratory's international tour of Surrounded 2.0. The Unexpected Laboratory has been invited to create a new iteration of Surrounded at the Royal Conservatoire
of Scotland in Glasgow! With this collaboration, we will take our performance to premiere at the
Prague Quadrennial in the Czech Republic!                           With this invitation we have decided
to go on tour!
As well
as creating Surrounded 2.0, Will and Travis will be:1) Work shopping and continuing to developing their new
two-man show, as a part of the Surrounded series. During our time abroad, we will continue our research on Violence in the 21st
century, specifically dealing with youth violence in our media driven society. We hope to present the work in the Fall season in Chicago, IL. 
2) Developing a system of physical training for the actor which we are calling "The Atomic Performer." We will continue our research on physical theatres, acting pedagogy, and
martial arts. Through research, practice and inquiry we have been exploring and
testing a system of physical preparation for the stage that engages the actor’s
imagination, body, voice and emotional life to get to a state of readiness
where the performer can energetically come alive. The
work includes training in acrobatics,
martial arts, partner work, and vocal exercises to bring to life the conscious
actor who is in control of their body and energy as the base to begin crafting
a performance.WE NEED YOUR HELP. 
With
your help, getting to these places becomes a little easier. All we are asking
for is the funds to buy plane tickets to Scotland and Prague.
This will help us to have personal funds for living, food, and other travel
expenses. 
It
cost 2,200 to get us to Scotland, Prague and back home to Chicago where we hope
to share our new project after work shopping it overseas. (2x) Flight from Chicago to Scotland: $495(2x) Flight from Scotland to Prague: $100(2x) Flight from Prague to Chicago: $495
Our
summer will start June 1st when we will meet the whole company in
Scotland to begin our new phase of creation, training, and work
shopping. This summer includes one ensemble show, workshops, a documentary,
a manuscript of our development and our second international exchange. "India Project" partnership with Visions Global EmpowermentThis is a dream come true! At the age of 21, we are
both finding opportunities for exciting adventures where we get to create our
work and exchange with others in a global dialogue.
We
are pleased to invite you to be a part of the biggest project yet! And we can't
thank you enough for your support.                                                                                              –Travis Coe and Will Greenburg

story:
Zarzuela – What is it?

Zarzuela is Spain’s national lyric theatre tradition, and is highly unique since it merges folkloric musical styles like the habanera and the fandango with classical musical structures. Zarzuelas are embedded in local Spanish culture, using elements like folkloric dance, local jargon, unusual instrumentation like castanets, and plot rooted in Spanish history. Much like its culinary counterpart, the zarzuela stew, the Zarzuela tradition is a feast for the eyes and ears – intricate dances, gorgeous sets, and breath-taking music. Zarzuela has its own variation in many countries that were once Spanish colonies like Cuba, the Philippines, and Mexico.

 

The Show

El Huésped Del Sevillano is Jacinto Guerrero’s masterpiece and has been dear to the hearts of Spaniards ever since its premiere in 1926. The story revolves around the kidnapping of a young woman, Raquel, at the hands of the powerful and cruel Don Diego. With the help of the cunning kitchen maid Constancia, Raquel’s rescuers - the court painter Juan Luis  and his squire Rodrigo – rush to the Sevillano Inn to free Raquel. The events unfold in front of a mysterious guest at the Inn, the famous writer Miguel de Cervantes, who, inspired by the witty Constancica,  begins to write one of his most exemplary novels, “La Ilustre Fregona”.

 

Why is this show important?

 

Beneath the twilit romantic action of El Huésped lies a deeply felt tribute to the Golden Age of Spain and the Spanish language’s most beloved writer, Don Miguel de Cervantes. This production is also my homage to Spanish-language theatre and artists, both of which are still underappreciated and under-represented in the current American performing arts climate. Frequently, Latinos are typecast and pigeonholed into one-dimensional, subservient, or threatening roles in mainstream media.

 Latinos are much more talented, creative, and ambitious. We can be the heroes, we can be the leading ladies, and we can be complex characters.  By staging this production, I want to shine a light on the talent, imagination, and dedication of Hispanic peoples both on stage and backstage in order to update the stereotypical conventions that American culture has upheld. Furthermore, while this project is perfectly catered to the Hispanic community, it will be accessible to non-Spanish speakers through the use of  supertitles and an excellent event for cultural exchange.


 Our Campaign

Our project is underway. We have secured our creative team and artists, formed a tentative rehearsal schedule, constructed a strong marketing plan, and begun designs for our costumes, sets, and lighting. There is only one thing holding us back – we need more funds to make sure this show is a success. We need to cover necessary expenses prior to our June performances, which include theatre venue rental, program and promotional material printing, sets, costumes, and props. This totals to $6,500.

Most of these expenses were going to be covered by (now) two Chicago arts organization. Unfortunately,  two of our sponsors did not receive enough government funding due to cuts to arts nationwide, which leaves us with a much more difficult funding situation than we had anticipated. We do have a few businesses offering sponsorship to our project, but we need the support of many more in order to cover necessary costs.

If you think this project is as wonderful as we do, please consider contributing to our campaign. Any contribution is greatly appreciated and is also tax-deductible! You can also check out our cool assortment of prizes for certain levels of contribution. Gracías!

Who are we?

 

Melissa Segarra – Producer of “El Huésped del Sevillano”.

 This is my second venture in producing zarzuela. My first production was 2014’s “La Dolorosa” at Chicago’s Casa Italia and Instituto Cervantes. I studied vocal performance, dramaturgy, and Spanish at Northwestern University and am highly interested in the intersection between the arts and social justice. I plan to pursue a master’s degree in the fall for Arts Management so I can produce art that is relevant, powerful, and impactful.

Grinlight Theater Company – Co-Producer and Head of the Creative Team.

Grinlight Theatre Company started in 2012 through the efforts of two Chicago theater veterans - José Mendiola and Max da Silva. Grinlight Theater Company focuses on creating theater specifically targeting Chicago’s burgeoning Hispanic population. They also offer acting workshops.

Main Street Opera – Fiscal Sponsor

Main Street Opera is a Chicago-based non-profit arts organization founded by Chicago finance expert and opera performer, Katherine Bergman. MSO ‘s mission focuses on spreading the joy of opera and theatre to local suburban communities throughout the Chicago area. They are currently in their fifth season. As fiscal sponsors, MSO has offered to extend their non-profit status to this production so that you can benefit from a tax deductible contribution.
